SourceText: If you have already noticed some changes in your life or relationship with your children, that's great!
text: Fa o setse o lemogile dingwe tsa diphetogo mo botshelong jwa gago kgotsa go botsalano le bana ba gago, go gontle!

SourceText: If you have not noticed any changes, please keep it up. Sometimes these things take time to change. We know you can do it!
text: Fa o ise o lemoge diphetogo dipe, ka kopo tswelela. Dilo tse di tsaya nako le bopelotelele go fetoga. Re a itse gore o tla kgona!

SourceText: If you have not noticed any changes, please keep it up. Sometimes these things take time to change. I know you can do it!
text: Fa o ise o lemoge diphetogo dipe, ka kopo tswelela. Dilo tse di tsaya nako le bopelotelele go fetoga. Ke a itse gore o tla kgona!

SourceText: It can be exhausting when your children have too much energy or can't focus on one thing. Sometimes, your children need opportunities to be very active and run around to help them be calm afterwards.
text: Go a lapisa fa bana ba gago ba na le matlhagatlhaga go feta kgotsa ba retelelwa ke go tsepama go selo se le sengwe.  Nako dingwe, bana ba gago ba tlhoka ditshono go nna matlhagatlhaga thata mme ba siane gotlhe go ithusa go ritibala moragonyana.

SourceText: Would you like suggestions for active and calm things to do with your child?
text: A o ka rata ditshitshinyo tsa dilo tse di matlhagatlhaga le tse di ritibetseng tse o ka di dirang le ngwana wa gago?

SourceText: Remember that you’re in charge of what they eat, but not how much. Newborns have stomach the size of a grape! They need to eat often (sometimes in the middle of the night). It’s important to build trust around eating, especially as your baby starts on solid food. Let them know you are listening to their wishes in the eating department. They’ll be ravenous again soon!
text: Gopola gore o laola gore ba ja eng, fela e seng gore bontsi jo bokae. Masea a na le mpa ya bogolo jwa terebe! Ba tlhoka go ja gantsi (nako dingwe le mo mpeng ya bosigo). Go botlhokwa go aga botshephegi ka go ja, segolo fa lesea la gago le simolola go ja dijo sentle. Ba lemose gore o reeditse dikeletso tsa bona go lefapha la dijo. Ba tla tshwarwa ke tlala gape go ise go e kae!

SourceText: Your baby will cry as soon as a caregiver’s attention is diverted and are cranky as well as clingy. Prioritise being there for them and give them physical contact when needed.
text: Lesea la gago le tla lela, le nne matepe le go ingaparela fela fa tsepamo ya motlhokomedi e tlhaela. Dira nako go nna gona go ba tlhokomela go nna ya botlhokwa mme o ba kgome fa go tlhokega.

SourceText: Would you like to learn more?
text: A o ka rata go ithuta go feta?

SourceText: Your baby or toddler may sometimes want something that they cannot have. If they start whining, first check to see if there is something wrong (are they actually hungry or tired)? If they continue, try to redirect their attention to something else. You should also try to ignore their behaviour while attending to them for comfort and support
text: Nako dingwe lesea kgotsa mapimpana wa gago a ka batla sengwe se a ka se kgoneng go se bona. Fa ba simolola go ngongorega, lekola pele go bona gore a go sengwe se se phoso (a tota ba tshwerwe ke tlala kgotsa ba lapile)? Fa ba tswelela, leka go ba tsepamisa go sengwe se sele. Gape o tshwanetse go leka go ikgatholosa maitsholo a bona ntse o ba neela namatshego le tshegetso

SourceText: Unfortunately, your baby will go through phases for the next 2 years of sleeping poorly. Try wearing @fields.child_nickname close to you, feeding them and carrying them in a sling. And hang in there, remember it’s a phase. You and @fields.child_nickname will get through it together!
text: Ka maswabi, lesea la gago le tla tsamaya dikgato tse tsa go sa robale sentle dingwaga di le 2 tse di latelang. Leka go tshola @fields.child_nicknamegaufi, ba jese le go ba pepa ka thari. Itshoke, o gopole gore seno se tla feta. Wena le@fields.child_nickname le tla feta mmogo!

SourceText: Unfortunately, your baby will go through phases for the next 2 years of sleeping poorly. Try wearing your baby close to you, feeding them and carrying them in a sling. And hang in there, remember it’s a phase. You and your baby will get through it together!

SourceText: Pay close attention to @fields.child_nickname in case they try something dangerous! Just because they are able to play on their own now, doesn’t mean you can look away for long. Redirect mischievous behaviours into practice waving, imitation games, singing and moving games and pretending to talk on the phone!
text: Elatlhoko 1 gongwe a ka leka sengwe se se kotsi Fela gonne ba kgona go itshamekisa, ga go reye gore o ka ba tlogela sebaka. Kaelagape maitsholo a boganana ka go tsholetsa seatla, go itirisa metshameko, go opela le metshameko ya go tsamaya le go itira o ka re o mo mogaleng!

SourceText: Pay close attention to your baby in case they try something dangerous! Just because they are able to play on their own now, doesn’t mean you can look away for long. Redirect mischievous behaviours into practice waving, imitation games, singing and moving games and pretending to talk on the phone!
text: Ela lesea la gago tlhoko gongwe a ka leka sengwe se se kotsi! Fela gonne ba kgona go itshamekisa, ga go reye gore o ka ba tlogela sebaka. Kaelagape maitsholo a boganana ka go tsholetsa seatla, go itirisa metshameko, go opela le metshameko ya go tsamaya le go itira o ka re o mo mogaleng!

SourceText: Try to stay calm and support @fields.child_nickname as they move through the tantrum. Your priority is to ensure that they don’t hurt themselves. Don’t add to @fields.child_nickname’s anger by shouting and showing angry emotions. This won’t help.
text: Leka go ritibala le go tshegetsa 1 jaaka a tsweletse a matepe. Sa botlhokwa ke go netefatsa gore ba ikgobatse. Se tlaleletse go 2 go ngala ga gagwe ka go goeletsa le go bontsha maikutlo a kgalefo. Seo se ka se go thuse.

SourceText: Try to stay calm and support your toddler as they move through the tantrum. Your priority is to ensure that they don’t hurt themselves. Don’t add to your child’s anger by shouting and showing angry emotions. This won’t help.
text: Leka go ritibala le go tshegetsa lesea la gago jaaka a tsweletse a matepe. Sa botlhokwa ke go netefatsa gore ba ikgobatse. Se tlaleletse go go ngala ga ngwana wa gago ka go goeletsa le go bontsha maikutlo a kgalefo. Seo se ka se go thuse.

SourceText: Babies are much more likely to want to do things if you make the activity fun and playful. Patience is also a must. Take a deep breath if you notice yourself getting frustrated by @fields.child_nickname.

SourceText: It is hard to find time to have fun with your children. How many days in the past week did you do something fun together? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)
text: Go thata go bona nako ya go itumela le bana ba gago. Le dirile sengwe se se monate mmogo malatsi a le makae mo bekeng e e fetileng? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)

SourceText: If you don't want to answer, please type 99.
text: Fa o sa rate go araba, ka kopo tlanya 99.

SourceText: Sorry, I don't understand what you mean. Please reply with a number between 0 and 7.
text: Intshwarele, ga ke go tlhaloganye. Ka kopo araba ka nomoro magareng ga 0 le 7.

SourceText: Amazing that you keep doing fun things with your child. You are the best parent they could wish for!
text: Go itumedisa gore o be o tsweletse go dira dilo tse di monate le ngwana wa gago. O motsadi yo o molemo yo o ba ka go eletsang!

SourceText: Great that you are setting aside time with your child – it is THE foundation for a happy home!
text: Go gontle go bo o beela nako thoko go nna le ngwana wa gago - ke MOTHEO wa legae la boitumelo!

SourceText: Finding time to do something fun with your child can be hard, I understand! The great thing is that spending time together will make other things go easier – you will see!
text: Go bona nako go nna mmogo le ngwana wa gago go ka nna popota, ke a tlhaloganya! Selo se sentle ke gore o nna le nako mmogo go tla tokafatsa dilo tse dingwe - o tla bona!

SourceText: Give yourself credit for trying. A 5 minutes of fun activity with your child a day can make a BIG difference.
text: Itebogele gore o a leka. Tirwana e e itumedisang ya metsotso e le 5 le ngwana wa gago ka letsatsi go tla tlhola pharologanyo e KGOLO.

SourceText: Life can get so busy sometimes, I know! If you start spending time together doing one small activity, it will get easier over time!
text: Botshelo bo ka tlala mekgaphe nako dingwe, ke a itse! Fa o simolola go nna le nako mmogo le dira tirwana e nnye, go tla tokafala fa nako e ntse e tsamaya!

SourceText: In our busy lives, it's hard to focus on the positive. How many days in the past week have you praised your child? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)
text: Mo mekgapheng ya botshelo jwa rona go boima go tsepama go se se siameng. O akgotse mosha wa gago ga kae mo bekeng e e fetileng? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)

SourceText: We all sometimes feel like our children are causing more negativity than positivity. Try to see through negative attitudes and praise any positive behaviour you notice. With time, you will see the change!
text: Ka nako dingwe re ikutlwa o kare bana ba rona ba tlhola tse di sa siamang go feta tse di siameng. Leka go bona ka kwa ga maitseo a a sa siamang mme o akgole maitsholo a a siameng a o a elangtlhoko. Fa nako e ya, o tla bona diphetogo!

SourceText: This is a very stressful time for families. How many days in the past week did you feel very stressed as a parent/caregiver? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)
text: Eno ke nako e e tshwenyang mo maikutlong mo malapeng. Ke malatsi a le kae a o neng o ikutlwa o tshwenyegile mo maikutlong jaaka motsadi/motlhokomedi mo bekeng e e fetileng? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)

SourceText: Would you like a brief activity to help you with stress?
text: A o ka rata tirwana e khutswane go go thusa ka katelelo?

SourceText: Would like a brief relaxing activity now?
text: A o ka rata tirwana e khutswane gogo thusa go repa jaanong?

SourceText: Sometimes our children make us really upset. How many days in the past week did you shout, scream, or yell at your children? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)
text: Ka dinako tse dingwe bana ba rona ba dira gore re tenege thata. Mo bekeng e e fetileng o omantse kgotsa o goile mosha wa gago malatsi a le kae? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)

SourceText: It can be difficult to control our anger, especially when they make us really angry. Take a deep breath, and be proud of yourself when you manage to do it!
text: Go ka nna bokete go laola kgalefo ya gago, segolo fa ba re galefisa tota. Hemela kwa teng, mme o itlotlomatse fa o kgona go e laola!

SourceText: Sorry that you are having a difficult time with your child. It happens to all of us. Remember, we can choose to behave differently next time.
text: Ke maswabi go utlwa gore o na le bothata ka ngwana wa gago. Re re diragalela rotlhe. Gopola, re ka kgetha go itshola botoka mo nakong e e tlang.

SourceText: Being a parent is not easy. Try to be patient with yourself and your family, and take some space if you need it. By talking about our challenges calmly, we can solve them together!
text: Go nna motsadi ga go bonolo. Leka go nna pelotelele go wena le go balelapa la gago, mme o iphe nako fa o e tlhoka. Ka go bua ka dikgwetlho tsa rona ka thitibalo, re ka di rarabolola mmogo!

SourceText: Great work! When we respond calmly, our teens are more likely to do the same.
text: Tiro e ntle! Fa re araba ka thitibalo, basha ba rona ba ka dira fela jalo.

SourceText: Our children can really drive us crazy sometimes. By responding calmly, they will learn to do the same when something upsets them at home or outside. Your patience will pay off, you will see!
text: Bana ba rona ba kgona go re galefisa tota nako dingwe. Ka go araba ka thitibalo, ba tla ithuta go dira fela jalo fa sengwe se ba kgopisa kwa gae kgotsa gongwe fela. Bopelotelele jwa gago bo tla go tswela mosola, o tla bona!

SourceText: It is so stressful when children misbehave. How many days in the past week did you physically discipline your children by hitting, spanking, or slapping with your hand or an object like a stick or a belt? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)
text: Go tshwenya mo maikutlong tota fa bana ba sa itshware sentle. Mo bekeng e e fetileng, ke malatsi a makae a o kileng wa otlhaya bana ba gago mo mmeleng ka go ba itaya, go ba kgwathisa, kgotsa go ba faphola ka seatla sa gago kgotsa ka sengwe jaaka thupa kgotsa lebanta? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)

SourceText: We all struggle to stay calm sometimes. Take a deep breath and remember that mistakes are human. Talking to your child will help more in the end – you are an awesome parent!
text: Re kgaratlhela go ritibala nako dingwe. Hemela kwa teng mme o gopole gore phoso e dirwa ke motho. Go bua le ngwana wa gago go tla thusa bontsi kwa bokhutlong - o motsadi yo o tlhotlhwa!

SourceText: It can be so difficult to keep calm when things get out of hand. Try again next time – each day is a new opportunity!
text: Go ka nna bokete go ritibala fa dilo di tswa mo taolong. Leka gape nako e e tlang - letsatsi le lentsatsi ke tshono e ntshwa!

SourceText: It sounds like you are having a difficult time with your child. This can be really hard so be patient with yourself. Try to take a pause (even one deep breath!) next time and respond differently. You can do it!
text: Go utlwala o kare o na le bothata ka ngwana wa gago. Seno se ka nna bokete tota go nna pelo telele go wena. Leka go ema go se kae (le fa e le mothamo o le mongwe wa go heleme kwa teng) nako e e latelang mme o arabe ka pharologanyo. O ka dira seno!

SourceText: Money is one of the biggest stresses for families now. How many days in the past week have you felt very worried or anxious about money? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)
text: Madi ke nngwe ya tse dikgolo e e dirang gore malapa a tshwenyege mo maikutlong gone gaanong. O ikutlwile o tshwenyegile kgotsa o akanya thata ka madi malatsi a le kae mo bekeng e e fetileng? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)

SourceText: How many days in the past month (30 days) did you run out of money to pay for food? (0, 1, 2, 3, ... 30)?
text: Ke malatsi a le kae mo kgweding (malatsi a 30) e e fetileng mo o o neng o felelwa ke madi a go duela dijo? (0, 1, 2, 3, ... 30)?

SourceText: Sorry, I don't understand what you mean. Please reply with a number between 0 and 30.
text: Intshwarele, ga ke go tlhaloganye. Ka kopo araba ka nomoro magareng ga 0 le 30.

SourceText: It can sometimes be difficult to have a positive relationship with our children. How confident do you feel about your ability as a parent/caregiver to have a positive relationship with your children? (0=not confident to 7=extremely confident)
text: Nako dingwe go ka nna bokete go nna le kamano e e siameng le bana ba rona. O itshepa go le kae ka ga bokgoni jwa gago jaaka motsadi/motlhokomedi go nna le botsalano jo bo siameng le bana ba gago? (0=ga ke itshepe go ya go 7=ke itshepa go feta)

SourceText: Having a positive relationship with our children can be difficult, especially during stressful times. You might want to try spending a little more One-on-One Time with your child. It will show them that they are valued and loved.
text: Go nna le kamano e e simaneg le bana ba rona go ka nna bokete, segolo mo dinakong tse di dikgwetlho. O ka rata go nna le Nako ya Motho-ka-Mong le ngwana wa gago. Go tla ba bontsha gore o bona boleng jwa bona le gore o a ba rata.

SourceText: It is so wonderful to hear that you are able to maintain a positive relationship with your children. They really benefit from having you as a source of love and support in their lives.
text: Go a itumedisa go utlwa gore o kgona go tshegetsa botsalano jo bo siameng le bana ba gago. Ba a ungwelwa fa ba na le wena jaaka motswedi wa lerato le tshegetsoo matshelong a bona.

SourceText: Bonus question: We all want to keep our children safe. In the past month, have you talked with your child about keeping safe from sexual violence online or offline? This could be when they are going out with friends, or talking about the websites they use.

Mo kgweding e e fetileng a o buile le ngwana wa gago ka go itshola a sireletsegile mo tirisong dikgoka ya tlhakanelo dikobo mo mafaratlhatlheng kgotsa ka namana? SourceText: Hi! Were you able to follow the steps to stay safe online?
text: Dumela! A o kgonne go latela dikgato tsa go nna o sireletsegile mo mafaratlhatlheng?

SourceText: Would you like to review the content?
text: A o ka rata go go leba diteng gape?

SourceText: It can be hard to find time during your day, with work, chores, and everything else. Can you think of even 30 minutes this week to do this activity? It will make a big difference in keeping you safe online. You can do it!
text: Ee, go ka nna boima go nna le nako motshegare, ka tiro, ditiro tsa legae, le dilo tse dingwe tsotlhe. A o kgona go akanya le fa e le metsotso e le 30 mo bekeng eno go dira tirwana eno? Go tla tlhola pharologanyo e kgolo go itshola o sireletsegile mo mafaratlhatlheng. O ka dira seno!

SourceText: That is okay! Here is a list of some of the risks and dangers that you may encounter online:
text: Seo se siame! Fano ke lenaneo la mangwe a matshosetsi le dikotsi tse o ka rakanang natso mo mafaratlhatlheng:

SourceText: • Adults targeting people for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.
text: Bagolo ba lepane le batho go ba dirisetsa mesola ya thobalano mo sohiale mmediyeng, metshameko, le dipolatefomo tsa melaetsa.

SourceText: • Harmful content – like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography
text: Diteng tse di gobatsang - jaaka tirisodikgoka, go tlhoa basadi, go tlhoa batswantle, go rotloetsa go ipolaya le go ikgobatsa, tshedimosetso e e fosagetseng, le ditshwantsho tsa thobalano

SourceText: • Sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos.
text: Go arolelanela tshedimosetso ya sebele le ditshwantsho kgotsa dibidiyo tsa thobalano.

SourceText: • Cyberbullying from other people and strangers.
text: Kgokontsho ka inthanete go tswa go batho ba bangwe le batho ba re sa ba itseng.

SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are finding this challenging. Here is a review on quick technical fixes:
text: Re itshwarele go bo o fitlhela seno se gwetlha. Fano ke teboseswa ya diphosololo tsa ka bonako tsa setegeniki:

SourceText: • Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.
text: Tshuba SafeSearch mo sebatlising sa gago go laola diteng tsa bagolo.

SourceText: https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/entertainment-search-engines/
text: https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/entertainment-search-engines/

SourceText: • Set up parental controls.
text: Tsenya ditaolo ka motsadi.

SourceText: https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/
text: https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/

SourceText: • Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.
text: Tsenya maparego a bosephiri a a gagametseng go diapp le metshameko mo mafaratlhatlheng.

SourceText: https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/social-media/
text: https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/social-media/

SourceText: • Cover webcams when not in use.
text: Khurumetsa khamera ya wepo fa o sa e dirise.

SourceText: That is okay! Here are some websites where you can report to and seek help from:
text: Seo se siame! Fano ke dingwe tsa diweposaete fao o ka begang le go batla thuso:

SourceText: Report to INHOPE Hotlines and IWF portals to get support if you experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.
text: Bega go INHOPE Hotlines le dipotale tsa IWF go bona tshegetso fa o itemogela tirisodikgoka ya mafaratlhatlha kgotsa dilo dingwe tse di sa amogelesegeng.

SourceText: INHOPE Hotlines: https://www.inhope.org/EN#hotlineReferral
text: INHOPE Hotlines: https://www.inhope.org/EN#hotlineReferral

SourceText: IWF portals: https://report.iwf.org.uk/en
text: IWF portals: https://report.iwf.org.uk/en

SourceText: Child Helpline: https://www.childhelplineinternational.org/
text: Child Helpline: https://www.childhelplineinternational.org/

SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are finding this challenging. Try balancing the time that you spend online and offline. Set an amount of time that you can spend online and try it for a week. If you succeed, try adding a little bit more offline time every week. You can do this!
text: Re itshwarele go bo o fitlhela seno se gwetlha. Leka go lekantsha nako e o e tsayang mo mafaratlhatlheng e o se mo mafaratlhatlheng. Baya bokana jwa nako e o e tsayang mo mafaratlhatlheng mme o e leke beke. Fa o atlega, leka go tsenya nako e e fetang o se mo mafaratlhatlheng bele nngwe le nngwe. O ka dira seno!

SourceText: First person gets to choose or sing a song.

SourceText: Everyone else must guess the name of the tune (to make it harder they can guess the singer).

SourceText: The first one to guess it right becomes the next leader who will choose or sing the next song.

SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are not having a good day. It is completely normal to be going through a difficult time now. Remember that you are not alone.
text: Ke maswabi go utlwa gore gompieno go thatanyana. Go tlwaelegile ka gotlhe go bo o le mo nakong e e boima gajaana. Gopola gore ga o nosi.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you get through the day!

SourceText: Recognise what is happening for you in this moment. What are you thinking? Are your thoughts positive or negative. How do you feel? Do you feel pleasant or unpleasant? How does your body feel? Do you feel tense or relaxed?
text: Lemoga se se go diragalelang gone jaanong. Ke eng se o se akanyang? A dikakanyo tsa gago di siame kgotsa ga di a siama. O ikutlwa jang? O ikutlwa sentle kgotsa ga o ikutlwe sentle? Mmele wa gago o ikutlwa jang? O ikutlwa o gateletswe kgotsa o repile?

SourceText: Sit comfortably and close your eyes. Connect to your heart in a kind and gentle way. You may want to place one hand on your heart or chest. Say the following words silently to yourself:
text: Dula sentle mme o tswale matlho a gago. Golagana le pelo ya gago ka tsela e e siameng le e e bonolo. O ka nna wa batla go baya letsogo la gago mo pelong ya gago kgotsa mo sefubeng sa gago. Ipolelele mafoko a a latelang ka tidimalo:

SourceText: Take a moment to reflect on your experience. Notice if you feel any different.
text: Tsaya motsotso go akanya ka maitemogelo a gago. Lemoga fa o utlwa pharologanyo.

SourceText: May I be peaceful.
text: A ke nne kagiso.

SourceText: May I be safe.
text: A ke nne ke sireletsegile.

SourceText: May I be healthy.
text: A ke nne le boitekanelo jo bo siameng.

SourceText: May I be happy.
text: A ke itumele.

SourceText: May there be love in my family.
text: A go nne le lorato mo lelapeng la me.

SourceText: May I feel loved.
text: A ke ikutlwe ke ratiwa.

SourceText: It can be difficult to find the time to ask our partners for their opinions when we are making decisions. Can you think of a time during the day when both you and your partner might be less busy, such as early in the morning or later in the evening?

SourceText: Sorry to hear that your partner reacted negatively. Be proud of yourself for trying and be gentle with yourself. Remember you can always get extra support by typing "Help".

SourceText: It can sometimes be hard to know how to involve your partner when making a decision. Sometimes all you need to do is to ask them what they think. This shows them you care and want them to be involved!
text: Nako dingwe go ka nna boima go itse gore o ka tsenyeletsa molekane wa gago jang fa o tsaya ditshwetso. Nako dingwe se o tlhokang go se dira fela ke go mmotsa gore o akanya eng? seno se supa gore o a kgathala le gore o batla e nna karolo!

SourceText: It can be hard to remember to involve our partners in decision making. If you forget, it’s important to try again! Asking them for their opinion shows them that you care and want them to be involved.

SourceText: It can take time to get used to making decisions together. Give yourself time to adjust. Remember that by communicating with your partner and involving them in decision-making, they will start to feel more comfortable doing so too.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to guide you through a fun physical activity!
text: Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo go go kaela go tirwana ya mmele ya go iitumedisa!

SourceText: Stand up and stretch your arms up like you are reaching to the sky. Pretend to push away any clouds and let the sun shine down on you. Stretch to both sides. Stretch to the front and to the back.
text: Ema mme o otlololele diatla tsa gago ko godimo. Itire o ka re o sutisa maru a o a bonang mme o letle letsatsi le go phatsimele. Ikotlololele ko matlhakoreng o o mabedi. Ikotlololele ko pele le ko morago.

SourceText: Here's a fun video of a physical activity that can help you release stress and keep healthy!
text: Fano ke bidiyo e e itumedisang ya tirwana ya mmele e e ka go thusang go tlosa kgatelelo le go itshola o itekanetse!

SourceText: Let your hand hang by your side. As you breathe in, squeeze your shoulders tightly up to your ears, scrunch your eyes and face, and hold your breath. Release your breath and then relax your shoulders and body.
text: Letla letsogo la gago le akgegele mo letlhakoreng la gago. Fa o ntse o hemela ko teng, gatelela magetla a gago go ya kwa ditsebeng, gagamatsa matlho le sefatlhego sa gago, mme o tshware mowa wa gago. Tlogelela mowa wa gago mme o repise magetla le mmele.

SourceText: Relax your arms and let your arms swing sideways, and turn your upper body. Your arms should gently hit your back as you twist from side to side.
text: Repisa matsogo a gago mme letlelela matsogo a gago go elela ko pele le ko morago, mme o thedimosetse mmele wa gago o o ko godimo. Matsogo a gago a iteye mokotla wa gago ka bonolo fa o ntse o sokamisetsa ko matlhakoreng.

SourceText: Place one foot in front of the other and make small circles from ankles, remember to turn to both sides. Do each foot with four circles in each direction.
text: Baya leoto mo pele ga le lengwe mme o dire dikgolokwe tse dinnye ka legwejana, gopola go dira mo matlhakoreng o o mabedi. Dira leoto lengwe le lengwe ka dikgolokwe tse nne mo matlhakoreng otlhe.

SourceText: Now shake your whole body as fast as you can. Shake it up high! Shake it down low! Shake it all around!
text: Jaanong tshikinya mmele wa gago otlhe ka bonako jo o ka bo kgonang. Tshikinyetsa ko godimo! Tshikinyetsa ko tlase! Tshikinyetsa go dikologa otlhe!

SourceText: Close your eyes and raise your arms slowly above your head as you breathe in. Lower your arms slowly to your side as you breathe out.
text: Tswala matlho mme o emise matsogo a gago ka bonya mo godimo ga tlhogo ya gago fa o ntse o hemela ko teng. Isa matsogo a gago ka bonya ko letlhakoreng la gago fa o ntse o hemela kwa ntle.

SourceText: Sometimes it can be hard to find time during the day. Can you think of a time when you’re less busy? For example, maybe it is easier to help out with housework later in the evening when some of the children have gone to sleep. Try to see what works for you!
text: Nako nngwe go ka nna bokete go nna le nako mo letsatsing. A o ka akanya kanako eo o neng o sena mekgapheo? Sekao, gongwe go ka nna bonolo go thusa ka tiro ya fa gae moragonayana maitseboa fa bangwe ba bana ba setse ba robetse. Leka go bona se se go direlang!

SourceText: Ask them! By telling your partner you want to help out but don’t know how, you are showing them you care and are interested in being involved. This can also help family members understand each other better.
text: Ba kope! Ka go bolelela molekane wa gago gore o batla go thusa fela ga o itse gore jang, o mo lemosa gore o a kgathale le gore o batla go nna karolo. Gape, seno se ka thusa maloko a lelapa go tlhaloganyana botoka.

SourceText: It can be difficult to remember to ask others what they need help with. Once you start offering to help however, others may realise you want to be involved and may ask for help when they need it!
text: Go ka nna bokete go gopola go botsa ba bangwe gore ba tlhoka thuso mo go eng. Fela fa o simolotse go neelana ka thuso, ba bangwe ba tla lemoga gore o batla go nna karolo mme ba ka kopa thuso fa ba e tlhoka!

SourceText: It can be hard to ask for help. Sometimes we expect our partners to know we need help even if we don’t ask them. Once you start telling however, they will likely start offering to help more often in the future.
text: Go ka nna bokete go kopa thuso. Nako dingwe re lebelela gore balekane ba rona ba itse gore re tlhoka thuso le fa re sa e kope. fa o simolola go go ba bolelela ba ka simolola go neelana ka thuso gantso mo isagong.

SourceText: Be kind to yourself - trying something new is often hard at first! Give yourself time to adjust. Also remind yourself that helping your partner with these tasks benefits the whole family!
text: Ineneketse - go leka sengwe se seswa gantsi go bokete kwa tshimologong! Iphe nako go tlwaela. Gape ikgopotse gore ka go thusa molekane wa gago ka ditiro tseno go ungwela lelapa lotlhe!

SourceText: Hello @fields.user_name! This is a stressful time, especially for fathers. When we are stressed or angry, we do not make the best decisions. Taking the time to care for ourselves will help us care for our children.

SourceText: It looks like you are facing an emergency. Can you please tell us what kind of assistance you require?
text: Go lebega o ka re o lebagane le maemo a tshoganyetso. a o ka re bolelela ka kopo gore o tlhoka thuso ya mofuta mang?

SourceText: Type "SOS" at any time if you would like the details of any other emergency service or hotline. Remember everything you say will be completely private!
text: Tlanya “SOS” nako nngwe le nngwe fa o batla dintlha tsa tirelo nngwe fela kgotsa mogala wa tsa tshoganyetso. Gopola, tsotlhe tse o tla di buang di tla tsholwa di le poraefete ka gotlhe!

SourceText: Let's take a pause together! Take a deep breath and ask yourself, "What am I thinking?"
text: Tla re eme go se kae! Hemela kwa teng mme o ipotse, “Ke akanya eng?”

SourceText: Notice if your thoughts are positive or negative. Notice if your emotions are pleasant or unpleasant. Whatever you are feeling, it is okay. Notice how your body feels. Notice anything that hurts or is tense.
text: Lemoga fa dikakanyo tsa gago di siame kgotsa di sa siama. Lemoga fa maikutlo a gago a siame kgotsa a sa siama. Maikutlo mangwe le mangwe fela, go siame. Lemoga kafa mmele wa gago o ikutlwang ka gone. Lemoga fa sengwe se le botlhoko kgotsa se gagametse.

SourceText: Focus on your breath as it goes in and out. Do this for about 10 breaths.
text: Reetsa tsela e o hemang ka yone o ntse o tsenya mowa o bo o o ntsha. Dira seno o hema ga 10.

SourceText: Now, expand your awareness to your whole body. Listen to the sounds in the room.
text: Atolosa temogo ya gago mo mmeleng otlhe wa gago. Reetsa medumo e e mo kamoreng.

SourceText: Take a moment to reflect on whether you feel any different.
text: Tsaya motsotso go bona fa o utlwa pharologanyo epe.

SourceText: Here's a video about how to keep calm and manage stress in our busy lives.
text: Fano ke bidiyo ka ga gore o itshola jang ka thitibalo le go laola kgatelelo mo matshelong a rona a a mekgaphe.

SourceText: Taking a Pause is a simple relaxation activity that you can do whenever you are feeling stressed or worried. It can also be helpful when you find your child is irritating you or has done something wrong.
text: Go ema go se kae ke tirwana e e bonolo ya go repa e o ka e dirang fela fa o ikutlwa go imetswe kgotsa o tshwenyegile. Gape e ka nna le mosola fa o fitlhela ngwana wa gago a go somola mowa kgotsa a dirile sengwe se se phoso.

SourceText: Here is a comic to remind you of taking a pause!
text: Fano ke motlae go go gopotsa go ema go se kae!

SourceText: “How am I going to get through this?”
text: “Ke tlile go kgona se jang?”

SourceText: “Whatever it is, I am okay.”
text: “Ga go tshwenye gore ke eng, Ke siame.”

SourceText: “Breathe in. Breathe out."
text: “Hemela teng. Hemela kwa ntle.”

SourceText: “I can do this. We will get through it together.”
text: Ke tla dira seno. Mmogo re tla kgona.”

SourceText: Chat later!
text: Tla re bue moragonyana!

SourceText: Well done for Taking a Pause @fields.user_name. You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Over the next few days, try taking a pause whenever you are feeling stressed. It gives you a chance to be calmer. Even a few deep breaths or connecting with the ground beneath you can make a difference. You can also Take a Pause with your Child!
text: O dirile bontle ka go Ema go se kae 1tsentse kgono e le nngwe go Kaedi ya Botsadi beke eno. Mo malatsi a a tlang a a mmalwa, leka go ema go se kae fela fa o ikutlwa o imetswe. SourceText: Hi @fields.user_name! Were you able to spend 5 minutes or more of One-on-One Time with your children today?
text: Dumela @fields.user_name! A o kgonne go nna le metsotso e le 5 kgotsa go feta ya Nako ya Motho ka mong le bana ba gago gompieno?
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Hi! Were you able to spend 5 minutes or more of One-on-One Time with your children today?
text: Dumela! A o kgonne go nna le metsotso e le 5 kgotsa go feta ya Nako ya Motho ka mong le bana ba gago gompieno?

SourceText: Wonderful! Spending One-on-One Time with your children may make them more willing to help out more often. You are doing great!
text: Bontle tota! Go fetsa nako ya Motho ka Mong le bana ba gago go ka dira gore ba batle go go thusa go feta. O dira sentle!

SourceText: We understand that spending One-on-One Time can sometimes be difficult. Here are some of the main reasons parents struggle. Which one is the closest to you?
text: R tlhaloganya gore go nna le Nako ya Motho ka Mong go ka nna bokete nako dingwe. Fano ke mangwe a mabakamagolo a a tshwenyang batsadi. Ke lefe le bapileng go feta le wena?

SourceText: It can be hard to find time during your day, with work, chores, and everything else. Can you think of a time each day that you can make 5 minutes or a bit more? You can even make household chores into a game to do together. Even 5 minutes can make a big difference!
text: Ee, go ka nna boima go nna le nako motshegare, ka tiro, ditiro tsa legae, le dilo tse dingwe tsotlhe. Akanya ka nako tsatsi lengwe le lengwe e nka beelang kwa thoko metsotso e le 5 kgotsa e e oketsegileng. O ka fetola tiro ya fa gae go nna motshameko o le o tshamekang mmogo. Le metsotso e le 5 fela ka letsatsi e ka dira pharologanyo e kgolo!

SourceText: Children often want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget. Sometimes you might want to give them some other fun options to do instead (Type: "Help" if you want a suggestion).
text: Bana gantsi ba batla go nna ba lebeletse T.V. kgotsa ba tshameka ka sedirisiwa sa eleketeroniki. Nako dingwe o ka batla go ba neela diitlhophelo tse dingwe gore ba di dire gona le go (Tlanya: “Thusa” fa o batla tshitsinyo).

SourceText: It can make you feel bad if your children do not want to spend One-on-One Time with you. Think to yourself: When are they more open to you? Maybe in the morning or right before bedtime.
text: Go ka utlwisa botlhoko tota fa bana ba rona ba sa batle go ipha nako le rona. Akanya: Ba go phuthologela leng? Gongwe mo mosong kgotsa fela pele ba robala.

SourceText: Competitive games can be challenging for children (and adults!) if they have difficulty losing. You may want to suggest other activities that you can play together instead of against each other (Type "Help" if you want a suggestion").
text: Metshameko ya dikgaisano e ka nna kgwetlho mo baneng (le bagolo!) fa ba sa kgone go amogela fa ba fentswe. O ka batla go tshitsinya ditirwana tse dingwe tse le ka di dirang mmogo gona le kgatlhanong (Tlanya “Thusa” fa o batla tshitsinyo”)

SourceText: Sometimes our children will suggest activities that are violent or unsafe. Explain why they can't, and try suggesting alternative activities that would be more appropriate. Type "Help" if you want a suggestion.
text: Nako dingwe bana ba rona ba tla tshitsinya ditirwana tsa tirisodikgoka kgotsa di sa bolokega. tlhalosa gore ke goreng ba sa tshwanela, mme o leke go tshitsinya ditirwana refosano tse di ka nnang maleba. Tlanya “Thusa” fa o batla tshitsinyo.

SourceText: It can be difficult to spend One-on-One Time with each one child when you have more than one child. If possible, you can ask another adult or older sibling to look after the other children while you spend One-on-One Time with one child.

SourceText: You can also think of times when it would be easier to spend One-on-One Time each child, like later in the evening with an older child after the others have gone to sleep.

SourceText: Today's tip is about spending One-on-One Time with Our Children.
text: Kakantsho ya gompieno ka ga go nna le nako ya motho ka mong le bana ba rona.

SourceText: Children learn through play! Here is a comic about spending one-on-one time with your baby!
text: Bana ba ithuta ka motshameko! Fano ke motlae ka ga go nnako le nako ya motho ka mong le lesea la gago!

SourceText: Parent: "Such a strong baby you are."
text: Motsadi: “O lesea le le matlajang.”

SourceText: Parent: "We are making a delicious meal together."
text: Motsadi: “Re dira dijo tse di latswegang mmogo.”

SourceText: Parent: “Here I am?”
text: Motsadi: “Ke fano?”

SourceText: Baby: "Ha ha ha!"
text: Nana: "Ha ha ha!"

SourceText: Parent: "Wow! You have stacked 3 blocks on top of each other. Well done!"
text: Motsadi: "Iyo! O agile diboloko di le 3 e nngwe fa godimo ga e nngwe. O dirile sentle!”

SourceText: I know that you have already received this tip (well done!).Would you like to review it again?
text: Ke a itse gore o setse o amogetse kakantsho eno (tiro e ntle!). A o ka rata go e lebagape?

SourceText: Invest in One-on-One Time! The more time you spend with your children, the more likely they will listen to you and behave well at other times. It really works!
text: Beeletsa go Nako ya Motho ka mong! Nako e o iphang yona le bana ba gago, e tla thusa gore ba reetse go feta le go itshola sentle mo nakong tse dingwe. E thusa tota!

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to receive more tips about how to manage your child's behaviour.
text: Ga se bothata! Ka gale o ka tlanya “Thusa” fa o batla go amogela dikakantsho tse dingwe ka ga gore o ka laola jang maitsholo a ngwana wa gago.

SourceText: The first 1000 days of life are a window of opportunity for your baby. It is when their brain develops faster than any other time in their life. When you spend time with your baby, you build a healthy attachment between you both that will make them feel secure and loved.
text: Malatsi a ntlha a le 1000 a botshelo jwa ngwana wa gago le paka ya tshono go lesea la gago. Ke fa boboko jwa bona bo golela ka bonako go feta nako nngwe fela mo matshelong a bona. Fa o ipha nako le lesea la gago, o aga kamano e e itekanetseng magareng ga lona e e tla dirang gore a ikutlwe a bolokegile le go ratiwa.

SourceText: Here are 7 easy tips to make One-on-One Time with your baby a success:
text: Fano le dikakantsho di le 7 tse di bonolo go atlega ka nako ya motho ka mong le lesea la gago:

SourceText: 1. Do it every day
text: 1. Dira se letsatsi le letsatsi

SourceText: 2. Be close to your baby
text: 2. Atamelana le lesea la gago

SourceText: 3. Let your baby take the lead
text: 3. Letla lesea la gago go di etapele

SourceText: 4. Observe and listen to your child
text: 4. Lebelela le go reetsa ngwana wa gago

SourceText: 5. Play with your baby
text: 5. Tshameka le lesea la gago

SourceText: 6. Talk to your baby
text: 6. Bua le lesea la gago

SourceText: 7. You can have quality time with your baby anytime!
text: 7. O ka nna le nako e e boleng le lesea la gago nako nngwe le nngwe!

SourceText: To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "7". You can also type "N" to move on.
text: Go ithuta go le gontsi ka nngwe ya dikakantsho tse, tlanya “1” go ya go “7”. Gape o ka tlanya “N”go tswelelapele.

SourceText: 2. Be close to your child.
text: 2. Atamelana le lesea la gago.

SourceText: Skin-to-skin contact is especially important for new-borns and infants. For older toddlers, make sure you are at the same level as they are.
text: Kgomano ka mmele e botlhokwa segolo go masea le bomapimpana. Go bana ba bagolwane, netefatsa gore o boemo golekalekana le bona.

SourceText: Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Remember that the world is brand new to your child!
text: Bana ba tlhoka go dira dilo ka nako ya bona. Leka go ba neela nako go utolola mme o nne pelotelele. Gopola gore go ngwana wa gago lefatshe ke sengwe se seswa!

SourceText: Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening. Speak with enthusiasm when describing what your child is doing. Here is a comic on how to communicate with your baby.
text: Dirisa mafoko go tlhalosa dikgato, mebala, dipopego, dinomoro, bogolo, boalo, thempereisha, ditatso, medumo, le sengwe fela se se diragalang. Bua ka mafolofolo fa o tlhalosa se ngwana wa gago a se dirang. Fano ke khomiki ka ga gore o ka tlhaeletsana jang le lesea la gago.

SourceText: Parent: "You are such a beautiful person"
text: Motsadi: “O motho yo montle tota”

SourceText: Parent: "Buh, buh, buh, big baby!"
text: Motsadi: "Buh, buh, buh, kgarebe la mmagwe!"

SourceText: Baby: "Buh, buh, buh…"
text: Nana: "Buh, buh, buh…"

SourceText: Parent: "And then there were two green parrots in the mango tree!"
text: Motsadi: “Mme go ne gona le dipapage tse pedi tse tala godimo sa setlhare sa dimmengu!”

SourceText: Parent: "And now I am cleaning your toes, and your feet, and your knees…"
text: Motsadi: “Mme jaanong ke phepafatsa menwana ya gago ya maoto, dikgato, le mangole...”

SourceText: It is normal for men of the family to struggle to think of what to do with their babies, especially when it seems they just eat, sleep, cry, poop, and repeat. It can be especially challenging when your baby is very young and not able to talk to you.
text: Go tlwaelegile gore borre mo malapeng ba kgarakgatswe ke go akanya gore ba ka dirang le masea a bona, segolo ka go lebega o ka re ba batla fela go ja, go robala, go lela, go ithoma, mme ba boeletse. Ke kgwetlho e kgolo tota fa lesea la gago le le lennye mme le sa kgone go bua le wena.

SourceText: It is normal to struggle to think of what to do with our babies, especially when it seems they just eat, sleep, cry, poop, and repeat. It can be especially challenging when your baby is very young and not able to talk to you.
text: Go tlwaelegile go kgarakgadiwa ke go akanya gore ba ka dirang le masea a bona, segolo ka go lebega o ka re ba batla fela go ja, go robala, go lela, go ithoma, mme ba boeletse. Ke kgwetlho e kgolo tota fa lesea la gago le le lennye mme le sa kgone go bua le wena.

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" whenever you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your baby. Chat to you later @fields.user_name!

SourceText: Try to spend time playing with @fields.child_nickname every day for at least 20 minutes where you are giving them your full attention. Choose a time when you are unlikely to be interrupted. Switch off the television and put away phones.

SourceText: Babies learn through play! Help your child explore the world through the five senses. Let @fields.child_nickname use all of their senses when exploring the world. SourceText: It is okay for your child to want to do many different things. Your child’s attention may wander to many different things during One-on-One Time. Anything that is happening can grab their attention: the sound of a siren, the feeling of a breeze, feelings in the body. Just keep your attention on your child.
text: Go siame gore ngwana wa gago a batle go dira dilo tse dintsi tse di farologaneng. Tsepo ya ngwana wa gago e ka tlalatlalela go dilo tse dintsi tse di farologaneng ka nako ya nako ya motho ka mong. Sengwe le sengwe se se diragalang se ka phamola tsepo ya bona; modumo wa saerini, mowa o o monajana, maikutlo mo mmeleng. Wena tsepama go go ngwana wa gago.

SourceText: Here is a comic on spending one-on-one time with your child.
text: Fano ke khomiki ka ga go nnako le nako ya motho ka mong le ngwana wa gago!

SourceText: Child: “I’m bored! There is nothing to do.”
text: Ngwana: “Ke nyenegile! Ga go sepe se nka se dirang.”

SourceText: Parent: “Let’s do something together! How about we make some drawings and put them on the gate with messages for people to see?”
text: Motsadi: “Tla re dire sengwe mmogo! Go ka nna jang fa re ka thala ditshwantsho mme re di pege kwa hekeng ka meaetsa gore batho ba e buise?”

SourceText: Children: “Okay!”
text: Bana: “Go siame!”

SourceText: Parent: “You make the pictures and I’ll write the messages”
text: Motsadi: “O thala ditshwantsho fa nna ke kwala melaetsa”

SourceText: Child: “Sure!”
text: Ngwana: “Ke a leboga.

SourceText: Parent: "Remember to wash hands! We love our neighbours!”
text: Motsadi: “Gopola go tlhala diatla! Re rata baagisani ba rona!”

SourceText: Hi @fields.user_name! Have you tried sharing family responsibilities at home recently?
text: Dumela @fields.user_name! A o kile wa leka go arolelanela maikarabelo a lelapa kwa gae morago jaana?
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Hi! Have you tried sharing family responsibilities at home recently?
text: Dumela! A o kile wa leka go arolelanela maikarabelo a lelapa kwa gae morago jaana?

SourceText: This can be hard to remember! Establishing a routine around caregiving or housework tasks can sometimes be helpful. This also lets you talk to your partner or other adults about how to share the workload.
text: Seno se ka nna boima go gopolega! Go tlhama mekgwatlwaelo go ditiro tsa fa gae le go tlhokomelana go ka thusa tota nako dingwe. Gape seno se go letla go bua le molekane wa gago kgotsa bagolo ba bangwe ka ga go arolelanela mokgweleo.

SourceText: It is hard to remember to ask for help. Be kind to yourself if you forget to ask and try again another time. Asking for help and sharing family responsibilities benefits the whole family!
text: Go bokete go gopola go kopa thuso. Ineneketse fa o lebala go kopa kgotsa o leke nako e nngwe. Go kopa thuso le go arolelalnela maikarabelo go ungwela lelapa lotlhe!

SourceText: It can be difficult to know how to ask for help. Try starting off with suggesting a task you would like help with. Being specific gives your partner a clearer idea of what they can support you with.
text: Go ka nna boima go itse gore o kakopa jang thuso. Leka go simolola ka go tshitsinya tiro e o ka ratang go thusiwa ka yona. Go lolama go neela molekane wa gago kakanyo e e sedisegileng ya gore a ka go tshegetsa jang.

SourceText: Trying something new can be hard! To make it easier, ask your partner to do it together with you the first few times. Soon you’ll feel more confident doing it on your own!
text: Go leka sengwe se seswa go ka nna boima! Go e nolofatsa, kopa molekane wa gago go e dira mmogo le wena makgetlho a ntlha a ammalwa. Fa gautshwane o tla itshepa go itirela o le nosi!

SourceText: Talk to them! Talking with your partner about how you can share family responsibilities helps both of you understand each other better. It also shows that you care!
text: Bua le bona! go bua le molekane wa gago ka ga gore le ka arolelanela jang maikarabelo a lelapa go tla le thusa go tlhaloganyana botoka. Ga go bontsha gore o a kgathala!

SourceText: It can be difficult to find time during the day sometimes! Can you think of a time when your partner might be less busy, such as early in the morning or later in the evening? Creating a routine around housework can also be helpful.
text: Nako nngwe go ka nna bokete go nna le nako mo letsatsing! a o ka kgona go akanya nako mo letsatsing eo wena le molekane wa gago le ka se nneng le mekgapheo, jaaka mo mosong kgotsa moragonyana mo maitseboeng? Go tlhama mokgwatlwaelo go tiro ya fa gae go tla nna mosola tota.

SourceText: Sharing responsibilities in the home benefits everyone! While trying something new can feel hard at first, soon you will start to feel more comfortable. If it helps, ask your partner to join you in the beginning!
text: Go arolelanela maikarabelo fa gae go ungwela botlhe! Fa o leka sengwe se seswa o ka ikutlwa o palelwa lwa ntlha, o tla ikutlwa o simolola go namatshega fa o ntse o tsweletse. Fa go tla thusa, kopa molekane go dira le wena kwa tshimologong!

SourceText: Excellent job @fields.user_name! Sharing the workload benefits the whole family. How was your experience?
text: Tiro e ntle1! Go arolelanela mokgweleo go mosola go lelapa lotlhe. Maitemogelo a gago a nnile jang?
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Excellent job! Sharing the workload benefits the whole family. How was your experience?
text: Tiro e ntle! Go arolelanela mokgweleo go mosola go lelapa lotlhe. Maitemogelo a gago a nnile jang?

SourceText: We are sorry to hear this. What was difficult for you about sharing family responsibilities?
text: Ke maswabi go utlwa seno. Ke eng se se nnileng popota go wena ka ga go arolelanela maikarabelo a lelapa?

SourceText: I am sorry to hear this. What was difficult for you about sharing family responsibilities?
text: “Ke maswabi go utlwa se . Ke eng se se nnileng popota go wena ka ga go arolelanela maikarabelo a lelapa?

SourceText: Hi! Thank you for signing up to receive ParentText tips. Please tell us which language you would like:
text: Dumela! Re leboga fa o ikwadisitse go amogela dikakantsho tsa ParentText. Ka kopo re bolelele gore o ka rata puo efe:

SourceText: Hi! Thank you for signing up to receive ParentText tips. Please tell me which language you would like:
text: Dumela! Re leboga fa o ikwadisitse go amogela dikakantsho tsa ParentText. Ka kopo mpolelele gore o ka rata puo efe:

SourceText: How did you find out about ParentText?
text: O itsitse jang ka ga ParentText?

SourceText: Stand up and stretch your arms up to the sky. Push away any clouds and let the Sunshine of Positive Attention shine down on you. Stretch to both sides. Stretch to the front and to the back.
text: Ema mme o otlololele diatla tsa gago ko godimo. Itire o ka re o sutisa maru a o a bonang mme o letle letsatsi le go phatsimele. Ikotlololele ko matlhakoreng o o mabedi. Ikotlololele ko pele le ko morago.

SourceText: Place one foot in front of the other and make small circles from your ankles. Remember to turn your foot to both sides - to the left and then to the right. Do each foot with four circles in each direction.
text: Baya leoto mo pele ga le lengwe mme o dire dikgolokwe tse dinnye ka legwejana, gopola go dira mo matlhakoreng o o mabedi. Gopola go retolola kgato ya gago go matlhakore ka bobedi - go ya molemeng le go ya mojeng. Dira leoto lengwe le lengwe ka dikgolokwe tse nne mo matlhakoreng otlhe.

SourceText: Let your hand hang by your side. As you breathe in, squeeze your shoulders up to your ears, scrunch your eyes, and hold your breath. Release your shoulders as you breathe out and relax your body.
text: Letla letsogo la gago le akgegele mo letlhakoreng la gago. Gatelela magetla a gago gaufi le ditsebe tsa gago fa o ntse o hemela ko teng, dira e kete o tswala matlho a gago, mme o tshware mowa wa gago. Tlogela magetla a gago fa o ntse o hemela kwa ntle mme o repise mmele wa gago.

SourceText: Close your eyes and raise your arms slowly above your head as you breathe in. Lower your arms slowly to your side as you breathe out. Repeat 4 times.
text: Tswala matlho mme o emise matsogo a gago ka bonya mo godimo ga tlhogo ya gago fa o ntse o hemela ko teng. Isa matsogo a gago ka bonya ko letlhakoreng la gago fa o ntse o hemela kwa ntle. Boeletsa makgetlho a le 4.

SourceText: Relax your arms and let them swing to the front and back. Take 4 deep breaths while you do this. This is good for your lower back.
text: Repisa matsogo a gago mme o a letle go ya pele le morago. Hemela kwa teng ga 4 fa o ntse o dira se. Go siametse letheka la gago.

SourceText: Relax your arms and let your arms swing sideways as you turn your upper body. Your arms should gently hit your back as you twist from side to side.
text: Repisa matsogo a gago mme letlelela matsogo a gago go elela ko pele le ko morago, mme o tshedimosetse mmele wa gago o o ko godimo. Matsogo a gago a iteye mokotla wa gago ka bonolo fa o ntse o sokamisetsa ko matlhakoreng.

SourceText: Take a moment to reflect on your experience. Remember that you can do this activity at any time whenever you feel like you need to release stress and energise your mind and body.
text: Tsaya motsotso go akanya ka maitemogelo a gago. Gopola go dira tirwana eno nako nngwe le nngwe fa o ikutlwa o tlhoka go ntsha go tshwenyega mo maikutlong mme o neye tlhaloganyo ya gago le mmele wa gago maatla.

SourceText: How helpful was this tip?
text: Kakantsho eno e nnile mosola jang?

SourceText: How helpful was this activity?
text: Tirwana eno e nnile mosola jang?

SourceText: Have these relaxation activities helped reduce the stress in your life?
text: Ditirwana tseno tsa go repa di thusitse jang go fokotsa kgatelelo mo botshelong jwa gago?

SourceText: Was this advice helpful?
text: A kgakololo eno e nnile mosola?

SourceText: Thank you for the feedback!
text: Re lebogela dipholo!

SourceText: Hi @fields.user_name! Have you tried resolving conflict in a calm way even when you have felt frustrated recently?
text: Dumela @fields.user_name! A o kile wa leka go rarabolola kgotlhang ka mokgwa o o ritibetseng le fa o ne o ikutlwa o tlalalane morago jaana?
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Hi! Have you tried resolving conflict in a calm way even when you have felt frustrated recently?
text: Dumela! A o kile wa leka go rarabolola kgotlhang ka mokgwa o o ritibetseng le fa o ne o ikutlwa o tlalalane morago jaana?

SourceText: Sorry to hear this. What was difficult for you about resolving conflicts between you and your partner?
text: Ke maswabi go utlwa seno. O fitlhetse e leng e e bokete ka ga go rarabolola dikgotlhang magareng ga gago le molekane wa gago?

SourceText: It can be really hard to stay calm when we’re having a disagreement with others. Try to think of something that you can do that might help like taking a couple deep breaths.
text: O ka nna boima go tsweletsa o ritibetse fa o na le dikgogakgogano le ba bangwe. Leka go akanya ka sengwe se o ka se dirang se se ka go thusang jaaka go hemela kwa teng makgetlho.

SourceText: It can be easy to forget, but don’t give up! Next time when you start feeling angry, try taking a deep breath before responding. You can also try walking away for a bit if you start feeling frustrated.
text: Go bonolo go lebalega, fela se fele pelo! Mo nakong e e tlang fa o ikutlwa o galefa, leka go hemela kwa teng pele o araba. Gape o ka leka go ktoga nakwana fa o simolola go ikutlwa o tlalalana.

SourceText: By taking a pause before responding, it can help us stay calm and respond better. When you feel yourself getting angry, try taking a pause. You can do this!
text: Ka go ema go se kae pele o raba, o ka re thusa go tswelela go ritibala le go araba botoka. Nako e e tlang fa o ikutlwa o galefa, leka go ema go se kae. O ka dira seno!

SourceText: Sometimes others respond to us negatively when we’re having a disagreement. In these situations, it is sometimes best to walk away for a bit until those involved have calmed down.
text: Nako dingwe ba bangwe ba ka re araba bosula fa re sa dumalane. Mo maemong a, nako dingwe go siame go katoga nakwana go fitlha bao na amegang ba ritibetse.

SourceText: Good job @fields.user_name! Resolving conflicts isn’t always easy. How was your experience?
text: Tiro e ntle 1! Go rarabolola dikgotlhang ga go bonolo ka gale. Maitemogelo a gago a nnile jang?

SourceText: Good job! Resolving conflicts isn’t always easy. How was your experience?

SourceText: Having a loving relationship with our partner can have a big impact on how we feel. It also helps make our children feel loved and safe.
text: Go nna le botsalano jo bo lerato le molekane wa gago go ka nna le seabe se segolo mo maikutlong a rona. Gape go thusa go dira gore bana ba rona ba ikutlwe ba ratiwa le go sireletsega.

SourceText: Here are 5 simple tips on how you can develop a loving and peaceful relationship with your partner:
text: Fano ke dikakantsho tse di bonolo di le 5 gore o ka aga jang botsalano jo bo lerato e bile bo na le kagiso le molekane wa gago!

SourceText: 1. Treat each other as equals
text: 1. Tsholanang ka go lekalekana

SourceText: 2. Become a confident father and a supportive partner
text: 2. Nna ntate yo o itshepang le molekane yo o nang le tshegetso

SourceText: 3. Share family responsibilities
text: 3. Arolelanelanelang maikarabelo a lelapa

SourceText: 4. Resolve conflict peacefully
text: 4. Rarabololang kgotlhang ka kagiso

SourceText: 5. Listen and talk to each other
text: 5. Reetsanang le go buang mmogo

SourceText: Household chores aren’t fun… or are they? You can make them into a game, like this.

SourceText: There’s a fire on the mountain! Run, run, run!
text: Go nale molelo mo thabeng! Taboga, taboga, taboga!

SourceText: Touch something red.
text: “Tshwara sengwe se se khibidu.”

SourceText: Jump up and down ten times.
text: “Tlolela ko godimo le ko tlase ga lesome.”

SourceText: Put the shoes in the shoe rack.
text: “Baya ditlhako mo di nnang teng.”

SourceText: Did you manage to establish ONE rule or daily routine together with @fields.child_nickname?
text: A o kgonne go tlhama molao o le MONGWE kgotsa mokgwatswaelo wa letsatsi le letsatsi mmogo le 1?
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Did you manage to establish ONE rule or daily routine together with your child or teen ?
text: A o kgonne go tlhama molao o le MONGWE kgotsa mokgwatswaelo wa letsatsi le letsatsi mmogo le ngwana kgotsa mosha wa gago?

SourceText: Great to hear it this! Remember, the more we involve our children in setting rules, the more our children will be likely to follow them!
text: Ke leboga go utlwa gore dilo di tsamaile sentle! Gopola, fa re tsenyeletsa bana ba rona mo go tlhameng melao, bana ba rona ba tla di latela!

SourceText: Did you have any challenges when trying to establish a rule or routine together?
text: A o nnile le dikgwetlho dipe fa o leka go dira molao lo le mmogo?

SourceText: It is always important when establishing rules and routines  as a family to consider the age of each child, so you can come up with age-appropriate routines. This is most important for bedtime, time to come home/play, household chores.
text: Ka gale go botlhokwa gore fa o tlhama melao le mekgwatlwaelo le le lelapa le tsee tsia dingwaga tsa ngwana mongwe le mongwe, gore o kgone go tla ka mekgwatlwaelo e e maleba. Seno se botlhokwa go nako ya go robala, nako go boela gae/go tshameka.

SourceText: We should always remember that children learn best from us. The more we follow the rules, they more they will follow the rules too. You can adjust the rule to make sure that it is realistic for everyone to follow it, considering their responsibilities (for example school or work activities).
text: Re tshwanetse go gopola ka metlha gore bana ba ithuta thata go tswa mo go rona. Fa re latela melao thata, le bone ba tla o latela. O ka nna wa tokafatsa melao go netefatsa gore a kgonega gore botlhe ba e latele, o akanyetsa maikarabelo a gago le maikarabelo a mosha wa gago (ka sekai, sekolo kgotsa dilo tsa tiro).

SourceText: When we establish rules together with our children or teens, that helps the family to understand each other better. The rules will be more realistic and our children will be more willing and able to follow the rule.
text: Fa re tlhoma melao mmogo le bana le basha ba rona, seno se thusa lelapa go tlhaloganyana botoka. Melao e tla kgona go diragadiwa, le bana ba rona ba tla batla le go kgona go e latela melao eo.

SourceText: When we establish rules together with our children, that helps the family to understand each other better. The rules will be more realistic and our children will be more willing and able to follow the rule.
text: Fa re tlhoma melao mmogo le bana ba rona, seno se thusa lelapa go tlhaloganyana botoka. Melao e tla kgona go diragadiwa, le bana ba rona ba tla batla le go kgona go e latela melao eo.

SourceText: Sorry you did not manage to do this yet. Sit down with @fields.child_nickname and try again today - involving your children will make them want to follow the rule more often!
text: Maswabi ka ga o ise o kgone go dira se. Nna fa fatshe le 1 mme o leke gape gompieno - go tsenyeletsa bana ba gago go tla dira gore ba batle go latela molao le go feta!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Sorry you did not manage to do this yet. Sit down with your child or teen  and try again today - involving your children will make them want to follow the rule more often!
text: Maswabi ka ga o ise o kgone go dira se. Nna fa fatshe le 1 mme o leke gape gompieno - go tsenyeletsa bana ba gago go tla dira gore ba batle go latela molao le go feta!

text: Ke eng se se neng lse le bokete ka ga go tlhama molao kgotsa mokgwatlwaelo ka 1?
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: What was difficult for you about establishing a rule or routine with your child or teen ?
text: Ke eng se se neng lse le bokete ka ga go tlhama molao kgotsa mokgwatlwaelole ngwana kgotsa mosha wa gago?

SourceText: Amazing! Consistent rules and routines help make @fields.child_nickname feel secure. They also keep them safe!
text: Bontle! Melaole mekgwatlwaelo ka tlhomamo e thusa gore dira gore 1 ikutlwe a sireletsegile. Gape e ba tshola ba sireletsegile!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Amazing! Consistent rules and routines help make your child or teen  feel secure. They also keep them safe!
text: Bontle! Melaole mekgwatlwaelo ka tlhomamo e thusa gore dira gore ngwana le mosha wa gago ba ikutlwe a sireletsegile. Gape e ba tshola ba sireletsegile!

SourceText: The sound of a baby crying can be very distressing, especially for a father It is completely natural to want to make it stop. You might also think that you are not a good parent or that your baby is crying to spite you. But all babies cry. It is one of the main ways a baby can tell you that something is wrong.
text: Modumo wa selelo sa lesea o ka go tsenya tsebetsebe, segolo go ntate Ke tlholego gore o batle go le didimatsa. Gape o ka akanya gore ga o motsadi yo o siameng kgotsa gore ngwana wa gago o lela go go ntshetsa. Fela masea otlhe a a lela. Ke nngwe ya mekgwa megolo e lesea le ka go bolelelang fa gona le sengwe se se fosagetseng.

SourceText: The sound of a baby crying can be very distressing, especially for a mother. It is completely natural to want to make it stop. You might also think that you are not a good parent or that your baby is crying to spite you. But all babies cry. It is one of the main ways a baby can tell you that something is wrong.
text: Modumo wa selelo sa lesea o ka go tsenya tsebetsebe, segolo go mme. ke tlholego go rata go ka le didimatsa. Gape o ka akanya gore ga o motsadi yo o siameng kgotsa gore ngwana wa gago o lela go go ntshetsa. Fela masea otlhe a a lela. Ke nngwe ya mekgwa megolo e lesea le ka go bolelelang fa gona le sengwe se se fosagetseng.

SourceText: The sound of a baby crying can be very distressing, especially for a parent. It is completely natural to want to make it stop. You might also think that you are not a good parent or that your baby is crying to spite you. But all babies cry. It is one of the main ways a baby can tell you that something is wrong.
text: Modumo wa selelo sa lesea o ka go tsenya tsebetsebe, segolo go mme. ke tlholego go rata go ka le didimatsa. Gape o ka akanya gore ga o motsadi yo o siameng kgotsa gore ngwana wa gago o lela go go ntshetsa. Fela masea otlhe a a lela. Ke nngwe ya mekgwa megolo e lesea le ka go bolelelang fa gona le sengwe se se fosagetseng.

SourceText: I know that you have already received this tip (well done!). Would you like to review it again?
text: Re a itse gore o setse o amogetse kakantsho eno (tiro e ntle!). A o ka rata go go leba diteng gape?

SourceText: 2 Truths, 1 Lie
text: Dinnete 2, Maaka 1

SourceText: Think of three statements about yourself. Two must be true and one must be a lie.
text: Akanya ka dipolelwana tse tharo ka wena. Tse pedi di tshwanetse go nna tsa nnete mme e nngwe e nne ya maaka.

SourceText: It might help to think of wishes, dreams, likes or dislikes. For example, I hate bananas, I love ice cream and I really wish I could sing.
text: Go ka nna ga thusa go akanya ka dikeletso, ditoro, tse di rategang kgotsa tse di sa rategeng. Sekao, ga ke rate dipanana, ke rata bebetsididi mme ke tota ke eletsa gore nka opela.

SourceText: Say them to your partner or friends. Ask them to guess which one is a lie.
text: Bolelela molekane kgotsa ditsala.  Ba kope go fopholetsa gore ke efe e e leng maaka.

SourceText: Did they guess correctly? Was it a surprise?
text: A ba fopholeditse ka nepo? A o ne o maketse?

SourceText: Now ask them to do the same. Did you learn something new about each other?
text: Jaanong ba kope ba dire se se tshwanang. A lo ithutile sengwe se sesha ka yo mongwe?

SourceText: Crazy Chicken
text: Koko e e sa utlweng

SourceText: Shake your hand in the air 8 times while counting to 8
text: Tsholelletsang matsogo a lona mo moweng ga 8 fa lo ntse lo bala go fitlha go 8.

SourceText: Do it as fast and loud as you can
text: Dirang seno ka bonako le kwa godimo ka mo go kgonegang.

SourceText: Repeat with your other hand and both feet
text: Boeletsang seno ka letsogo le lengwe la gago le maoto ka bobedi.

SourceText: Do it 7 times, then 6 times until you get to 1.
text: Dirang seno makgetlo a le 7, morago ga moo a le 6 mme lo tswelele go fitlhelela lo fitlha ko go 1.

SourceText: Call out “Crazy chicken” as loud as you can!
text: Goeletsang “Kgogo e e sa utlweng” kwa godimo ka fa go kgonegang!

SourceText: Have you released all your stress? If not, do it again even faster and louder!
text: A o ntshitse matshwenyego otlhe a gago? Fa go se jal, boeletsa seno ka bonako mme o tsholetse lentswe go feta!

SourceText: Family Work Out
text: Se lelapa le ka se dirang

SourceText: Choose a sport or exercise to do together
text: Tlhopha motshameko kgotsa ikatiso e lo ka e dirang mmogo.

SourceText: Decide on a schedule. Are you going to do it every day? For how long?
text: Dirang tshwetso ka thulaganyo. A lo tlile go dira seno tsatsi le letsatsi? Ka lobaka lo lo kae?

SourceText: Try it out for a week.
text: E lekeng beke yotlhe.

SourceText: At the end of the week, ask yourself and your family these questions. How’s it going? How did you feel at the start of the week? How do you feel at the end of the week? What can we do differently next week?
text: Kwa mafelong a beke, wena le lelapa la gago ipotseng dipotso tse di latelang: Go tsamaya jang? Lo ikutlwa jang kwa tshimologong ya beke? Lo ikutlwa jang kwa mafelong a beke? Ke eng se re ka se dirang ka tsela e e farologaneng beke e e latelang?

SourceText: COVID-19 has interrupted our children's education with school closures and remote learning. It is normal to feel overwhelmed about to do this alone, especially when we also have stress about work and money.
text: COVID-19 e tshwenyane le thuto ya bana ba rona ka go tswalwa ga dikolo le go ithutela kwa gae. Go tlwaelegile go ikutlwa o tlalana fa o mekamekana le eno o le nosi, segolo ka rena le mathata a madi le tiro.

SourceText: Would you like to learn more about how to support your children with remote learning and returning to school?
text: A o ka rata go ithuta go feta ka ga tshegetso ya bana ba gago ba ba ithutang ka mafaratlhatlha le go boela sekolong?

SourceText: Stop & Listen
text: Ema &Reetsa

SourceText: • Stop for a moment and close your eyes.
text: Ema nakwana mme o tswale matlho a gago.

SourceText: • How many sounds can you hear? Listen to sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers. (Pause for 10 seconds)
text: O utlwa medumo e kae? Reetsa medumo e e mo teng le kwa ntle ga kamore. E bale ka menwana ya gago. (Ema metsotswana e le 10)

SourceText: • How many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear?
text: Go setse menwana e kae e e emeng? O utlwile medumo efe?

SourceText: • Let’s try again. Can you hear any new sounds this time? Can you hear any sounds inside your own body? (Pause for 10 seconds)
text: Tla re leke gape. A o utlwile medumo mengwe e mesha? kgetlhong le? A o kgona go utlwa medumo mo teng ga mmele wa gago? (Ema metsotswana e le 10)

SourceText: • Open your eyes. What new sounds did you hear?
text: Bula matlho a gago. O utlwile medumo efe e mesha?

SourceText: A Short Pause
text: Ema go se kae

SourceText: Sit down and close your eyes.
text: Nna fatshe o tswale matlho a gago.

SourceText: Listen to your breath as it goes in and out.
text: Reetsa tsela e o hemang ka yone o ntse o tsenya o ntsha mowa makgetlo a matlhano.

SourceText: Notice how you feel.
text: Lemoga kafa o ikutlwang ka gone.

SourceText: Take a few more deep breaths.
text: Hemela kwa teng makgetlho a a mmalwa.

SourceText: When you are ready open your eyes again. Do you feel any different?
text: Fa go siametse go dira jalo bula matlho a gago gape. A o utlwa pharologanyo?

SourceText: Remind yourself that “Everything is ok”.
text: Ikgopotse gore “Tsotlhe di siame”.

SourceText: Give Yourself A Hug
text: Itlamparele

SourceText: Bella mama, bella mama hey.
text: Bella mama, bella mama heela.

SourceText: Hey there! How are you feeling today? Do you feel great?!
text: Heela! O ikutlwa jang gompieno? O ikutlwa sentle?

SourceText: Maybe not. Maybe you shouted again at your children today? Maybe you got angry and said something you don't feel proud of? It’s ok. It’s super stressful right now.
text: Gongwe nnyaa. Gongwe o kgakgautile bana ba gago gompieno? Gongwe o ne wa galefa mme wa bua sengwe se o se motlotlo ka sona? Ga se bothata. Go thata tota gajaana.

SourceText: Take a deep breath and think of one thing you did today that you do feel proud of. It doesn't have to be big. And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug. And now think of one thing you did today that you don't feel proud of. What can you do differently tomorrow? And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug.
text: Hemela kwa teng mme o akanye selo se le sengwe se o se dirileng gompieno se o leng motlotlo ka sona. Ga di a tshwanela go nna dikgolo. Jaanong itlamparele ka matsogo a gago mme o iphe tlamparelo e kgolo! Mme jaanong mme o akanye selo se le sengwe se o se dirileng gompieno se o leng motlotlo ka sona. O ka dirang ka pharologanyo ka moso? Jaanong itlamparele ka matsogo a gago mme o iphe tlamparelo e kgolo!

SourceText: Bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama hey”.
text: Bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama heela”.

SourceText: Hello @fields.user_name! Did you know that 3 is a magical number? Breathe in to the count of three and breathe out to the count of three. How do you feel now? Do you feel any different?
text: Dumela. A o ne o itse gore 3 ke nomoro ya motlholo? Hemela kwa teng o bala ka tharo mme o hemele kwa ntle o bala ka tharo. Jaanong o ikutlwa jang? A o utlwa pharologanyo?
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated. @results.count is a number (counter for list)

SourceText: Hello! Did you know that 3 is a magical number? Breathe in to the count of three and breathe out to the count of three. How do you feel now? Do you feel any different?
text: Dumela! A o ne o itse gore 3 ke nomoro ya motlholo? Hemela kwa teng o bala ka tharo mme o hemele kwa ntle o bala ka tharo. Jaanong o ikutlwa jang? A o utlwa pharologanyo?

SourceText: What are your three favourite foods? Can you name three things you can see right now? Can you hear three sounds you can hear right now? What are three things you are grateful for right now?
text: Ke dijo dife tse tharo tse o di ratang? A o ka neela maina a dilo tse tharo tse o kgonang go di bona gajaana? A o ka bitsa maina a medumo e o e utlwang gone jaanong? Ke dilo dife tse tharo tse o di lebogelang gone jaanong?

SourceText: Breathe in to the count of three and breathe out to the count of three? How do you feel now? Do you feel any different? Three is a magical number!
text: Hemela kwa teng o bala ka tharo mme o hemele kwa ntle o bala ka tharo. Jaanong o ikutlwa jang? A o utlwa pharologanyo? Tharo ke nomoro ya motlholo!

SourceText: Release Some Energy
text: Golola Matla Mangwe

SourceText: Baba da bi da ba da baaa! Pause Power!
text: Baba da bi da ba da baaa! Maatla a go Emisa go se Kae!

SourceText: What’s Pause Power I hear you say? It’s the ability to transform from a grumpy, angry person into a calm, clear one.
text: Matla go Ema goo se kae ke eng? Ke bokgoni go fetoga go motho yo o galefileng go nna yo o ritibetseng, a tlhomame.

SourceText: When I’m feeling frustrated I plant my feet firmly on the ground and I breathe in and out three times as slowly as I can. Sometimes I imagine I’m smelling a flower and blowing out a candle.
text: Fa ke ikutlwa ke tlalalane ke tsepamisa dinao tsa me fa fatshe mme ke hemele kwa teng le kwa ntle garago ka iketlo e e kgonagalang. Nako dingwe ke nagana gore ke nkgelela lebolomo kgotsa ke tima kerese.

SourceText: Da ta! Pause Power! My transformation from grumpy to calm is complete!
text: Da ta! Maatla a go Emisa go se Kae! Phetogo ya me go tswa go ketsaetsego go ya thitibalong e digetswe!

SourceText: Taking care of yourself
text: Itlhokomele

SourceText: Recognise what is happening for you in this moment. What are you thinking? Are your thoughts positive or negative. How do you feel? Do you feel pleasant or unpleasant? How does your body feel? Do you feel tense or relaxed?
text: Lemoga se se go diragalelang gone jaanong. Ke eng se o se akanyang? A dikakanyo tsa gago di siame kgotsa ga di a siama. O ikutlwa jang? O ikutlwa sentle kgotsa ga o ikutlwe sentle? Mmele wa gago o ikutlwa jang? O ikutlwa o gateletswe kgotsa o repile?

SourceText: Connect to your heart in a kind and gentle way. You may want to place one hand on your heart or chest.
text: Golagana le pelo ya gago ka tsela e e siameng le e e bonolo. O ka nna wa batla go baya letsogo la gago mo pelong ya gago kgotsa mo sefubeng sa gago.

SourceText: You can then say the following words silently to yourself:
text: O ka ipolelela mafoko a a latelang ka tidimalo:

SourceText: Take a moment to reflect on your experience. Remember that you can do this activity at any time whenever you feel like you need extra support.
text: Tsaya motsotso go akanya ka maitemogelo a gago. Gopola go dira tirwana eno nako nngwe le nngwe fa o ikutlwa o ka re o tlhoka tshegetso e ntsi.

SourceText: Cooking together
text: Go apaya mmogo

SourceText: Children love to do what you do!
text: Bana ba rata go dira se o se dirang!

SourceText: Let your baby play with pots and spoons while you are making dinner.
text: Letla lesea la gago go tshameka ka dipitsa le maswana fa o tsweletse go dira dijo.

SourceText: Dance Party
text: Moletlo wa Tanse

SourceText: Put on your favourite music or sing your favourite song and dance around the room with your toddler. If you have a baby hold them while you dance.
text: Tshameka mmino kgotsa pina ya mmamoratwa mme wena le mapimpana wa gago le tanse go ralala phaposi. Fa o na le lesea le tsholetse fa o ntse o tansa.

SourceText: Dance in different ways or with different parts of your body.
text: Tansa ka mekgwa e e farologaneng kgotsa ka dikarolo tse di farologaneng tsa mmele wa gago.

SourceText: For example, “Dance like a monkey”, “Dance like a chicken” or “Let’s dance with our knees and hips.”
text: Sekao, “Tansa jaaka kgabo”. “Tansa jaaka kgogo” kgotsa “Tla re tanse ka mangole le matheka a rona.”

SourceText: Think up different instructions. Be seriously playful!
text: Akanya ka ditaelo tse di farologaneng. Tshameka ka tshisibalo!

SourceText: When the music stops, everyone does a funny freeze.
text: Fa mmino o didimala, mongwe le mongwe a eme ka mokgwa o o tshegisang.

SourceText: Notice what rhythms or movements they like!
text: Elatlhoko morethetho kgotsa metsamao eo ba e ratang!

SourceText: Down in a ditch!
text: Kwa mosimeng!

SourceText: Sit on a chair and put your toddler on your lap facing you. Hold them firmly under the arms.
text: Nna mo setilong mme o kuke mapimpana o mo lebisitse kwa go wena. Mo tshware sentle mo tlase ga magwafa.

SourceText: Gently bounce your legs and say in a soft voice “Baby horse, baby horse, baby horse, baby horse”
text: Tlolatlodisa maoto a gago mme o bua ka lentswe le le bonolo “Pitse, pitse, pitse, pitse”

SourceText: Bounce your legs a bit more and say a bit louder “Little horse, little horse, little horse, little horse”
text: Tlolatlodisa maoto a gago go feta mme o tlhatlose lentswe “Pitse, pitse, pitse”

SourceText: Bounce your legs more and say louder “Big horse, big horse, big horse, big horse”
text: Tlolatlodisa maoto a gago go feta mme o oketse lentswe “Pitse, pitse, pitse, pitse”

SourceText: When you call out “Down in a ditch!” open your knees and let your child drop down between them. Make sure you hold them so they don’t fall far!
text: Fa o goeletsa “Kwa mosimeng!” bula maoto mme o tlegele ngwana go wela tlase fa gare ga ona. Netefatsa gore o mo tshwara gore a se wele kgakala!

SourceText: Funny Faces
text: Difatlhego ts e di Tshegisang

SourceText: Look at your baby in the eyes and make different funny faces.
text: Leba lesea la gago mo matlhong mme o dire difatlhego tse di tshegisang tse di farologaneng.

SourceText: Make a big face. Make a small face. Make a happy face. Make a surprised face.
text: Dira sefatlhego se segolo. Dira sefatlhego se sennye. Dira sefatlhego se se itumetseng. Dira sefatlhego se se gakgametseng>

SourceText: Which ones make your baby smile or laugh? Do them again, even bigger this time!
text: Ke sefe se se dirang gore lesea la gago le nyebe kgotsa le tshege? Di boeletse, di dire tse kgolo gajaana!

SourceText: Play with different feelings and add sounds.
text: Tshameka ka maikutlo a a farologaneng mme o tsenye le medumo.

SourceText: Copy their facial expressions too. Exaggerate them to make them funny.
text: Kopisa ditlhagiso tsa difatlhego tsa bona. Di feletse gore di tshegise.

SourceText: Always end on a positive expression!
text: Ka gale feleletsa ka tlhagiso e e siameng!

SourceText: Mirror Game
text: Motshameko wa Seipone

SourceText: • Get to your baby's level so they can see you and hear you.
text: Lekalekana le lesea la gago gore le kgone go go bona le go go utlwa.

SourceText: • Copy their facial expressions and sounds.
text: Kopisa ditlhagiso tsa difatlhego tsa bona le medumo.

SourceText: • It is simple and helps create a strong bond between you and your baby!
text: Go bonolo mme go thusa go tlhama kgolagano e e matlafetseng magareng ga gago le lesea la gago!

SourceText: Musical Toes
text: Menwana wa maoto ya Mmino

SourceText: Put your baby on their back.
text: Kanamisa lesela la gago.

SourceText: Wiggle their toe and say, “This little toe goes [funny sound].”
text: Sokasoka menwana ya maoto ya bona mme o re: “Monwananyana o o [dira modumo o o tshegisang].”

SourceText: Make a funny sound for each toe.
