text: Dira modumo o o tshegisang go monwana mongwe le mongwe wa maoto.

SourceText: Play with different sounds. For example, animal sounds, popping sounds, squeaky sounds, fart sounds.
text: Tshameka ka medumo e e farologaneng. Sekao, medumo ya diphologolo, modumo wa go ntsha mowa, modumo o o tsirinyang, modumo wa go ntsha mantle.

SourceText: Repeat this for all ten toes.
text: Boeletsa seno ka menwana yotlhe e e lesome ya maoto.

SourceText: Try to make the last toe the biggest and funniest sound!
text: Leka go dira modumo o mogolo o o tshegisang go feta ka monwana wa bofelo!

SourceText: Peek-a-Boo!
text: Peek-a-Boo!

SourceText: • Cover your face with your hands.
text: Thiba sefatlhego sa gago ka diatla tsa gago.

SourceText: • Quickly show your face and say "Peek-a-Boo!" or "Hello!" Babies love it!
text: Tlhagisa sefatlhego sa gago ka bonako mme o re “Peek-a-Boo!” kgotsa “Dumela!” Masea a a e rata!

SourceText: See It Be It
text: E bone Nna yone

SourceText: Look around you and name something that you can see. For example, a tree or a cup.
text: Leba mme o bitse leina la sengwe se o se bonang. Sekao, setlhare kgotsa kopi.

SourceText: Say to your child “I see a tree, let’s be it”.
text: E re go ngwana wa gago “Ke bona setlhare, tla se nne sona”.

SourceText: Countdown from 5 and make the shape of a tree with your bodies. Be as big and silly as possible.
text: Balela go tloga go 5 mme le dire popego ya setlhare ka mebele ya lona. Nnang bagolo mme le tshegise ka fao go kgonagalang ka gona.

SourceText: Now let your child have a turn. What can they see?
text: Jaanong refosana le ngwana wa gago. O bona eng?

SourceText: If you can, go outside and be in nature. If you can’t, play it inside.
text: fa o kgona, tswela kwa ntle mme o nne mo tlholegong. Fa o sa kgonege, go siame tshamekelang ka fa ntlong.

SourceText: When you’ve done it a few times, add moves and sounds!
text: Fa o setse o dirile se makgetlho a a mmalwa, tsenya metsamao le medumo!

SourceText: Shakers
text: dikgotlhokgotsi

SourceText: Find an empty, clean plastic bottle or pot with a lid that closes tight.
text: Batla lebotlolo le le senang sepe, le le phepa la polasetiki kgotsa pitsa ka sekhurumelo se se tswalegang sentle.

SourceText: Fill it with sand, stones, uncooked rice, beans or any small objects that make an interesting sound.
text: E tlatse ka santa, maje, raese e e sa butswang, dinawa kgotsa dilwana tse di nnye go dira modumo o o itumedisang.

SourceText: Move your body as you shake it in front of your baby.
text: Binisa mmele wa gago fa o tsweletse go e kgotlhokgotsa fa pele ga lesea la gago.

SourceText: If it is safe, give it to your baby to shake!
text: Fa go bolokesegile, o ka e neela ngwana wa gago gore a kgotlokgotse!

SourceText: Get creative! Can you find something colourful or try it with water?
text: Nna le boitlhamedi! A o ka bona sengwe sa mebalabala kgotsa wa leka ka metsi?

SourceText: What sounds does your baby like?
text: Lesea la gago le rata medumo efe?

SourceText: The Sun is Coming!
text: Letsatsi le a tlhaba!

SourceText: Lie your baby on their back after washing them or changing their diaper.
text: Kanamisa lesea la gago fa o sena go le tlhapisa kgotsa go ntsha mongwato.

SourceText: Tell them the sun is coming! Wiggle your fingers like sun rays above their head and make your face a big smiling sun.
text: Le bolelele gore letsatsi le a tlhaba! Tsamaisa menwana ya gago marang a letsatsi fa godimo ga tlhogo ya gagwe mme o dire sefatlhego sa gago letsatsi le le golo le le nyebang.

SourceText: Tell them the wind is coming! Blow softly over their body.
text: Le bolelele gore lphefo e a foka! Futswela mowa mo mmeleng wa gagwe.

SourceText: Tell them the rain is coming! Use your fingers to gently pat over their whole body like light raindrops.
text: Ba bolelele gore pula e a na!Le bolelele gore letsatsi le a tlhaba! dirisa menwana wa gago o gatagate mmele otlhe jaaka marothodi a pula.

SourceText: Tell them the clouds are coming! Wrap the towel or cloth around them like a blanket and cuddle them.
text: Ba bolelele gore go thibile. Mo phuthele ka kobo, toulo kgotsa lesela mme o mo tlamparele.

SourceText: Play with different weathers. Which one does your baby like best?
text: Tshameka ka maemo a bosa a a farologaneng. Lesea la gago le rata afe go feta?

SourceText: Add sound effects or make it into a little song. Use the tune of another song you know!
text: Tsenya dikgabiso go medumo kgotsa o o fetole go nna pinanyana. Dirisa motswako wa pina nngwe e o e itseng!

SourceText: At the End of the Day
text: Kwa bokhutlong jwa letsatsi

SourceText: At the end of each day, take a minute to think about the day.
text: Kwa bokhutlong jwa letsatsi lengwe le lengwe, tsaya motsotso o akanye ka letsatsi.

SourceText: Talk to your child about one positive or fun thing they did.
text: Bua le ngwana wa gago ka ga selo se le sengwese se siameng kgotsa se itumedisang se ba se dirileng.

SourceText: Praise yourself for one thing you did well today.
text: Ikakgole fa o dirile sengwe se le nosi se sentle gompieno.

SourceText: Think of one thing that you are grateful for.
text: Bitsa selo se le sengwe se o se lebogelang.

SourceText: You are a star!
text: O naledi!

SourceText: Lullaby
text: Pina ya tutuletso

SourceText: When your baby or toddler cries, sing a soft song to calm you both down.
text: Fa lesea kgotsa mapimpana a lela, mo oplele pina e e tla le ritibatsang mmogo.

SourceText: Sing a soothing song you know or make up your own with a simple melody and some soothing words.
text: Opela pina e e namatshang e o e itseng kgotsa o itlhamele ya gago ka molodi o o bonolo le mantswe a a namatshang.

SourceText: Repeat it over and over in a rhythmical way. For example, “My little one, oh little one”.
text: E boeletse makgetlho ka mokgwa o o nang le morethetho. Sekao, “Leseanyana la me, ijoo leseanyana la me”.

SourceText: Sing the same song regularly so your child gets used to it!
text: Opela pina e le nngwe ka gale gore ngwana wa gago a e tlwaele!

SourceText: Shake your left hands in the air 8 times while counting to 8
text: * Tshikinyang matsogo a lona a molema mo moweng ga 8 fa lo ntse lo bala go fitlha go 8.

SourceText: Repeat with your other hand. Repeat with each foot.
text: * Boeletsang seno ka matsogo a lona a mangwe. Boeletsa ka leoto lengwe le lengwe.

SourceText: Do it 7 times, then 6 times and continue until you get to 1.
text: * Dirang seno makgetlo a le 7, morago ga moo a le 6 mme lo tswelele go fitlhelela lo fitlha ko go 1.

SourceText: Everyone calls out “Crazy chicken” and does their best crazy chicken dance!
text: * Mongwe le mongwe o goeletsa a re “Koko e e sa utlweng” ba bo ba diragatsa go bina ga bone go go gaisang ga koko e e sa utlweng!

SourceText: Dance choreography
text: Tansa ka khareokerafi

SourceText: Create a dance choreography to your children’s favorite songs.
text: Tlhama khareokerafi ya tanse ya dipina tse bana ba gago ba di ratang.

SourceText: First person does a dance move and everyone else copies.
text: * Motho a le nosi o a bina mme ba bangwe botlhe ba a mo etsa.

SourceText: Everyone takes turns being the leader.
text: * Refosanang ka go etelela pele.

SourceText: Perform it for the household!
text: * Diragatsang seno fa pele ga balelapa!

SourceText: Play or sing your favourite music and dance around the room.
text: Letsa mmino kgotsa o opele pina ya mmamoratwa mme o tanse go ralala phaposi.

SourceText: For example, “Dance like a monkey”, “Dance like a chicken” or “Dance with just our knees and hips”.
text: Sekao, “Tansa jaaka kgabo”. “Tansa jaaka kgogo” kgotsa “Tla re tanse ka mangole le matheka a rona.”

SourceText: When the music stops, everyone does a funny freeze.
text: Fa mmino o didimala, mongwe le mongwe a eme ka mokgwa o o tshegisang.

SourceText: Give your child a chance to be the one to stop the music!
text: Neela ngwana wa gago shono go nna ene a timang mmino!

SourceText: Freeze dance
text: Tanso Tsemeledi

SourceText: Play music or someone sings a song, and everyone dances.
text: Letsa mmino kgotsa mongwe a opele pina, mme botlhe ba tanse.

SourceText: When the music stops, everyone must freeze.
text: Fa mmino o didimala, mongwe le mongwe a eme tsemeledi.

SourceText: Last person still dancing becomes the judge for the next round.
text: Motho yo o saletseng kwa morago a tansa e nna moatlhodi wa kgaolo e e latelang.

SourceText: A variation to Freeze Dance is Animal Dance: It’s the same as Freeze Dance but when the music stops, one member of the family calls out the name of an animal, and everyone has to become that animal.
text: Tanso tsemeledi ke kemedi ya Tanse sekaphologolo: E tshwana fela le Tanso Tsemeledi fela fa mmino o tima, leloko le lengwe la lelapa le bitsa leina la phologolo mme botlhe ba tshwanela go nna phologolo eo.

SourceText: Mirror
text: Seipone

SourceText: This game can be played in pairs or even as a group.
text: * Motshameko ono o ka tshamekiwa ka dipara kgotsa jaaka setlhopha.

SourceText: Stand facing each other or in a circle.
text: * Emang lo lebane kgotsa mo kgolokweng.

SourceText: One person leads first while everyone else must copy, trying to move exactly at the same time as the leader.
text: * Motho a le nosi o etelela pele mme ba bangwe botlhe ba a mo etsa, ba leka go suta ka nako e le nngwe kgo le moeteledipele.

SourceText: Make sure the leader moves slowly enough for everyone to follow! Explore moving different body parts and in different levels.
text: * Netefatsa gore moeteledipele o suta ka iketlo ka mo go lekaneng gore mongwe le mongwe a mo latele! Bina ka tsela ya gore go sute mmele otlhe ka selekanyo se se farologaneng.

SourceText: After a while, switch who is leading. Give everyone a chance to lead.
text: * Morago ga sebaka, yo mongwe e nne ene a etelelang pele. Naya mongwe le mongwe tshono ya go etelela pele.

SourceText: Try it with no leaders!
text: * Leka seno go sena baeteledipele!

SourceText: Here's a video to help you support your child's learning.
text: Fano ke bidiyo gogo thusa go tshegetsa go ithuta ga ngwana wa gago.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you support your child's learning.
text: Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo go go thusa go tshegetsa go ithuta ga ngwana wa gago.

SourceText: Here are 5 steps that you can do to help your children continue learning during this time:
text: Fano ke dikgato di le 5 tse o ka di tsayang go thusa ngwana wa gago go tswelela go ithuta mo pakeng e:

SourceText: 1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork
text: 1. Tlhama mokgwatlwaelo go dikologa go ithuta le tiro ya sekolo

SourceText: 2. Make learning fun and playful
text: 2. Dira go ithuta monate mme go tshamekiwe

SourceText: 3. Remember that you are a parent NOT a substitute teacher
text: 3. Gopola gore o motsadi E SENG morutaban thefosi

SourceText: 4. Stay connected with your child's school and teachers
text: 4. Tswelela ka kgolaganyo le sekolo le barutanabana ba ngwana wa gago

SourceText: 5. Support your child when they return to school
text: 5. Neela ngwana wa gago tshegetso fa a tswa sekolong

SourceText: Type "1" to "5" to learn more about each tip. Type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Go ithuta go le gontsi ka nngwe le nngwe ya dikakantsho tse, tlanya “1” go ya go “5”. Tlanya “N” go emisa kakantsho e.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to support your child's learning:
text: Ka kopo tlhopha nomoro e nngwe fa o batla go ithuta go feta ka ga go ipha nako ya motho ka mong le ngwana wa gago:

SourceText: Step 5. Support your child when they go back to school
text: Kgato 5. Neela ngwana wa gago tshegetso fa a tswa sekolong

SourceText: Tell @fields.child_nickname that it is okay to feel scared or worried about going back to school. Allow your child to share how they are feeling. It is also normal if your child behaves differently to their usual behaviour. Discuss how going to school might be different and how they can protect themselves from COVID-19. Ask them how their day went and support them if they experienced any difficulties.
text: Botsa 1 gore a go siame go ikutlwa o tshogile kgotsa o tshwenyegile ka ga go boela sekolong. Letla ngwana wa gago go arolelanela gore o ikutlwa jang. Gape go tlwaelegile fa ngwana wa gago a itshola ka pharologanyo gona le ka maitsholo a gago a ka gale. Tlotlang ka ga gore go ya sekolong go tla farologana jang le gore ba kgona go itshireletsa jang go COVID-19. Ba botse gore ba tlhotse jang mme o ba neele tshegetso fa ba itemogela mathata mangwe.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Tell your child that it is okay to feel scared or worried about going back to school. Allow your child to share how they are feeling. It is also normal if your child behaves differently to their usual behaviour. Discuss how going to school might be different and how they can protect themselves from COVID-19. Ask them how their day went and support them if they experienced any difficulties.
text: Botsa 1 gore a go siame go ikutlwa o tshogile kgotsa o tshwenyegile ka ga go boela sekolong. Letla ngwana wa gago go arolelanela gore o ikutlwa jang. Gape go tlwaelegile fa ngwana wa gago a itshola ka pharologanyo gona le ka maitsholo a gago a ka gale. Tlotlang ka ga gore go ya sekolong go tla farologana jang le gore ba kgona go itshireletsa jang go COVID-19. Ba botse gore ba tlhotse jang mme o ba neele tshegetso fa ba itemogela mathata mangwe.

SourceText: Step 2. Make learning fun and playful
text: Kgato 2. Dira go ithuta monate mme go tshamekiwe

SourceText: Children learn best when learning is fun! Try to find ways to make learning playful to keep @fields.child_nickname interested and engaged. Type "Help" if you ever need any fun ideas!
text: Bana ba ithuta botoka fa go ithuta go le monate! Leka go bona ditsela go dira go ithuta monate le go tshola 1 a na le kgatlhego mme a tsaya karolo. Tlanya “Thuso” fa o tlhoka dikakanyo tsa go itumedisa!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Children learn best when learning is fun! Try to find ways to make learning playful to keep your child interested and engaged. Type "Help" if you ever need any fun ideas!
text: Bana ba ithuta botoka fa go ithuta go le monate! Leka go bona ditsela go dira go ithuta monate le go tshola 1 a na le kgatlhego mme a tsaya karolo. Tlanya “Thuso” fa o tlhoka dikakanyo tsa go itumedisa!

SourceText: Step 3. Remember that you are a father NOT a substitute teacher!
text: Kgato 3. Gopola gore o motsadi E SENG morutaban thefosi

SourceText: Your role is to support your child by creating a space to learn. You do not need to know all the answers. Help them explore their interests and ask questions. Go at @fields.child_nickname's pace and be patient with yourself.
text: Seabe sa gago ke go neela ngwana wa gago tshegetso ka go tlhama sebaka go ithuta. Ga o tlhoke go itse dikarabo tsotlhe. Ba thuse go uolola dikgatlhegelo tsa bona le go botsa dipotso. Tsamaya ka 1 bonya mme o nne pelotelele.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Step 3. Remember that you are a mother NOT a substitute teacher!
text: Kgato 3. Gopola gore o motsadi E SENG morutabana thefosi

SourceText: Step 3. Remember that you are a parent NOT a substitute teacher!
text: Kgato 3. Gopola gore o motsadi E SENG morutaban thefosi

SourceText: Your role is to support your child by creating a space to learn. You do not need to know all the answers. Help them explore their interests and ask questions. Go at your child's pace and be patient with yourself.
text: Seabe sa gago ke go neela ngwana wa gago tshegetso ka go tlhama sebaka go ithuta. Ga o tlhoke go itse dikarabo tsotlhe. Ba thuse go uolola dikgatlhegelo tsa bona le go botsa dipotso. Tsamaya ka 1 bonya mme o nne pelotelele.

SourceText: Step 1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork
text: Kgato 1. Tlhama mokgwatlwaelo go dikologa go ithuta le tiro ya sekolo

SourceText: Make a daily plan with @fields.child_nickname for when they can spend time doing educational activities. This can include structured schoolwork and other activities online, reading, writing, or arts. Allow flexibility and time for play and relaxation too.
text: Dira thulaganyo ya letsatsi le letsatsi le 1 gore a kgone go ipha nako a dira ditirwana tsa thuto. Seno se ka tsenyeletsa tiro ya sekolo e e rulagantsweng le ditirwana tse dingwe mo inthaneteng, go buisa, go kwala, kgotsa botaki. Letlelela phetophetogo le nako ya go tshameka le go iketla.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Make a daily plan with your child for when they can spend time doing educational activities. This can include structured schoolwork and other activities online, reading, writing, or arts. Allow flexibility and time for play and relaxation too.
text: Dira thulaganyo ya letsatsi le letsatsi le 1 gore a kgone go ipha nako a dira ditirwana tsa thuto. Seno se ka tsenyeletsa tiro ya sekolo e e rulagantsweng le ditirwana tse dingwe mo inthaneteng, go buisa, go kwala, kgotsa botaki. Letlelela phetophetogo le nako ya go tshameka le go iketla.

SourceText: Step 4. Stay connected with your child's school and teachers
text: Kgato 4. Tswelela ka kgolaganyo le sekolo le barutanabana ba ngwana wa gago

SourceText: Find out how to stay in touch with @fields.child_nickname’s teacher or school to stay informed, ask questions and get more guidance. If you are struggling or know someone who is struggling with school work or the home situation, please discuss this with a teacher that you feel close to. Parent groups or community groups can also be a good way to support each other with your home schooling.
text: Batla gore o ka tswelela jang go golagana le morutabana kgotsa sekolo sa 1 go nna o itsie, go botsa dipotso le go bona kaelo go feta. Fa o itemogela mathata kgotsa o itse mongwe yo o itemogelang mathata ka maemo a tiro ya sekolo kgotsa kwa gae, ka kopo tlotla ka ga se le morutabana yo o gaufi le ene. Ditlhopha tsa batsadi kgotsa ditlhopha tsa baagi di ka nna tsela e ntle go tshegetsana go thuto fa gae.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Find out how to stay in touch with your children’s teacher or school to stay informed, ask questions and get more guidance. If you are struggling or know someone who is struggling with school work or the home situation, please discuss this with a teacher that you feel close to. Parent groups or community groups can also be a good way to support each other with your home schooling.
text: Batla gore o ka tswelela jang go golagana le morutabana kgotsa sekolo sa 1 go nna o itsie, go botsa dipotso le go bona kaelo go feta. Fa o itemogela mathata kgotsa o itse mongwe yo o itemogelang mathata ka maemo a tiro ya sekolo kgotsa kwa gae, ka kopo tlotla ka ga se le morutabana yo o gaufi le ene. Ditlhopha tsa batsadi kgotsa ditlhopha tsa baagi di ka nna tsela e ntle go tshegetsana go thuto fa gae.

SourceText: Well done for adding another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Over the next few days, try creating a learning plan with your child that includes both fun and focused educational activities. Helping your child continue learning during this difficult time is so important. Your best efforts will make a difference!
text: O dirile bontle ka go tsenya kgono e le nngwe go Kaedi ya Botsadi beke eno! Mo malatsing a a mmalwa a a tlang, leka go tlhama thulaganyo ya go ithuta le ngwana wa gago e e akaretsang ditirwana tsa go itumedisa le go ithuta mmogo. Go thusa ngwana wa gago go tswelela go ithuta mo nakong e e masisi e go botlhokwa tota. Maiteko a gago a tla ungwa molemo!

SourceText: Well done for adding another layer to your House of Support! Over the next few days, try creating a learning plan with your child that includes both fun and focused educational activities. Helping your child continue learning during this difficult time is so important. Your best efforts will make a difference!
text: O dirile sentle ka go tsenya moalo o le mongwe go Ntlo ya gago ya Tshegetso! Mo malatsing a a mmalwa a a tlang, leka go tlhama thulaganyo ya go ithuta le ngwana wa gago e e akaretsang ditirwana tsa go itumedisa le go ithuta mmogo. Go thusa ngwana wa gago go tswelela go ithuta mo nakong e e masisi e go botlhokwa tota. Maiteko a gago a tla ungwa molemo!

SourceText: We understand that these times can be really difficult. Please type "Help" if you want any extra support or guidance. Chat to you later @fields.user_name!
text: Re tlhaloganya gore nako eno e na le kgwetlho ota. Ka kopo tlanya “thusa” fa o batla tshegetso kgotsa kaelo e nngwe. ke tla bua le wena moragonyana 1!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: We understand that these times can be really difficult. Please type "Help" if you want any extra support or guidance. Chat to you later!
text: Re tlhaloganya gore nako eno e na le kgwetlho ota. Ka kopo tlanya “thusa” fa o batla tshegetso kgotsa kaelo e nngwe. Ke tla bua le wena moragonyana!

SourceText: Rain on the Mountain
text: Pula mo Thabeng

SourceText: Call out, “There’s rain on the mountain”.
text: Goeletsa, “Go na pula mo thabeng”.

SourceText: Everyone else replies “Run, run, run” while running around the space.
text: Botlhe ba arabe “Siana, siana, siana” fa ba tsweletse go dikologa mo sebakeng.

SourceText: Call out different instructions. For example, touch something red or hop like a frog.
text: Akanya ka ditaelo tse di farologaneng. Sekao, kgoma sengwe se se khibidu kgotsa o tlolatlole jaaka segwagwa.

SourceText: Keep playing and change the instructions each time.
text: Tswelela go tshameka mme o fetole ditaelo nako nngwe le nngwe.

SourceText: You can use this as a fun way to learn colours or even tidy up!
text: O ka dirisa seno jaaka tsela e e itumedisang go ithuta mebala kgotsa go phepafatsa!

SourceText: Run Around and Do This
text: Sianakaka mme o DIRE SE

SourceText: Everyone runs around the room or garden.  Make sure the space is large enough and safe.
text: Botlhe ba sianakaka go ralala phaposi kgotsa tshingwana.  Netefatsa gore sebaka se segolo jo bo lekaneng mme se bolokegile.

SourceText: At any time, someone can stop somewhere and say, “When you get over here, you do this!”
text: Nako nngwe fela, motho a ka ema gongwe mme a re, “Fa o fitlha fano, o dira se!”

SourceText: What you do can be anything: push-ups, singing a song, crying, jumping…
text: O ka dira sengwe le sengwe: ikgoromeletse godimo, go opela pina, go lela, go tlola...

SourceText: The more you play, the more there are things to do in more and more places.
text: Fa o ntse o tshameka, go nna le dilo tse dintsi tse o ka di dirang mo mafelong a mangwe a mantsi.

SourceText: Each person can decide where to go and when.
text: Motho mongwe le mongwe o kgona go swetsa gore o ya kae leng.

SourceText: It’s fun to interact with other people who are doing the same thing as you!
text: Go monate go ikgolaganya le batho ba bangwe ba o ba dirang selo se se tshwanang le se o se dirang!

SourceText: Say to your child “I see a tree, let’s be it!”
text: E re go ngwana wa gago “Ke bona setlhare, tla se nne sona”.

SourceText: Ship to Shore
text: Laola sekepe

SourceText: A fun active game where children learn different parts of a boat. Everyone must go to the place or activity that you call out.
text: Motshameko o o monate fao bana ba ithutang dikarolo tse di farologaneng tsa sekepe. Mongwe le mongwe o tshwanetse go ya kwa lefelong kgotsa a dire tirwana e o e goeleditseng.

SourceText: “Bow” means run to the front of the boat (room).
text: “E ya pele” go kaya gore sianela kwa pele ga sekepe (phaposi).

SourceText: “Stern” means run to the back of the boat.
text: “Boa” go kaya gore sianela kwa morago mo sekepeng.

SourceText: “Starboard” means run to the right side and “Port” means run to the left side.
text: “Mojeng” go kaya go sianela kwa letlhakoreng la moja fa “Molemeng” go kaya go sianela kwa molemeng.

SourceText: “Climb the rigging”: pretend to climb.
text: “A go iweng”: itire o ka re o a palama.

SourceText: “Clean the deck”: pretend to clean the floor.
text: “Selaselang”: itireng o ka re le phepafatsa fa fatshe.

SourceText: “Lifeboat, [number] people!”: hold hands in a circle with that many people and do knee bends.
text: Bapalamimmogo [palo]: tshwaranang ka diatla mo sedikong ka bontsi jwa lona mme le kobe mangole.

SourceText: Everyone not in a lifeboat must swim!
text: Botlhe bapalamimmogo ba tshwanela go thuma!

SourceText: Stage Directions
text: Dikaelo tsa Serala

SourceText: This is the same as Ship to Shore but with Stage Directions. This can be done in an elevated and safe area. The director gives the instructions.
text: Seno se tshwana fela le Laola Sekepe fela ka Dikaelo tsa Serala. Seno se ka dirwa mo lefelong le le tlhatlogileng mme le bolokegile. Moneelataelo o neelana ka ditaelo.

SourceText: “Stage Right” means you go to the right.
text: “Mojeng wa Serala” go kaya gore o ye mojeng.

SourceText: “Stage Left” means you go to the left.
text: “Molemeng wa Serala” go kaya gore o ye molemeng.

SourceText: “Downstage” means you go down.
text: “Tlase Seraleng” go kaya gore e ya tlase.

SourceText: “Upstage” means you go up.
text: “Tlase Seraleng” go kaya gore e ya tlase.

SourceText: “Centre Stage” means you go to the centre of the stage.”
text: “Serala Magareng” go kaya gore o ya magareng a serala.”

SourceText: You can have fun actions like “Dramatic Death, Take a Bow, Open the Curtain, Clean the Floor,” etc.
text: O ka diragatsa dilo tse di monate jaaka “Leso la Motlholo, Tswelantle, Bula garetene, Phepafatsa Fa fatshe,” jj.

SourceText: Instead of “Lifeboat” you make “Cast of Actors.” Those not in the cast become the director!
text: Gona le gore “Bapalamimmogo” go ka dira “Ithulaganyo ya Badiragatsi.” Bao ba seng mo ipaakanyong e nna baneeladitaelo!

SourceText: Superpowers
text: Maatla a Masaitsiweng

SourceText: Think of a superpower. For example, going anywhere instantly, travelling in time, reading minds.
text: * Akanya ka maatla a a sa tlwaelegang. Ka sekai, go ya gope fela ka ponyo ya leitlho, go busetsa nako morago, go bala megopolo.

SourceText: Ask your child “If you had the superpower to […] how would you use it?
text: * Botsa mosha wa gago jaana, “Fa o ka bo o na le maatla a a sa tlwaelegang a go […], o ne o tla a dirisa jang?”

SourceText: Encourage them to give themselves a superhero name and act it out.
text: * Ba kgothaletse go taya maatla a bone a a sa tlwaelegang leina le go a diragatsa.

SourceText: Now let them choose a super power for you!
text: Jaanong ba letle go go tlhophela matla a masaitsiweng!

SourceText: Make sure you act it out too!
text: Netefatsa gore o a a diragatsa!

SourceText: Transform the object
text: Fetola sengwe

SourceText: Everyday household items like brooms, mops, or scarfs can become fun props for games
text: Dilwana tsa fa gae tsa letsatsi le letsatsi jaaka mafielo, dimmopo, kgotsa disekhafo e ka nna ditshamekisi tsa metshameko

SourceText: Place an object in the center of the room and whenever someone has an idea, they jump in and show the rest what the object can be
text: Baya sengwe mo gare ga phaposi mme fela fa mongwe a na le kakanyo, a tlolele mo gare mme a bontshe botlhe gore selo se e ka nna eng

SourceText: For example, a broom might be ridden as a horse or a microphone or a guitar!
text: Sekao, lefielo e ka nna pitse kgotsa maekerofounu kgotsa katara!

SourceText: What Are You Doing?
text: O dira eng?

SourceText: This game is best when more than 2 people play
text: Motshameko ono o botoka fa o tshamekiwa ke batho ba feta ba le 2.

SourceText: One person pretends to be doing something – for example, combing hair or making dinner
text: * Motho a le nosi o itira e kete o dira sengwe - ka sekai, go kama moriri kgotsa go apaya dijo tsa maitseboa.

SourceText: Another person asks, “What are you doing?”
text: * Motho yo mongwe o botsa gore, “O dirang?”

SourceText: The first person needs to say something that has nothing to do with combing hair, for example, “Tying my shoes.”
text: * Motho wa ntlha o tlhoka go bua sengwe se se sa amaneng ka gope le go kama moriri, ka sekai, “Ke bofa ditlhako.”

SourceText: The second person then starts pretending to tie their shoes until a new person asks, “What are you doing?”
text: * Motho wa bobedi jaanong o simolola go itira ekete o bofa ditlhako tsa gagwe go fitlhelela motho yo mo ntshwa a botsa gore, “O dirang?”

SourceText: The answer must always be something different than what you are actually doing!
text: Karabo e tshwanetse ka metlha ya nna e e farologaneng go na le se o se dirang!

SourceText: Worms Go Home
text: Diboko di ya gae.

SourceText: Lie on your tummies and pretend your index fingers are a wiggly worm.
text: Patlamang mme le itire o kare menwana wa lona ya kgononoje ke dibokwana.

SourceText: With your other hand make a worm house by making a circle with your fingers and thumb and place it on the floor.
text: Ka letsogo le lengwe dira ntlo ya diboko ka go dira sediko ka menwana le kgononoje mme o le beye fa fatshe.

SourceText: Call out an instruction for your finger to touch, like “Worms on noses” or “Worms on ears”
text: Goeletsa taelo gore monwana wa gago o kgome, jaaka “Diboko nkong” kgotsa “Diboko tsebeng”

SourceText: When you call out “Worms go home”, your wiggly worm has to find a worm house as quickly as possible.
text: Fa o goeletsa “Diboko di ya gae”, sebokwana se monokelela go ya kwa ntlong ya doboko ka bonako jo bo kgonegang.

SourceText: The last worm to find a home calls out the instructions next.
text: Seboko sa bofelo go fitlha kwa gae se goeletsa ditaelo tse di latelang.

SourceText: Keep playing until you feel rejuvenated from lying down.
text: Tswelela go tshameka go fitlha o ikutlwa o tsogologile go tswa mo go rapameng.

SourceText: Blind Dragon
text: KTerakone ya Sefofu

SourceText: This game is great if you have at least 4 people
text: Motshameko o o siame fa o na le bonnye batho ba le 4

SourceText: Tell the story about a ferocious dragon who lived near a village. He would sneak into the village at night and steal people’s treasures – anything they loved.  Anybody who tried to take their treasure back would be eaten alive.  This continued for many years until the dragon became old, fat, and blind from sitting on his treasure and gazing at the glare of the gold coins. Then the townspeople could try and sneak into his lair and steal back their relatives’ treasure.
text: Bua ka kgang ya terakone e e setlhogo e e neng e nna gaufi le motse. O ne a khukhunela mo motseng bosigo le go utswa dikhum tsa batho - sengwe le sengwe se ba se ratang.  Mongwe le mongwe yo o neng a leka go tsaya dikhumo tsa gagwe o ne a jewa a ntse a tshela.  Seno se tswelletse jalo dingwaga di le dintsi go fitlhela terakone e tsofala, e nona, le go foufala ka fa e ntse mo dikhumong tsa yona le go bogela dikhoene tsa gauta. Morago baagi ba teropo ba ne ba leka go khukhuna le go tsena kwa ga yona mme ba utswe dikhumo tsa masika a bona gape.

SourceText: One person plays the dragon. Dragon sits blindfolded or with eyes closed surrounded by a pile of treasure.
text: Motho a le mongwe o itira terakone. Terakone e nna e tswetse matlho kgotsa a bofilwe matlho mme a dikologilwe ke thoto ya dikhumo.

SourceText: Everyone has one piece of treasure that they must steal back.
text: Mongwe le mongwe o na le setokwana sa khumo se a tshwanela go se utswa gape...

SourceText: If the dragon hears you and points at you, you must go back to the starting place.
text: Fa terakone e go utlwa mme e go supa, o tshwanetse go boela kwa morago kwa lefelong la tshimololo.

SourceText: Only one person can try to get the treasure at a time.
text: Ke motho a le mongwe fela yo a kgonang go bona khumo ka nako.

SourceText: Dancing with Angels
text: Go tansa le Manyeloi

SourceText: This activity helps children learn how to lead. It also builds trust between you and your child.
text: Tirwana e e thusa bana go ithuta go etelelapele. Gape e aga tshepano magareng ga gago le ngwana wa gago.

SourceText: Play a piece of music that is gentle and relaxed to encourage smooth and calming movement.
text: TLetsa mmino o o edileng le go ritibala jalo go rotloetsa motsamao o o eldileng le go ritibalala.

SourceText: One person goes first and closes their eyes while the other person is the guardian angel or protector.
text: Motho a le mongwe o tsamaya pele mme a tswale matlho fa motho yo mongwe e le lenyeloi la tlhokomelo kgotsa mosireletsi.

SourceText: The guardian angel must protect the person with their eyes closed from harm while gently dancing together.
text: Lenyeloi la tlhokomelo le tshwanetse go sireletsa motlo yo o tswetseng matlho mo kotsing fa ba tsweletse go tansa mmogo.

SourceText: When the music ends, the dancer can open their eyes before switching roles.
text: Fa pina e fela, motansi a ka bula matlho pele a refosanela karolo.

SourceText: Drawing
text: Go thala

SourceText: Children love to draw! It helps build creativity.
text: Bana ba rata go thala! Go ba thusa go aga boitlhamedi.

SourceText: Get some pens or crayons and a piece of paper or cardboard.
text: Bona sipene kgotsa dikherayone dingwe le setokwana sa pampiri kgotsa lebokoso.

SourceText: Let your children freely draw whatever they want.
text: Letla bana ba gago go thala se ba se ratang ka phuthologo.

SourceText: While your child is drawing, use words to describe what they are doing: “I see you are drawing a person” or “I see you are making lines with the red crayon.”
text: Fa ngwana wa gago a thala, dirisa mafoko go tlhalosa gore ba dira eng: “Ke a bona gore o thala motho” kgotsa “Ke a bona go thala mela ka kerayone e khibidu.”

SourceText: You can also have fun drawing next to them.
text: Gape o ka itumedisa ka go thala fa thoko ga bona.

SourceText: Put their drawings up on the wall, refrigerator, or outside to decorate the house – it will make your children feel appreciated!
text: Pega dithalwa tsa bona mo leboteng, mo setsidifatsing, kwa ntle go kgabisa ntlo - go tla dira gore bana ba gago ba ikutlwe ba ananeelwa!

SourceText: Listening to Sounds
text: go reetsa medumo

SourceText: Sit down and close your eyes
text: Nna fatshe o tswale matlho a gago.

SourceText: How many sounds can you hear? Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers
text: O utlwa medumo e kae? Reetsa medumo e e mo teng le kwa ntle ga kamore. E bale ka menwana ya gago.

SourceText: After ten seconds, how many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear?
text: Morago ga metsotswana e le lesome, go setse menwana e kae e e emeng? O utlwile medumo efe?

SourceText: Try again for another ten seconds.
text: Leka gape metsotswana e le lesome.

SourceText: Can you hear any new sounds? Can you hear any sounds inside your own body?
text: A o utlwile medumo e mesha? A o kgona go utlwa medumo mo teng ga mmele wa gago?

SourceText: Notice how you feel and ask your child how they are feeling.
text: Lemoga gore o ikutlwa jang mme o botse ngwana wa gago gore o ikutlwa jang.

SourceText: Memory game – “When COVID-19 ends…”
text: Motshameko wa mogopolo - “Fa COVID-19 e fela...”

SourceText: First person says, “When COVID-19 ends, I am going to… (e.g., go to the park)”
text: Motho wa ntlha a re, “Fa COVID-19 e fela, ke ya kwa... (s.k., ke ya kwa parakeng)”

SourceText: Second person adds to the first person’s plan, “When COVID-19 ends, I am going to the park and… (e.g., visit my best friend)”
text: Motho wa bobedi o tlatsa wa ntlha ka gore, “Fa COVID-19 e fela ke ya kwa parakeng le... (s.k., ke etela tsala ya me e kgolo).

SourceText: Each person adds to the previous list of plans, trying to think of all of the fun things to do when COVID-19 ends.
text: * Motho mongwe le mongwe o tlatsa yo o sa tswang go feta, ba leka go akanya ka dilo tsotlhe tse di itumedisang go ka di dira fa COVID-19e fela.

SourceText: Self-portrait
text: Sethalwa sa gago

SourceText: Here’s how your children can draw a picture of themselves!
text: Fano ke gore bana ba ka thala jang setshwantsho sa bona!

SourceText: Find a big piece of paper or cardboard. It needs to be the same length or slightly longer than the height of your child
text: Bona setokwana se segolo sa pampiri kgotsa lebokoso. E tshwanetse go nna boleele jo bo lekanang kgotsa e nne teletsana go feta ngwana wa gago.

SourceText: Ask your child to lie down on the paper. Carefully draw the outline of your child.
text: Kopa ngwana wa gago go robala mo godimo ga pampiri. Thala ka kelotlhoko sebopego sa ngwana wa gago.

SourceText: Now let your child fill in the outline: face, hair, clothes, shoes, or anything they want!
text: Jaanong letla ngwana wa gago go tlaleletsa sebopego: sefatlhego, moriri, diaparo, ditlhako, kgotsa sengwe fela se a se batlang!

SourceText: Ask your child to draw things that they like and do not like outside of the outline
text: Kopa ngwana wa gago go thala dimo tse ba di ratang mme tse ba sa di rateng ka kwa ntle ga sebopego.

SourceText: Have a conversation with your child about these things. You may learn something about your child!
text: Buisana le ngwana wa gago ka ga dilo tse. O ka ithuta sengwe ka ngwana wa gago!

SourceText: You can put their outline up in their room or anywhere in the house – it will make your children feel appreciated!
text: O ka pega sethalwa sa bona ka mo phaposing ya bona kgotsa gongwe fela mo ntlong - go tla dira gore bana ba gago ba ikutlwe ba ananeelwa!

SourceText: Story time
text: Nako ya Kgang

SourceText: Start the story with “Once upon a time there was a…”
text: * Simolola kgang ka “Ga twe e rile....”

SourceText: Let your child make up the next sentence
text: * Letla ngwana wa gago go itirela polelwana e e latelang.

SourceText: Then you make up a sentence
text: * Morago ga moo itirele polelwana.

SourceText: Take turns until you have a wonderful new story
text: * Refosanang go fitlhelela lo nna le kgang e ntshwa e e gakgamatsang.

SourceText: Make sure to end the story on a positive note.
text: * Netefatsang gore lo khutlhisa kgang ka ntlha e e siameng.

SourceText: Ask your child what was their favourite part of the story!
text: * Botsa ngwana wa gago gore ke karolo efe e a e ratileng thata ya polelo!

SourceText: The Interrupter
text: Sekgoreletsi

SourceText: Choose a storyteller to start making up a story.
text: * Tlhopha mmegakgang go simolola go itlhamela kgang.

SourceText: Story listeners can interrupt with a word at any time.
text: * Bareetsakgang ba ka nna ba go tsena ganong ka lefoko ka nako nngwe le nngwe fela.

SourceText: The storyteller needs to fit that word in their story.
text: Mmegakgang polelo o tlhoka go tsenyeletsa lefoko leo mo kgannyeng ya gagwe.

SourceText: Try with a different storyteller!
text: Leka se ka mmegakgang yo o faroganeng!

SourceText: Three options
text: Diitlhophelo di le tharo

SourceText: Think of three different situations. For example, driving a car, sailing a boat or flying a plane
text: * Akanya ka maemo a mararo a a sa tshwaneng. Ka sekai, go kgweetsa koloi, go kgweetsa mokoro kgotsa go fofisa sefofane.

SourceText: Say them to your child and ask, “Which would you prefer?”
text: * Di bolelele ngwana wa gago o bo o mmotsa gore, “Ke efe e o ka e ratang?”

SourceText: Ask them why?
text: * Ba botse gore goreng?

SourceText: Now think of three more situations or ask your child to do it for you
text: * Jaanong akanya ka maemo a mangwe gape a le mararo kgotsa kopa mosha wa gago go go direla jalo.

SourceText: When I Was Younger
text: Fa ke ne ke le monnye

SourceText: Children love to hear stories about your own life!
text: Bana ba rata go utlwa dikgang ka ga botshelo jwa gago!

SourceText: Think of a time when you were younger when something BIG happened to you
text: Akanya nako fa o ne o le monnye fa sengwe se SEGOLO se ne se go diragaleng

SourceText: It can be an adventure, happy memory, or challenge that you experienced
text: E ka nna kutololo, kgolopo e e monate, kgotsa kgwetlho e o e itemogetseng

SourceText: Share it with your child and notice how they listen!
text: e arolelanele le ngwana wa gago mme o lemoge gore ba reetsa jang!

SourceText: Co-chef
text: Moapei-mmogo

SourceText: Ask your teen what kind of meal they would like to eat.
text: * Botsa mosha wa gago gore ke mofuta ofe wa dijo tse a tla ratang go di ja.

SourceText: Prepare it together! The first time, you may need to guide them.
text: * Di baakanyetseng mmogo! O ka tshwanela go ba kaela kwa ntlheng.

SourceText: Once your teen knows how to prepare the meal, let them take the lead and follow their instructions.
text: Fela fa mosha wa gago a itse go apaya, mo letle go eteleapele mme wena o latele ditaelo.

SourceText: Let each child and teen in the house have a turn at being the head chef.
text: Letla ngwana mongwe le mongwe mo ntlong go refosanela go nna moapei.

SourceText: You can even help them make a budget for ingredients!
text: * O ka nna wa ba thusa go dira tekanyetsokabo ya ditswaki!

SourceText: Shake your left hands in the air 8 times while counting to 8.
text: * Tshikinyang matsogo a lona a molema mo moweng ga 8 fa lo ntse lo bala go fitlha go 8.

SourceText: Do it as fast and loud as you can.
text: * Dirang seno ka bonako le kwa godimo ka mo go kgonegang.

SourceText: Repeat with your other hand. Then do it for each foot.
text: * Boeletsang seno ka matsogo a lona a mangwe. Morago o dire se ka leoto lengwe le lengwe.

SourceText: Everyone calls out “Crazy chicken” when you’re finished and does their best crazy chicken dance!
text: * Mongwe le mongwe o goeletsa a re “Kgoko e e sa utlweng” ba bo ba diragatsa go bina ga bone go go gaisang ga koko e e sa utlweng!

SourceText: Create a dance choreography to your teen's favorite songs.
text: Tlhama khareokerafi ya tanse ya dipina tse basha ba gago ba di ratang.

SourceText: Get active!
text: Nna matlhagatlhaga!

SourceText: Come up with three types of exercise together. For example, walking, jogging, soccer or dancing
text: * Tla ka mefuta e meraro ya go ikatisa mmele e lo ka e dirang mmogo. Ka sekai, go tsamaya, go tshematshema, kgwele ya dinao kgotsa go tansa.

SourceText: Pick one together and try it out.
text: * Tlhopha e le nngwe mmogo mme lo e leke.

SourceText: If you both like it, decide how often you are going to do it. Once or twice a week? Every morning?
text: * Fa ka bobedi lo e rata, dirang tshwetso ya gore lo tlile go e dira kgapetsa ga kae. Gangwe kgotsa gabedi ka beke? Moso mongwe le mongwe?

SourceText: Together think of ways to make it even more fun. Can you jog to a certain point? Take turns in being the coach? Motivate each other with a small free reward?
text: * Lo akanyeng mmogo ka ditsela tsa go e dira monate le go feta. A o ka kgona go taboga go ya bokgakaleng jo bo rileng? Refosanang ka go nna bakaedi? Kgothatsanang ka tuelo e nnye ya mahala?

SourceText: When we are able to have peaceful and loving relationships, our children feel more secure and loved. Today's tip is about how we can support positive family relationships at home.
text: Fa re kgona go aga dikamano tse di nang le kagiso le lerato, bana ba rona ba ikutlwa ba sireletsegile le go ratiwa. Kakantsho ya gompieno e ka ga gore re ka tshegetsa jang dikamano tse di siameng tsa balelapa fa gae.

SourceText: Everyone else must guess the name of the tune (to make it harder, they can guess the singer).
text: * Mongwe le mongwe o tshwanetse go fopholetsa leina la pina (go e dira thata ba ka fopholetsa moopedi).

SourceText: The first one to guess it right becomes the next leader who will choose or sing the next song.
text: Wa ntlha go fopholetsa ka nepo e nna ene moeteledipele yo o latelang yo o tla tlhophang kgotsa a opela pina e e latelang.

SourceText: Pass the Snap
text: Thwantsha menwana

SourceText: This game is best with at least 3 people.
text: Motshameko ono o botoka fa o na le bobotlana batho ba le 3.

SourceText: Start in a circle and pass one snap around the circle (or clap if you cannot snap).
text: * Simolola mo teng ga kgolokwe mme o bo o fetisa “thwantsho” e le nngwe go dikologa kgolokwe (kgotsa go “opa diatla” fa o sa kgone go thwantsha).

SourceText: You snap once to throw the snap.
text: O ka thantsha monwana kgotsa wa o konopelo

SourceText: You can bounce the snap, throw it in the air, and catch it a few times before passing it.
text: * O ka busetsa morago “thwantsho”, wa e latlhela mo moweng, le go e tshwara ka makgetlo a le mmalwa pele ga o e fetisa.

SourceText: The direction (up, down, straight, curved, rolling the ground) and force (hard, soft, medium) that you throw the snap should affect how the person catches it.
text: * Letlhakore (godimo, tlase, tlhamaletseng, kgogoropo, dikologang fa fatshe) le maatla (thata, bonolo, magareng) a o thwantshang ka one a tshwanetse go ama tsela e motho a e tshwarang ka teng.

SourceText: Look at the person you are throwing the snap to.
text: Leba motho yo o mo latlhelelang yone.

SourceText: The person who will catch it has to snap once to catch it.
text: Motho oyo o tla tshwarang o tshwanetse go tswantsha gangwe go e tshwara.

SourceText: When everyone gets good at this, you can start moving around the room, still passing around the snap.
text: * Fa mongwe le mongwe a setse a tshwara seno, o ka simolola go suta go dikologa kamore, o ntse o latlhela “thwantsho”.

SourceText: Can you throw under the leg?  Behind the back?  Through your head?  Intercept a pass? Have fun with the snap!
text: * A o ka e latlhela kafa tlase ga leoto?  Mo mokotleng?  Mo godimo ga tlhogo?  Go kgaosetsa phetiso ya yone? Ijeseng monate ka “thwantsho monwana”!

SourceText: This game is best when more than 2 people play.
text: Motshameko ono o botoka fa o tshamekiwa ke batho ba feta ba le 2.

SourceText: One person pretends to be doing something – for example, combing hair.
text: * Motho a le nosi o itira e kete o dira sengwe - ka sekai, go kama moriri kgotsa go apaya dijo tsa maitseboa.

SourceText: A second person asks, “What are you doing?”
text: * Motho yo mongwe o botsa gore, “O dirang?”

SourceText: The second person’s answer must always be something different from what they are actually doing!
text: Karabo e tshwanetse ka metlha ya nna e e farologaneng go na le se o se dirang!

SourceText: The next person should act out the second person’s answer and when someone asks what they are doing, their answer must be different from what they are actually doing!
text: Motho yo o latelang o tshwanetse go diragatsa karabo ya motho wa bobedi mme fa mongwe a botsa gore o dirangkarabo ya bona e tshwanetse go farologaa le se a se dirang!

SourceText: What’s new?
text: Ke eng se sesha?

SourceText: Think of a new skill you could learn together with your teen. For example, keeping a ball in the air or your foot, juggling, learning a new language, or playing an instrument?
text: * Akanya ka botswerere jo bosha jo lo ka bo ithutang mmogo le mosha wa gago. Sekao, go tshola bolo mo moweng kgotsa mo leotong, o e tshamekitshamekisa, go ithuta puo e ntshwa, kgotsa go letsa seletswa?

SourceText: Take turns in trying the new skill out.
text: * Refosanang ka go leka kgono e ntshwa.

SourceText: Make sure to praise each other, and try to learn and play together!
text: * Netefatsa gore lo a bakana, mme lo leke go ithuta le go tshameka mmogo!

SourceText: It might help to think of wishes, dreams, experiences at school, likes or dislikes. For example, I hate bananas, my favourite subject is science, and I really wish I could sing.
text: * Go ka nna ga thusa go akanya ka dikeletso, ditoro, maitemogelo a ko sekolong, tse di rategang kgotsa tse di sa rategeng. Sekao, Ke tlhoile dipanana, serutwa se ke se ratang ke saense, mme ke eletsa e kete nkabo ke kgona go opela.

SourceText: Say them to your teenager. Ask them to guess which one is a lie.
text: Di boleletse mosha wa gago.  Ba kope go fopholetsa gore ke efe e e leng maaka.

SourceText: Now ask them to do the same. Did you learn something new about each other?
text: Jaanong ba kope ba dire se se tshwanang. A lo ithutile sengwe se sesha ka yo mongwe?

SourceText: Talk to your teen about one positive or fun thing they did.
text: * Bua le mosha wa gago ka selo se le nosi sa go ijesa monate se ba se dirileng.

SourceText: Dream Travel
text: Loeto lo lo Batlang go lo Tsaya

SourceText: You can’t travel but you can dream! Ask your teen these questions.
text: O ka se tseye leeto fela o ka lora! Botsa mosha wa gago dipotso tseno:

SourceText: Where do you want to travel? How long will you be away? What will you pack? What will you do? What will you see?
text: O batla go etela kae? Wa go tsamaya lobaka lo lo kae? O tla paka eng? O tla dira eng? O tla bona eng?

SourceText: Look at a map together if you have one.
text: Fa lo na le mmepe o lebeng mmogo.

SourceText: Choose a country that they’ve never heard of and look it up together online.
text: tlhopha naga e lo itse lo utlwe ka ga yona mme le e batleisise mo inthaneteng mmogo.

SourceText: How was your day?
text: O tlhotse jang?

SourceText: Ask each other, “What made you happy today?”
text: * Botsanang gore, “Ke eng se se go itumedisitseng gompieno?”

SourceText: Ask each other, “What was difficult today?”
text: Botsanang, “Ke eng se se nning bokete gompieno?”

SourceText: Ask each other, “How can we help you?”
text: * Botsanang gore, “Nka go thusa jang?”

SourceText: Try to do this together every day, when you are eating together or before bed
text: * Lekang go dira seno mmogo letsatsi le letsatsi; e ka nna ka nako ya fa lo ja dijo tsa maitseboa mmogo kgotsa pele ga lo ya go robala.

SourceText: Just a friendly chat
text: Motlotlo fela wa botsalano

SourceText: Have a conversation with your teen about something they like.
text: Nna le puisano le mosha wa gago ka selo se ba se ratang.

SourceText: It can be about anything they choose to talk about: sports, friends, music, celebrities…
text: E ka nna sengwe le sengwe se ba tlhophang go bua ka sone: metshameko, ditsala, mmino, batho ba ba tumileng...

SourceText: Try to listen to your teen and give them space to talk.
text: Leka go reetsa mosha wa gago mme o ba neye sebaka sa go bua.

SourceText: What new thing did you learn about your teen from your chat?
text: O ithutile eng se seswa ka ga mosha wa gago go tswa mo puisanong?

SourceText: Make up a story!
text: Itlhamele kgang!

SourceText: Let your teen make up the next sentence.
text: * Letla mosha wa gago go itirela polelwana e e latelang.

SourceText: Then you make up a sentence.
text: * Morago ga moo itirele polelwana.

SourceText: Take turns until you have a wonderful new story.
text: * Refosanang go fitlhelela lo nna le kgang e e ntshwa e e gakgamatsang.

SourceText: Ask your teen what was their favourite part of the story!
text: * Botsa mosha wa gago gore ke karolo efe e a e ratileng thata ya kgang!

SourceText: Ask your teen “If you had the superpower to […] how would you use it?”
text: * Botsa mosha wa gago jaana, “Fa o ka bo o na le maatla a a sa tlwaelegang a go […], o ne o tla a dirisa jang?”

SourceText: Encourage them to give themselves a superhero name and act like a superhero.
text: * Ba kgothaletse go taya maatla a bone a a sa tlwaelegang leina le go a diragatsa.

SourceText: Now let them choose a super power for you.
text: Jaanong ba letle go go tlhophela matla a masaitsiweng!

SourceText: Make sure you act it out too!
text: Netefatsa gore o a a diragatsa!

SourceText: Think of three different situations. For example, driving a car, sailing a boat, or flying a plane.
text: * Akanya ka maemo a mararo a a sa tshwaneng. Ka sekai, go kgweetsa koloi, go kgweetsa mokoro kgotsa go fofisa sefofane.

SourceText: Say them to your teen and ask, “Which would you prefer?”
text: * Di bolelele mosha wa gago o bo o mmotsa gore, “Ke efe e o ka e ratang?”

SourceText: Now think of three more situations or ask your teen to do it for you.
text: * Jaanong akanya ka maemo a mangwe gape a le mararo kgotsa kopa mosha wa gago go go direla jalo.

SourceText: Second person adds to first person’s plan, “When COVID-19 ends, I am going to the park and… (e.g., visit my best friend)”
text: * Motho wa bobedi o tlatsa wa ntlha ka gore, “Fa COVID-19 e fela, ke ya kwa parakeng le... (s.k., ke etela tsala ya me e kgolo).

SourceText: Yes, No or Maybe
text: Ee, Nnyaa kgotsa Gongwe

SourceText: Ask each other questions. They can be any questions about things you like or what you did today.
text: * Botsanang dipotso. E ka nna dipotso dipe fela kaga dilo tse o di ratang kgotsa se o se dirileng gompieno.

SourceText: The only rule is that you can’t answer Yes, No or Maybe
text: * Molawana o le nosi fela ke gore o ka se arabe ka “Ee”, “Nnyaa” kgotsa “Gongwe”.

SourceText: How long can you last? How creative can you get with your answers?
text: * O ka kgona go tsaya lobaka lo lo kae? O ka itirela dikarabo tse di kgatlhang jang?

SourceText: Swap over and play again!
text: * Refosanang mme lo tshameke gape!

SourceText: There are no bad children...only difficult behaviours! All children misbehave but these tips can help.
text: Ga gona bana ba ba bosula...ke ba ba maitsholo a a sa tlhaloganyegeng! Bana botlhe ba kgona go se itshole sentle fela dikakantsho tse di ka thusa.

SourceText: Which child do you want tips for?
text: O batlela ngwana ofe dikakantsho?

SourceText: Please select the age of your child:
text: Ka kopo tlhopha dingwaga tsa ngwana wa gago:

SourceText: A. Under 1 month
text: A. Mo tlase go kgwedi

SourceText: B. 1-2 months
text: B.  dikgwedi di le 1-2

SourceText: C. 3-5 months
text: C. dikgwedi di le 3-5

SourceText: D. 6-9 months
text: D. dikgwedi di le 6-9

SourceText: E. 10 -14 months
text: E. dikgwedi di le 10-14

SourceText: F. 15-18 months
text: F. dikgwedi di le 15-18

SourceText: G. 19-23 months
text: G. dikgwedi di le 19-23

SourceText: Which behaviour is most like the one you want support for?
text: Ke maitsholo afe a o batlang go a bonela tshegetso?

SourceText: Here are 8 simple tips to help you with your teen:
text: Fano ke dikakantsho tse di bonolo di le 8 go go thusa ka mosha wa gago:

SourceText: 1. Keep it positive
text: 1. Nna le tshepo

SourceText: 2. Invest in time
text: 2. Beeletsa go nako

SourceText: 3. Create routines
text: 3. Tlhama mekgwatlwaelo

SourceText: 4. Be open to your children
text: 4. Phuthologa go bana ba gago

SourceText: 5. Use reasonable consequences
text: 5. Dirisa ditlamorago tse di tlhaloganyengang

SourceText: 6. Solve problems with your teen
text: 6. Rarabolola mathata le mosha wa gago

SourceText: 7. Keeping your teen safe online
text: 7. Go tshola mosha wa gago a bolokegile go inthanete

SourceText: 8. Resolving crises when they happen
text: 8. Go rarabolola bothata fa bo direga

SourceText: Type "1" to "8" if you want to learn more about a specific strategy.
text: Tlanya “1” go ya go “8” fa o batla fo ithuta go le gontsi ka ga togamaano e e rileng.

SourceText: Here are 5 simple tips to help you with your babies:
text: Fano ke dikakantsho tse di bonolo di le 5 go go thusa ka masea a ago:

SourceText: 1. Play with your baby
text: 1. Tshameka le lesea la gago

SourceText: 2. Create routines
text: 2. Tlhama mekgwatlwaelo

SourceText: 3. Share books with your baby
text: 3. Arolelanelang dibuka le lesea la gago

SourceText: 4. Cope with crying
text: 4. Samagana le go lela

SourceText: 5. Redirect them to positive behaviours
text: 5. Ba kaele gape go maitsholo a a siameng

SourceText: Type "1" to "5" if you want to learn more about a specific strategy.
text: Tlanya “1” go ya go “5” fa o batla fo ithuta go le gontsi ka ga togamaano e e rileng.

SourceText: Here are 9 simple tips to help you with your children:
text: Fano ke dikakantsho tse di bonolo di le 9 go go thusa kabana ba gago:

SourceText: 6. Ignore attention seeking and demanding behaviours
text: 6. Ikgatholose maitsholo a a batlang go elatlhoko le go batla sengwe

SourceText: 7. Use reasonable consequences
text: 7. Dirisa ditlamorago tse di tlhaloganyengang

SourceText: 8. Solving problems with your child
text: 8. Rarabolola mathata le ngwana wa gago

SourceText: 9. Keeping your child safe online
text: 9. Go tshola ngwana wa gago a bolokegile go inthanete

SourceText: Type "1" to "9" if you want to learn more about a specific strategy.
text: Tlanya “1” go ya go “9” fa o batla fo ithuta go le gontsi ka ga togamaano e e rileng.

SourceText: Remember that you’re in charge of what they eat, but not how much. Newborns have stomach the size of a grape! They need to eat often (sometimes in the middle of the night.
text: Gopola gore o laola gore ba ja eng, fela e seng gore bontsi jo bokae. Masea a na le mpa ya bogolo jwa terebe! Ba tlhoka go ja gantsi (nako dingwe le mo mpeng ya bosigo).

SourceText: It’s important to build trust around eating, especially as your baby starts on solid food. Let them know you are listening to their wishes in the eating department. They’ll be ravenous again soon!
text: Go botlhokwa go aga botshephegi ka go ja, segolo fa lesea la gago le simolola go ja dijo sentle. Ba lemose gore o reeditse dikeletso tsa bona go lefapha la dijo. Ba tla tshwarwa ke tlala gape go ise go e kae!

SourceText: Would you like suggestions for active and calm things to do with @fields.child_nickname?
text: A o ka rata ditshitsinyo tsa dilo tse di matlhagatlhaga le tse di ritibetseng tse o ka di dirang le ngwana wa gago?
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: When your children ask you about COVID-19, be willing to talk. They will already have heard something. Silence and secrets do not protect our children. Honesty and openness do. Think about how much they will understand. You know them best.
text: Fa bana ba gago ba go botsa ka ga COVID-19, bua. Ba tshwanetse go bo ba setse ba utlwile sengwe. Tidimalo le diphiri ga di sireletse bana ba rona. Nnete le go phuthologa go a thusa. Akanya gore ba tla tlhaloganya go le kae. O ba itse botoka.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you talk about COVID-19 with your children!
text: Fano ke bidiyo go go thusa go bua ka ga COVID-19 le bana ba gago!

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you talk about COVID-19 with your children!
text: Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo go go thusa go bua ka ga COVID-19 le bana ba gago!

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about how to talk about COVID-19 with your child. Chat to you later!
text: Ga se bothata! Ka gale o ka tlanya “Thuso” fa o batla go ithuta go le gontsi ka ga gore o ka bua jang le ngwana wa gago ka COVID-19 Ke tla bua le wena moragonyana!

SourceText: Here are 4 simple steps that you can do when talking about COVID-19 with your children:
text: Fano ke dikgato tse di bonolo di le 4 tse o ka di tsayang fa o bua ka ga COVID-19 le bana ba gago:

SourceText: 1. Be open, honest, and supportive
text: 1. Phuthologa, bua nnete mme o neelane ka tshegetso

SourceText: 2. It is okay not to know the answers
text: 2. Go siame go bo o sa itse dikarabo

SourceText: 3. Be a hero not a bully
text: 3. Nna mogaka e seng mokgokgontshi

SourceText: 4. End on a good note
text: 4. Digela ka nnoto e e kwa godimo

SourceText: Type "1" to "4" to learn more about each tip. Type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Go ithuta go le gontsi ka nngwe le nngwe ya dikakantsho tse, tlanya “1” go ya go “4”. Tlanya “N” go emisa kakantsho e.

SourceText: Step 3. Be a hero not a bully
text: Kgato 3. Nna mogaka e seng mokgokgontshi

SourceText: Explain that COVID-19 has nothing to do with the way someone looks, where they are from, or what language they speak.
text: tlhalosa gore COVID-19ga e ye ka gore mongwe o lebega jang, gore o tswa kae, kgotsa gore o bua puo efe.

SourceText: Here is a comic on how to talk to your child about COVID-19.
text: Fano ke khomiki gore o ka bua jang le ngwana wa gago ka ga COVID-19.

SourceText: Child: “Am I going to get coronavirus?”
text: Ngwana: “A ke tlile go tshwaetsega ka mogare wa corona?”

SourceText: Parent: “It is very possible that we will all get coronavirus. But younger people do not normally get very sick.”
text: Motsadi: “Go a kgonagala gore rotlhe re ka tshwaetsega ka mogare wa corona. Fela ga go a tlwaelega gore bana ba bannye ba lwale thata.”

SourceText: Child: “I am scared…”
text: Ngwana: “Ke tshogile...?

SourceText: Parent: “It is okay to be afraid. We are all a bit scared about this. But we have each other and can do our best to keep ourselves and other people safe and healthy.”
text: Motsadi: “Go siame go tshoga. Re tshogile rotlhe ka ga se. Fela re mmogo mme re ka dira bojotlhe go itshola mmogo le ba bangwe le bolokesegile e bile re itekanetse.”

SourceText: Child: “How can we keep safe?”
text: Ngwana: “Ke kgona go itshireletsa jang?”

SourceText: Parent: “We can wash our hands regularly for 20 seconds. We can also keep a good physical distance away from people. We also need to try to avoid touching our faces as much as possible.”
text: Motsadi: “Ke tlhapa diatla ka gale metsotswana e le 20. Gape re ka nnela sekgala go tloga go batho. Gape re tlhoka go efoga go kgoma difatlhego tsa rona ka fa o go kgonagalang.”

SourceText: Child, “Okay…”
text: Ngwana, “LKe a legoba...”

SourceText: Child: “What happens to your body when you get coronavirus?”
text: Ngwana: “Go diragalang mo mmeleng wa gago fa o tshwaetsega ka mogare wa corona?”

SourceText: Parent: “To tell you the truth, I don’t know exactly. How about we look on the UNICEF website together?”
text: Motsadi: “Go go bolelela sentle, ga ke itse sentle. Go ka nna jang fa re ka etela weposaete ya UNICEF mmogo?”

SourceText: WHO: https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public
text: URL ke https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019

SourceText: UNICEF: https://www.unicef.org/coronavirus/covid-19
text: UNICEF: https://www.unicef.org/coronavirus/covid-19

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to talk about COVID-19 with your children:
text: Ka kopo tlhopha nomoro e nngwe fa o batla go ithuta go feta ka ga go bua ka ga COVID-19 le bana ba gago:

SourceText: Step 1. Be open, honest, and supportive
text: Kgato 1. Phuthologa, bua nnete mme o neelane ka tshegetso

SourceText: Allow @fields.child_nickname to talk freely. Ask them open questions and find out how much they already know.
text: Letla 1 go bua ka phuthologo. Ba botse dipotso tse di batlang dikarabo ka botlalo mme o bone gore ba setse ba itse go le kanakang.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Allow your child to talk freely. Ask them open questions and find out how much they already know.
text: Letla ngwana wa gago go bua ka phuthologo. Ba botse dipotso tse di batlang dikarabo ka botlalo mme o bone gore ba setse ba itse go le kanakang.

SourceText: Always answer their questions truthfully. Think about how old @fields.child_nickname is and how much they can understand.
text: Ka gale araba dipotso tsa bona ka boammaruri. Akanya gore 1 o bogolo jo bo kanakang le gore o kgona go tlhaloganya bontsi jo bo kanakang.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: @fields.child_nickname may be scared or confused. Give them space to share how they are feeling and let them know you are there for them.
text: 1 a ka tswa a tshogile le go etsaetsega. Ba neele sebaka go arolelanela gore ba ikutlwa jang mme o ba letle go itse gore o gona.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Always answer their questions truthfully. Think about how old your child is and how much they can understand.
text: Ka gale araba dipotso tsa bona ka boammaruri. Akanya gore ngwana wa gago o bogolo jo bo kanakang le gore o kgona go tlhaloganya bontsi jo bo kanakang.

SourceText: Your child may be scared or confused. Give them space to share how they are feeling and let them know you are there for them.
text: Ngwana wa gago  a ka tswa a tshogile le go etsaetsega. Ba neele sebaka go arolelanela gore ba ikutlwa jang mme o ba letle go itse gore o gona.

SourceText: Step 4. End on a good note
text: Kgato 4. Digela ka nnoto e e kwa godimo

SourceText: Check to see if @fields.child_nickname is okay. Remind them that you care and that they can talk to you anytime. Then do something fun together!
text: Tlhatlhoba go bona gore a 1 o siame. Ba gopotse gore o a kgathala le gore ba ka bua le wena ka nako nngwe le nngwe. Morago lo dire sengwe se se itumedisang mmogo!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Check to see if your child is okay. Remind them that you care and that they can talk to you anytime. Then do something fun together!
text: Tlhatlhoba go bona gore a ngwana wa gago o siame. Ba gopotse gore o a kgathala le gore ba ka bua le wena ka nako nngwe le nngwe. Morago lo dire sengwe se se itumedisang mmogo!

SourceText: Step 2. It is OK not to know the answers.
text: Kgato 2. GO SIAME go bo o sa itse dikarabo

SourceText: It is fine to say “We don’t know, but we are working on it; or we don’t know, ‘but we think’.”  Use this as an opportunity to learn something new with @fields.child_nickname. The WHO and UNICEF websites are great first steps to learn.
text: Go siame go re “Ga re itse, fela re batlana le yona; kgotsa ga re itse, ‘fela re akanya’.”  Dirisa eno jaaka tshono go ithuta sengwe se seswa le 1 Diweposaete tsa WHO le UNICEFke dikgato tse dintle tsa ntlha tsa go simolola go ithuta.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: It is fine to say “We don’t know, but we are working on it; or we don’t know, ‘but we think’.”  Use this as an opportunity to learn something new with your child. The WHO and UNICEF websites are great first steps to learn.
text: Go siame go re “Ga re itse, fela re batlana le yona; kgotsa ga re itse, ‘fela re akanya’.”  Dirisa tshono eno go ithuta sengwe se seswa mmogo le ngwana wa gago. Diweposaete tsa WHO le UNICEFke dikgato tse dintle tsa ntlha tsa go simolola go ithuta.

text: Bolelela ngwana wa gago gore re kgona go akanyetsa batho ba ba lwalang le bao ba ba tlhokomelang.

text: Ke tlhaloganya gore nako eno e na le kgwetlho ota.  Ka kopo tlanya “thusa” fa o batla tshegetso kgotsa kaelo e nngwe. Ke tla bua le wena moragonyana!

SourceText: Sometimes we feel frustrated with our children because we expect them to behave in ways that they are not yet developmentally ready for.
text: Nakko dingwe re ikutlwa re tlalalane ke bana ba rona gonne re lebeletse gore ba itshole ka mokgwa o ba iseng ba o diamele.

SourceText: Learning about child development means we can have realistic expectations and also to spot any problems with their growth and development.
text: Go ithuta kaga tlhabololo ya bana go kaya gore re kgona go nna le ditebelelo tse di kgonegang mme re kgone go bona mathata mangwe le mangwe go kgolo le tlhabololo ya bona.

SourceText: All children develop at different rates. Here's a video to help you understand what to expect from your children.
text: Bana botlhe ba tlhaloboga ka dikelo tse di farologaneng. Fano ke bidiyo go go thusa go tlhaloganya gore o lebelele eng go tswa go bana ba gago.

SourceText: All children develop at different rates. Here's an audio message to help you understand what to expect from your children.
text: Bana botlhe ba tlhaloboga ka dikelo tse di farologaneng. Fano ke odiyo go go thusa go tlhaloganya gore o lebelele eng go tswa go bana ba gago.

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about child development.
text: Ga se bothata! Gape o ka tlanya “Thuso” ka gale fa o batla go ithuta go le gontsi ka ga tlhbololo ya ngwana wa gago.

SourceText: All children develop at different rates. But there are some things that we expect children to be able to do at an age. These are called ‘development’ milestones.
text: Bana botlhe ba tlhaloboga ka dikelo tse di farologaneng. Fela gona le dilo dingwe tse re lebeletseng gore bana ba rona ka kgone go di dira ka dingwaga dingwe le dingwe. Tseno di bidiwa diphitlhelelo tsa “tlhabologo’.

SourceText: Many things affect our children's development. For example, development is helped by eating healthy food, having immunisations, and parents or caregivers who talk to them a lot.
text: Dilo di le dintsi di ama tlhabololo ya bana ba rona. Sekao, tlhabololo e thusiwa ke go ja dijo tse di itekanetseng, go enta, le batsadi kgotsa batlhokomedi ba bua thata le bona.

SourceText: Which child development milestones do you want to learn about?
text: Ke phitlhelelo efe ya tlhabololo ya bana e o ratang go ithuta ka ga yona?

SourceText: Sorry I don't understand what you mean.
text: Intshwarele, ga ke go tlhaloganye.

SourceText: Young children have similar needs as toddlers.  Here's an audio message to help you understand your child's developmental needs better.
text: Ditlhoko tsa bana ba bannye di tshwana fela le tsa bo mapimpana.  Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo go go thusa go tlhaloganyatlabologo ya bana botoka.

SourceText: Babies from 0 to 1 year need lots of play and attention. Here's a video to help you understand your child's developmental needs better.
text: Masea go tlhoga go ngwana o le 0 go ya go o le 1 a tlhoka go elwatlhoko go thata. Fano ke molaetsa wa bidiyo go go thusa go tlhaloganyatlabologo ya bana botoka.

SourceText: Babies from 0 to 1 year need lots of play and attention. Here's an audio message to help you understand your child's developmental needs better.
text: Masea go tlhoga go ngwana o le 0 go ya go o le 1 a tlhoka go elwatlhoko go thata. Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo go go thusa go tlhaloganyatlabologo ya bana botoka.

SourceText: Young children have similar needs as toddlers.  Here's a video to help you understand your child's developmental needs better.
text: Ditlhoko tsa bana ba bannye di tshwana fela le tsa bo mapimpana.  Fano ke molaetsa wa bidiyo go go thusa go tlhaloganyatlabologo ya bana botoka.

SourceText: Young children (4-6 years):
text: Bana ba bannye (dingwaga 4-6):

SourceText: • Same as toddlers, but also...
text: Go tshwana fela le bomapimpna, fela gape...

SourceText: • Learn through actions and play.
text: Ithuta ka tiragaltso le motshameko.

SourceText: • Develop friendships with other children
text: Aga botsalano le bana ba bangwe

SourceText: • Find it difficult to separate make-believe from reality. Still express feelings in dramatic ways!
text: Itemogela bothata go kgaoganya nnete go noolwane. Ba santse ba tlhagisa maikutlo ka mokgwa wa terama!

SourceText: Young teenagers (10-12 years)
text: Mosha ba bannye (dingwaga 10-12)

SourceText: • More interested in learning in school.
text: Ba kgatlhegela go ithuta kwa dikolong.

SourceText: • Start to want independence and trust.
text: Simolola go batla boikemelo le tshepo.

SourceText: • Want to spend time with other children and young teenagers.
text: Ba batla go nna le nako le bana ba bangwe le baswa ba bannye.

SourceText: • May be interested in religion or spirituality
text: Ba nna le kgatlhego go tumelo kgotsa tsa semowa

SourceText: • May answer back to adults to show that they “know”.
text: Ba ka ikarabisetsa go bagolo go bontsha gore ba a ‘itse”.

SourceText: • Can be very self-conscious and sensitive
text: Ba ikelatlhoko mme ba bosisi

SourceText: • Can learn to better manage anger and tolerate frustration.
text: Ba kgona go ithuta go laola kgalefo botoka le go emelana le ketsaetsego.

SourceText: Infant (0–1 year) needs:
text: Ditlhoko tsa masea (dingwaga 0-1):

SourceText: • Us to provide food, sleep, cleaning, comfort and safety.
text: Re ba neela dijo, re a ba robatsa, tlhapisa, ritibatsa le go ba sireletsa.

SourceText: • A strong bond with parent/ caregiver.
text: Kamano e e matla le motsadi/motlhokomedi.

SourceText: • Lots of play and attention - the most active time of brain development is during the first 1000 days of life!
text: Motshameko ka bontsi le go elwatlhoko - ke nako eo boboko bo leng mo tlhabologong e e matlhagatlhaga tota mo pakeng ya malatsi a ntlha a le 1000 a matshelo a bona!

SourceText: Middle teenagers (13-14 years)
text: Mosha ba magareng (dingwaga 13-14)

SourceText: • Begin to challenge adult rules
text: Simolola go mekamekana le melao ya bagolo

SourceText: • Are often insecure and confused.
text: Gantse ba tlhakatlhakane mme ga ba itshepe

SourceText: • Feelings get hurt easily and have mood swings
text: Maikutlo a kgopisega bonolo mme a fetogafetoga fela

SourceText: • Try to be the boss and are unhappy if they lose.
text: Leka go nna moeteledipele mme ga a itumelele go latlhegelwa.

SourceText: Infants (0-1):
text: Masea (0-1)

SourceText: • 0–6 months: Smile, babble and cry to attract your attention. We should provide care, cuddling and protection.
text: dikgwedi di le 0-6 Nyeba, dira dibudula le go lela gore a elwetlhoko. Re tshwanetse go neelana ka tlhokomelo, re ngaparelane le go sireletsana.

SourceText: • 6–11 months: Cling to you, especially when feeling insecure or frightened.
text: dikgwedi di le 6-11 Ikgomarela mo go wena, segolo fa a ikutlwa a sa sireletsega kgotsa a tshogile.

SourceText: • 12–23 months: Start to walk, talk and explore things around them!
text: dikgwedi di le 12-23 Simolola go tsamaya le go utlola dilo tse di mo dikologileng!

SourceText: • Their friends are important and affect their choices
text: Ditsala tsa bona di botlhokwa mme di na le seabe go dikgetho tsa bona

SourceText: • Need some freedom but also reliable rules that don't change
text: Tlhoka kgololosego nngwegape ba tlhoka melao e e ikanngwang e sa fetoge

SourceText: • Need affection, reassurance, self-esteem, encouragement to believe in their abilities
text: Tlhoka lerato, netefaletso, boitshepo, thotloetso go dumela go bokgoni jwa bona

SourceText: Toddlers (2-3 years):
text: Bomappimpana(dingwaga di le 2-3):

SourceText: • Become a curious little explorer - watch out for climbing!
text: E nna bautolodi ba bannye ba ba nang le phisego - ela tlhoko go a palamiwa!

SourceText: • Learn through play and trying things out
text: Ba ithuta ka motshameko le go lekeletsa

SourceText: • Want to learn how to do new things (like getting dressed) and make their own decisions.
text: Ba batla go ithuta go dira dilo tse diswa (jaaka go ikapesa) le go itseela ditshwetso.

SourceText: • Want your praise and your approval
text: Ba batla gore o ba akgole le go ba amogela

SourceText: • May talk a lot; ask many questions. We should be honest when we reply! Our child may ask again if they don't understand or want to know more
text: Ba ka bua thata; ba botsa dipotso tse dintsi. Re tshwanetse go nna le boammaruri fa re araba! Bana ba rona ba ka botsa gape fa ba sa tlhaloganye kgotsa ba rata go itse go feta

SourceText: • Does not like to lose, share or take turns, but losing and taking turns can be taught.
text: Ga ba rate go fenngwa, go arolelanela le go refosanela, fela o ka ba ruta go refosanela le go amogela phenyo.

SourceText: Older teenagers (15–19 years)
text: Mosha ba bagolwane (dingwaga 15-19)

SourceText: • The teen years are the second most active time of brain development!
text: Dingwaga tsa bosha ke paka ya bobedi eo boboko bo leng matlhagatlhaga ka tlhabologo!

SourceText: • Your child is almost an adult, they are able to communicate with you about
text: Ngwana wa gago o gaufi le go nna mogolo, mme o kgona go tlotla le wena ka ga

SourceText: almost anything.
text: sengwe le sengwe.

SourceText: • They can think about new ideas, develop their own ideals and set their own course.
text: Ba kgona go akanya dikakanyo tse diswa, go ikagela se ba se batlang le go ipeela maikaelelo.

SourceText: • Start speaking in sentences and  learning new words.
text: Simolola go bua ka dipolelo le go ithuta mafoko a maswa.

SourceText: • Does not like to lose or take turns, but sharing can be taught.
text: Ga ba rate go fenngwa kgotsa go refosanelwa, fela ba ka rutiwa go arolelanela.

SourceText: • May express feelings in dramatic ways (like screaming on the floor!). Can start to learn how to manage their feelings.
text: Ba ka tlhagisa maikutlo ka mokgwa wa terama (jaaka go goeletsa fa fatshe1). Kgona go simolola go ithuta gore ba laole jang maikutlo a bona.

SourceText: Older children (7-9 years)
text: Bana ba bagolwane (dingwaga 7-9):

SourceText: • Same early childhood, but also…
text: Bongwana jwa pejana jo bo tshwanang, mme gape...

SourceText: • Interested in learning at school.
text: Ba kgatlhegela go ithuta kwa dikolong.

SourceText: • Starts to want independence and trust.
text: Simolola go batla boikemelo le tshepo.

SourceText: • Wants to spend time with other children.
text: Batla go nna le nako le bana ba bangwe.

SourceText: • They are forming their own identity and have a growing sense of their
text: Ba itlhamela boitshupho jwa bona mme ba nna le tlhaloganyo ya

SourceText: sexuality
text: bong jwa bona

SourceText: • They may prefer being with peers more than with you
text: Ba ka rata go nna le balekanemmogo ka dingwana go feta go nna le wena

SourceText: • They may show risk-taking behaviours, frequent mood swings, and rebellious
text: Ba ka tlhagisa maitsholo a a nang le matshosetsi, phetophetogo ya maikutlo kgapetsakgapfetsa, mme ba nna nkane

SourceText: attitudes. They can also have exciting new ideas!
text: a nna le bobona Ba ka nna gape le dikakanyo tse diswa tse di itumedisang!

SourceText: • May start to ask questions about religion
text: Ba ka simolola go botsa dipotso ka ga sedumedi

SourceText: • Can be very self-conscious and sensitive. May be very active. By now they should be getting better at managing anger and frustration.
text: Ba kgona go ikela tlhoko le go kgopisega ka bonako.Ba ikelatlhoko mme ba bosisi Ba ka nna matlhagatlhaga. JGajaana ba tshwanetse go bo ba nna botoka mo go laoleng kgalefo le ketsaetsego.

SourceText: • Be patient and accepting of the person they are becoming - even if it is not what you had imagined
text: Nna pelotelele mme o amogele motho yo ba nnang ene 0- le fa e se se o neng o se akantse

SourceText: • Encourage them to begin to take responsibility for the future
text: Ba rotloetse go simolola go rwama maikarabelo a isago

SourceText: • Keep supporting them and loving them so that they feel comfortable, secure, and safe
text: Tswelela go ba tshegetsa le go ba rata gore ba ikutlwe ba phuthologile, sireletsegile mme ba itshepha
