SourceText: All children, including those living with disabilities, need love, respect and time especially at difficult times.
text: Bana botlhe, go tsenyeletsa le ba ba tshelang ka bogole, ba tlhoka lerato, tlhompho le nako segolo mo dinako tse di bokete.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you support children living with disabilities.
text: Fano ke bidiyo go go thusa go tshegetsa bana ba ba tshelang ka bogole.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you support children living with disabilities.
text: Fano ke bidiyo go go thusa go tshegetsa bana ba ba tshelang ka bogole.

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about how to support children living with disabilities.
text: Ga se bothata! Ka gale o ka tlanya “Thuso” fa o batla go ithuta go le gontsi ka ga go tshegetsa bana ba ba tshelang ka bogole.

SourceText: Here are 6 simple tips that you can do to support children living with disabilities:
text: Fano ke dikakantsho tse di bonolo di le 6 go go thusa go tshegetsa bana ba ba tshelang ka bogole:

SourceText: 1. Keep your child safe and well
text: 1. Tshola ngwana wa gago a sireletsegile mme a tsogile sentle

SourceText: 2. Try to understand what they are feeling
text: 2. Leka go tlhaloganya maikutlo a bona

SourceText: 3. Communicate and talk with them
text: 3. Buisana le bua le bona

SourceText: 4. Praise them!
text: 4. Ba akgole!

SourceText: 5. Make things that you do the same every day to help them feel secure
text: 5. Tlhama dilo tse le tla dirang ka go tshwana letsatsi le letsatsi go ba thusa go ikutlwa ba bolokesegile

SourceText: 6. Ask for help if you can
text: 6. Kopa thuso fa go kgonega

SourceText: Type "1" to "6" to learn more about each tip. Type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Go ithuta go le gontsi ka nngwe le nngwe ya dikakantsho tse, tlanya “1” go ya go “6”. Tlanya “N” go emisa kakantsho e.

SourceText: Step 4. Praise them!
text: Kgato 4. Ba akgole!

SourceText: • Praise them for behaving well, and for trying.
text: Ba akgolele go itshola sentle, le go leka

SourceText: • Focus on what they can do, not what they can't.
text: Tsepama mo go tse ba kgonang go di dira e seng tse di ba palelang.

SourceText: • Only help children when they need it. It is also good to build independence!
text: Thusa bana fela fa ba e tlhoka Gape go botlhokwa go aga boikemeli jwa bona

SourceText: Step 6. Ask for help if you can
text: Kgato 6: Kopa thuso fa go kgonega

SourceText: • Share the load with other adult family members.
text: Arolelanela mokgweleo le bagolo ba bangwe ba maloko a lelapa.

SourceText: •  You are not alone! Keep connected with people who understand your situation.
text: Ga o esi! Tswelela go golagana le batho ba ba tlhaloganyang mathata a gago.

SourceText: Here is a comic on how you can reinforce your child's strength.
text: Fano ke khomiki ka ga gore o ka agelela jang matla a ngwana wa gago.

SourceText: • Share your challenges AND your successes.
text: Arolelanela dikgwetlho LE dikatlego tsa gago.

SourceText: • It is normal to feel stressed, frustrated, and afraid at this time.
text: Go tlwaelegile go ikutlwa o imetswe, o etsaetsega, e bile  o tshaba mo nakong e.

SourceText: • Be kind to yourself and take a break when you need to!
text: Ineneketse mme o eme go se kae fa go tlhokega!

text: Ngwana: "la la la la…."

SourceText: Step 1. Keep your child safe and well
text: Kgato 1. Tshola ngwana wa gago a sireletsegile mme a tsogile sentle

SourceText: • Keep your country's COVID-19 rules, and also help @fields.child_nickname_disabled to be active - do whatever exercise you can with them inside or outside your home
text: Latela melao ya COVID-19ya naga ya gago, gape itshole 1 go nna matlhagatlhaga - dita ikatiso nngwe le nngwe fela mmogo le bona ka ntlong kgotsa kwa ntle

SourceText: • Keep emergency contact numbers somewhere easy to see
text: Baya dinomoro tsa tshoganyetso gongwe felafa goleng bonolo gore di bonale

SourceText: • Keep your country's COVID-19 rules, and also help your child to be active - do whatever exercise you can with them inside or outside your home
text: Latela melao ya COVID-19ya naga ya gago, gape itshole 1 go nna matlhagatlhaga - dita ikatiso nngwe le nngwe fela mmogo le bona ka ntlong kgotsa kwa ntle

SourceText: Step 5. Make daily plans to help them feel secure
text: Kgato 5. Tlhama dithulaganyo tsa letsatsi go ba thusa go ikutlwa ba sireletsegile

SourceText: • Having things that are the same each day helps children feel secure and safe.
text: Go nna le dilo tse di tshwanang letsatsi le letsatsi go tla thusa bana go ikutlwa ba sireletsegile le go bolokega

SourceText: • Make a daily plan that includes some things they like to do.
text: Dira dithulaganyo tsa letsatsi tse di tsenyeletsang dilo dingwe tse ba di ratang.

SourceText: • Help @fields.child_nickname_disabled connect to friends and family members through phone, writing cards, or drawing pictures.
text: Thusa 1 go golagana le ditsala le balelapa ka mogala, go remola dikarata, kgotsa go thala ditshwantsho.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: • Help your child connect to friends and family members through phone, writing cards, or drawing pictures.
text: Thusa ngwana wa gago go golagana le ditsala le balelapa ka mogala, go remola dikarata, kgotsa go thala ditshwantsho.

SourceText: Step 2. Try to understand how they are feeling
text: Kgato 2. Leka go tlhaloganya maikutlo a bona

SourceText: • @fields.child_nickname_disabled may be feeling a lot of stress, anxiety, and frustration.
text: 1 a ka ikutlwa a imetswe tota, a etsaetsega le go tlaalana.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: • Tell them that you love them
text: Mmpolele gore o a mo rata

SourceText: • Praise them for being good and for trying to be good!
text: Ba akgolele go bo ba siame le go leka go siama!

SourceText: • Your child may be feeling a lot of stress, anxiety, and frustration.
text: Ngwana wa gago a ka ikutlwa a imetswe tota, a etsaetsega le go tlaalana.

SourceText: • Give @fields.child_nickname_disabled choices: this gives them a sense of control and builds self-esteem.
text: Naya 1 dikhetho: seno se mo neela maikutlo a taolo le go aga go itshepa.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: • Use simple language and clear instructions. If words aren't good for them, try gestures and pictures.
text: Dirisa puo e e bonolo le ditaelo tse di tlhaloganyegang. Fa tiriso ya mafoko e se ntle go bona, leka go bua ka diatla le ditshwantsho.

SourceText: • Give your child choices: this gives them a sense of control and builds self-esteem.
text: Naya 1 dikhetho: seno se mo neela maikutlo a taolo le go aga go itshepa.

SourceText: Step 3. Talking and communicating with your child
text: Kgato 3. Buisana le bua le ngwana wa gago

SourceText: • Get down to @fields.child_nickname_disabled’s level when you speak.
text: Theogela go maemo a 1 fa o bua.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: • Look at them and smile
text: Mo lebe mme o nyebe

SourceText: • Give them time to tell you or show you what they think
text: Mo neele nako go go bolelela kgotsa go go bontsha gore o akanya eng

SourceText: • Tell @fields.child_nickname_disabled that you understand
text: Bolelea 1 gore o a tlhaloganya
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: • Get down to your child’s level when you speak.
text: Theogela go maemo a ngwana wa gago  fa o bua.

SourceText: • Tell your child that you understand
text: Bolelela ngwana wa gago gore o a tlhaloganya

SourceText: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Children living with disabilities need love, respect and time – just like any other child.

SourceText: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support.  You can also change the type of messages you receive for an older or younger child. Just select "Technical Support". Chat to you later!
text: Gopola go tlanya “Thusa” fa o ka tlhoka dikakantsho tse dingwe tsa botsadi kgotsa thuso nngwe.  Gape o ka fetola mofuta wa melaetsa o o amogelelang ngwana wa gago yo mogolwane kgotsa yo monnye. tlhopha fela “Tshegetso ya setegeniki”. Ke tla bua le wena moragonyana!

SourceText: Hello! Today we are going to learn what we can do when our children are already misbehaving or have already misbehaved…
text: Dumela! gompieno re tlile go ithuta gore re ka dirang fa bana ba rona ba setse ba sa itshole sentle kgotsa ba setse ba paetswe ke maitsholo a a siameng...

SourceText: Use consequences for refusing to follow instructions or forgetting household rules. Consequences help teach our children responsibility for what they do. They also allow discipline that is controlled. This is more effective than hitting or shouting.
text: Dirisa ditlamorago tsa go gana go latela ditaelo kgotsa go lebala melao ya ga lapeng. Go tlhalosa ditlamorago o ritibetse maikutlo go thusa bana ba rona gore ba bone gore ba tla rwala maikarabelo a se ba se dirang. Gape di letla kgalemo e e laolwang. Seno se nonofile go feta go itaya kgotsa go omanya.

SourceText: Children and teens often act disrespectfully or like they only care about themselves. Growing up is a difficult time when they are learning about who they are and how they want to be in the world. Luckily, there are other ways to discipline your teen without using violence…and they work well!
text: Bana ba kgona go dira o jaaka o ka re ga ba maitseo kgotsa ba ikgathalela ba le nosi fela. Nako ya fa ba gola ke nako e e thata ya fa ba leka go ithuta gore ke bomang le gore ba batla go nna jang mo lefatsheng. Ka lesego, go na le ditsela tsa go otlhaya ngwana wa gago wa dingwaga tsa bosha o sa tenega kgotsa o sa dirise dikgoka... e bile ditsela tseno di bereka sentle!

SourceText: Giving calm consequences help teach our children responsibility for what they do. They also allow discipline that is controlled. This is more effective than hitting or shouting.
text: Go tlhalosa ditlamorago o ritibetse maikutlo go thusa bana ba rona gore ba bone gore ba tla rwala maikarabelo a se ba se dirang. Gape di letla kgalemo e e laolwang. Seno se nonofile go feta go itaya kgotsa go omanya.

SourceText: Here are 5 tips for using consequences:
text: Fano ke dikakantsho di le 5 go dirisa ditlamorago:

SourceText: 1. Give a choice before consequence
text: 1. Neelana ka kgetho pele ga ditlamorago

SourceText: 2. Stay calm but be firm
text: 2. Ritibala mme o tsepame

SourceText: 3. Be realistic and follow through
text: 3. Dumelesega mme o latele

SourceText: 4. Reconnect afterwards
text: 4. Ikgolaganyegape morago

SourceText: 5. Consequences for breaking rules
text: 5. Ditlamorago pele o roba melao

SourceText: To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "5". You can also type "N" to move on.
text: Go ithuta go le gontsi ka nngwe ya dikakantsho tse, tlanya “1” go ya go “5”. Gape o ka tlanya “N”go tswelelapele.

SourceText: Consequences can also be used when your children forget a household rule, like going to bed at a certain hour or doing schoolwork before T.V.
text: Ditlamorago di kgona go dirisiwa fa bana ba lebala molao wa fa lapeng, jaaka go ya go robala ka ura e e rileng kgotsa go dira tiro ya sekolo pele ga TV

SourceText: 2. Try to stay calm but firm when giving the consequence.
text: 2. Leka go ritibala mme o tsepame fa o neelana ka ditlamorago.

SourceText: If you start yelling, it will just make things worse. Take a deep breath before you speak in a clear, calm, and firm voice.
text: Fa o simolola go omana, seno se tla etegetsa dilo fela. Hemea kwa teng pele o bua ka etswe le le tlhapileng, le ritibetse, mme le tsepame.

SourceText: Make sure you can follow through with the consequence. For example, taking away a teenager’s phone for a week is hard to enforce. Taking it away for one hour is more realistic.
text: Ke lebetse go latelela ditlamorago. Sekao, go tseela mosha founu beke go thata go go tsenya tirisong. Go e tsaya ura e le nngwe go a kgonega.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about using consequences:
text: Ka kopo tlhopha nomoro e nngwe fa o batla go ithuta go feta ka ga go ipha nako ya motho ka mong le ngwana wa gago:

SourceText: Here is a comic that shows a parent giving their child a choice to follow the instruction or receive a consequence.
text: Fano ke khomiki e e bontshang motsadi a neela ngwana kgetho go latela taelo kgotsa go amogela ditlamorago.

SourceText: Parent: “In 5 minutes it will be time to give me back the phone and start your school work.”
text: Motsadi: “KE tla bo e le nako ya go nnela founu mme o simolole ka tiro ya gago ya sekolo mo metsotsong e le 5.”

SourceText: Teen (distractedly): “Uh-huh…”
text: Mosha (a sa go tseetsia): “Uh-huh…”

SourceText: Parent: “5 minutes is up. Please give me the phone.”
text: Motsadi: “metsotso e 5 e fetile. Ke kopa o nnele founu.”

SourceText: Teen: “No, I am not done. I just need to get to the next level.”
text: * “Mosha”: “Nnyaa, ga ke ise ke fetse. Ke tlhoka fela go ya kwa boalong jo bo latelang.”

SourceText: Parent: “You have a choice, either you give me the phone now, or you cannot use it after dinner.”
text: Motsadi: “O na le kgetho, o ka nnela founu gona jaanon, kgotsa o ka se e dirise morago ga dijo.”

SourceText: Teen (not happy but agreeing): “Fine.”
text: Mosha (ga a itumela fela o a dumela): “Go siame.”

SourceText: Parent: “Thank you for giving me the phone back, Carter. Now please do your school work. After that we can take a walk or play a game together.”
text: Motsadi: “Ke lebogela founu, Carter. Jaanong ke kopa o tswelele ka tiro ya sekolo. Morago re ka tsamayatsamaya kgotsa ra tshameka mmogo.”

SourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! When your child is behaving badly, try responding in a calm way with a fair consequence. Go tla mo thusa go ithuta gore dikgato tsa gagwe di nna le seabe go ene le go ba bangwe. Gape go tla mo ruta go rwala maikarabelo le go nna le tlhompho!

SourceText: Today's Tip is about how we can support our teens when they experience really difficult situations.
text: Kakantsho ya gompieno e ka ga gore re ka tshegetsa jang basha ba rona fa ba itemogela maemo a a boima tota.

SourceText: When our children share difficult experiences with us, we may initially get angry because we are afraid for them. But that is when we need to stay calm, listen, and be open.
text: Fa bana ba rona ba arolelanela maitemogelo a a boima le rona, kwa tshimologong re ka galefa gonne re nna le poifo boemong jwa bona. Fela ke nako e re tshwanelang go n=ritibala, re reetse, mme re phuthologe.

SourceText: Do you want some tips that can help you respond in a more supportive way?
text: A o batla dikakantsho dingwe tse di ka go thusang go arabela ka mokgwa o o bontshang tshegetso?

SourceText: When our children share something that is especially troubling, we need to remember to stay calm, listen, and be open.
text: Fa bana ba rona ba arolelanela le rona sengwe se se tshwenyang, re tlhoka go gopola go ritibala, go reetsa le go phuthologa.

SourceText: Here's a video on how you can support your teen when they are experiencing difficult situations.
text: Fano ke bidiyo gore o kgona go tshegetsa jang mosha wa gago fa a itemogela maemo a a boima.

SourceText: Here's an audio message on how you can support your teen when they are experiencing difficult situations.
text: Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo gore o kgona go tshegetsa jang mosha wa gago fa a itemogela maemo a a boima.

SourceText: Here are some things you can do when your teen shares something difficult with you:
text: Fano ke dingwe tsa dilo tse o ka di dirang fa mosha wa gago a arolelanela le wena sengwe se se boima:

SourceText: • Take a deep breath before you respond.
text: Hemela kwa teng pele o araba.

SourceText: • Listen to what your child is saying. Notice how they are feeling.
text: Reetsa se ngwana wa gago a se buang. Elatlhoko gore ba ikutlwa jang.

SourceText: • Notice how you feel. Ask yourself, "What does my child need right now?"
text: Lemoga kafa o ikutlwang ka gone Ipotse gore, ‘ke eng se ngwana wa me a se tlhokang gone jaanong’

SourceText: • Reassure your child that you are there for them.
text: Netefaletsa ngwana wa gago gore o gona go mo thusa.

SourceText: • You can deal with the consequences later but right now your child needs you.
text: O tla mekamekana le ditlamorago moragonyana fela gajaana ngwana wa gago o a go tlhoka.

SourceText: • Discuss possible solutions or next steps to take action.
text: tlotang ka ditharabololo tse di kgonegang kgotsa dikgato tse di latelang di tla tsewang.

SourceText: • Remind your child again that you love them and thank them for sharing with you.
text: Gopotsa ngwana wa gago gore o a mo rata mme o mo lebogele go arolelanela le wena.

SourceText: We understand that this can be really difficult. Please type "Help" if you want any extra support or guidance.
text: Re tlhaloganya gore nako eno e na le kgwetlho ota. Ka kopo tlanya “thusa” fa o batla tshegetso kgotsa kaelo e nngwe.

SourceText: Here is a comic that shows how you can support your child during a crisis.
text: Fano ke khomiki go go bontsha gore o ka tshegetsa jang ngwana wa gago mo mathateng.

SourceText: Parent: “What’s wrong, my dear? Come and sit by me and tell me what happened.”
text: Motsadi: “Bothata ke eng moratiwa? Tla o nne fa thoko ga me mme o mpolelele gore go diragetseng.”

SourceText: Child: “It’s that person…they touched me…”
text: Ngwana: “Ke motho yole...o ntshwaratshwere...”

SourceText: Parent: “Take your time... I am listening.”
text: Motsadi: “Tsaya nako ya gago...” Ke reeditse.”“Tswelela, ke go reeditse.

SourceText: Child: “… they held me down…told me I would be in trouble if I told anybody…”
text: Ngwana: “...o ne a nkgatheletse...a mpolelela gore ke tla tsena mo mathateng fa nka bolelela mongwe...”

SourceText: Parent: “I believe you. You are not in trouble. It is not your fault. This is a big thing and we will find a way to get the help you need. I wonder where we can go for help…?”
text: Motsadi: “Ke a go dumela. O ka se tsene mo mathateng. Ga se phoso ya gago.” Kgang eno e masisi tota mme re tlile go batla thuso e re e tlhokang. Ke ipotsa gore re ka boa thuso kae...?”

SourceText: Child: “The clinic? But could you come with me?”
text: Ngwana: “Tleliniki? Fela a o tla tla le nna?”

SourceText: Parent: “Yes, they will know what to do. Of course, I will come with you. Remember, this is not your fault. I love you and we will get through this.”
text: Motsadi: “Ee, ba tla itse gore ba re thusa jang. Sentlenyane, ke tlaya le wena. Gopola gore seno ga se phoso ya gago. Ke a go rata mme re tla bona thuso.

SourceText: Child: “Thanks so much.”
text: Ngwana: Ke leboga go menagane!

SourceText: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support.
text: Gopola go tlanya “Thusa” fa o ka tlhoka dikakantsho tse dingwe tsa botsadi kgotsa thuso nngwe.

SourceText: When we are able to have peaceful and loving relationships, our children feel more secure and loved. Kindness and taking care of yourself help.
text: Fa re kgona go aga dikamano tse di nang le kagiso le lerato, bana ba rona ba ikutlwa ba sireletsegile le go ratiwa. Go ineneketsa le go itlhokomela go a thusa.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you support positive family relationships at home.
text: Fano ke bidiyo go go thusa go tshegetsa dikamano tse di siameng tsa lelapa fa gae.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you support positive family relationships at home.
text: Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo go go thusa go tshegetsa dikamano tse di siameng tsa lelapa fa gae.

SourceText: Here are 6 simple steps that you can do to support family harmony at home:
text: Fano ke dikgato tse di bonolo di le 6 tse o ka di tsayang go tshegetsa boitumelo jwa balelapa fa gae.

SourceText: 1. Be a model of behaviour for your kids
text: 1. Nna sekao sa maitsholo go bana ba gago

SourceText: 2. Keep it positive
text: 2. Nna le tshepo

SourceText: 3. Listen carefully to others
text: 3. Reetsa ba bangwe sentle

SourceText: 4. Share the load
text: 4. Arolelanelang mokgweleo

SourceText: 5. Take care of yourself
text: 5. Itlhokomele

SourceText: 6. Do nice things together as a family.
text: 6. Dirang dilo tse dintle mmogo jaaka lelapa.

SourceText: Type "1" to 6" to learn more about these tips. Type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Go ithuta go le gontsi ka nngwe ya dikakantsho tse, tlanya “1” go ya go “6”. Tlanya “N” go emisa kakantsho e.

SourceText: Step 4. Share the load
text: Kgato 4. Arolelanelang mokgweleo

SourceText: Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared. Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members
text: Go tlhokola bana le maloko a mangwe a lelapa go bokete, fela go bonolo tota fa re arolelanela maikarabelo. Lekang go arolelanela ditiro tsa ka fa gae, go tlhokomela bana, le ditiro tse dingwe ka go lekana magareng ga maloko a lelapa.

SourceText: Step 5. Take care of yourself
text: Kgato 5. Itlhokomele

SourceText: Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household. It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break
text: tlhamang shejule ka nako “teng” ke nako ya “ga ke yo” le bagolo ba bangwe mo lelapeng la gago Go siame go kopa thuso fa o ikutlwa o lapile kgotsa o imetswe gore o kgone go ikhutsa.

SourceText: Step 6. Do nice things together as a family
text: Kgato 6: Dirang dilo tse dintle mmogo jaaka lelapa.

SourceText: Let each family member take turns choosing a whole family activity. Find ways to spend time alone with other adults in your home, too!
text: Letla leloko lengwe le lengwe la lelapa go refosanela go tlhopha tirwana ya balelapa. Batla mekgwa ya go nna le nako o le nosi le bagolo ba bangwe mo ntlong ya gago!

SourceText: Step 1. Be a model of behaviour for your kids
text: Kgato 1. Nna sekao sa maitsholo go bana ba gago

SourceText: How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too! Try to talk kindly to everyone in the family, adults and children.
text: Gore re bua le go itshola jang ke tshusumetso e kgolo mo go reng bana ba rona ba itshole jang le bona! Leka go bua sentle go botlhe mo lelapeng, bagolo le bana.

SourceText: Step 2. Use positive language. It works!
text: Kgato 2. Dirisa puo e e siameng. go a thusa

SourceText: Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”
text: Bolelela ba bangwe gore o batla ba dire eng gona le go ba bolelela se o sa batleng ba se dira: Gona le le gore “Tlogelang go tlhodia,” leka “Ke kopa le buele kwa tlase”

SourceText: Decide to take a break from arguing when you see arguments building up, and go into another room or outside if you can.
text: Swetsa go ema go se kae fa o lemoga gore dikgaruu di a simolola, mme o tsene go phaposi e nngwe kgotsa o tswele kwa ntle fa go kgonega.

SourceText: You can always type "Help" if you need an activity to help you with stress.
text: Gopola ka gale gore o kgona go tlanya “Thuso” nako nngwe le nngwe fa o tlhoka tirwana go ithusa go repa.

SourceText: Praise others to make them feel appreciated and good about themselves. Simple words like, “Thank you for clearing the dinner,” or “Thank you for watching the baby” can make a big difference
text: Akgola ba bangwe go dira gore ba ikutlwe ba ananeelwa mme ba ipela. Mafoko a a bonolo jaaka, “Ke lebogela go bo o feditse dijo tsa gago,” kgotsa “Ke lebogela go bo o tlhokometse ngwana” a ka tlhola pharologanyo e kgolo

SourceText: Bad communication between adults in the household can have a negative impact on our children. The more we practice modeling peaceful, loving relationships for our children, the more secure and loved they will feel.
text: lthaeletsano e e bosula magareng ga bagolo fa lapeng e ka tlhoka seabe se se maswe go bana ba rona. Fa re tsweletse go bontsha dimkamano tse di nang le kagiso le lerato go bana ba rona, ba tla tswelela go ikutlwa ba sireletsegile le go ratiwa.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to support family harmony at home:
text: Ka kopo tlhopha nomoro e nngwe fa o batla go ithuta go feta ka ga go tsweletsa boitumelo jwa balelapa fa gae:

SourceText: Step 3. Be a great listener
text: Kgato 3. Reetsa sentle.

SourceText: Listen to others when they are talking with you. Be open and show them that you hear what they are saying. It can help to summarise what you have heard before responding: “What I hear you saying is…”
text: Reetsa ba bangwe fa ba bua le wena. Phuthologa mme o ba bontshe gore o batla go utlwa gore ba a reng. Go ka thusa go sobokanya se o se utlwileng pele o araba: “Se ke utlwang o se bua ke...”.

SourceText: Well done for adding another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Over the next few days, try taking a deep breath or walking away for a bit when you start getting angry at someone. Every time you find a way to resolve conflicts in a peaceful way, you increase your child's brain development. Be proud of yourself when you do it!
text: O dirile bontle ka go tsenya kgono e le nngwe go Kaedi ya Botsadi beke eno! Mo malatsing a a mmalwa a a latelang, leka go hemela kwa teng kgotsa go tswa gose kae fa o ikutlwa go simolola go galefela mongwe. Nako le nako o bona mokgwa wa go rarabolola dikgotlhang ka tsela ya kagiso, o oketsa tlhalobololo ya boboko jwa ngwana wa gago. Itlotlomatse fa o kgona go dira jalo!

SourceText: Here are some tips that might help when your baby cries:
text: Fano ke dingwe tsa dikakantsho tse di ka thusang fa lesea la gago le lela

SourceText: 1. Why babies cry
text: 1. Fa lesea le lela

SourceText: 2. Respond as soon as you can
text: 2. arabela ka bonako jo o bo kgonang

SourceText: 3. Check to see why your baby is crying
text: 3. Lekola go bona gore goreng ba na le maitsholo a a sa siamang.

SourceText: 4. Comfort your baby
text: 4. Namatsha lesea la gago

SourceText: 5. Take a break if you need it
text: 5. Ema go se kae fa go tlhokega

SourceText: 6. Be gentle and patient with yourself
text: 6. Nna pelotelele le go ineneketsa

SourceText: 7. If you think your baby is injured or sick, call or visit a clinic
text: 7. Fa o akanya gore lesea la gago le gobetse kgotsa le a lwala, leletsa kgotsa o etele tleliniki

SourceText: To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "7". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Go ithuta go le gontsi ka nngwe ya dikakantsho tse, tlanya “1” go ya go “7”. Tlanya “N” go emisa kakantsho e.

SourceText: If your baby cries for a long time and does not stop, they might be injured or sick. You should seek medical help immediately.
text: Fa ngwana wa gago a lela sebaka se se telele mme a sa didimale, a ka tswa a gobetse kgotsa a lwala. O tshwanetse go batla thuso ya bongaka ka bonako.

SourceText: Go to your baby when you hear them crying. You will not spoil your baby by picking them up. Babies who are carried and cuddled frequently, during both fussy and contented periods, may actually cry less.
text: Eya go ngwana wa gago fa o mo utlwa a lela. Ga o senye ngwana ka go mo kuka Bana ba ba kukiwang le go tlamparelwa kgafetsa, ka nako ya matepe le fa ba ritibetse gantsi ba fetsa ba lela go le gonnye.

SourceText: 1. Why do babies cry?
text: 1. Goreng masea a lela

SourceText: Crying is a normal part of your baby's development. Sometimes babies even have crying patterns. Crying usually increases at 2-3 weeks old and is generally highest when your baby is around 6 to 8 weeks. Often babies will start crying less around 3 to 4 months. Of course, remember that every baby is different!
text: Go lela le karolo e e tlwaelgileng ya tlhabololo ya lesea la gago Nako dingwe masea a nna le dipaterone tsa go lela. Go lela ka gale go oketsega mo dibekeng di le 2-3 mme go tlhatlogela kwa godimo mo dibekeng di le 6-8. Gantsi masea a tla fokotsa go lela mo dikgweding di le 3 go ya go di le 4. Sentlenyane, gopola gore lesea lengwe le lengwe le farologane.

SourceText: 3.  Check to see why your baby is crying
text: 3.  Lekola go bona gore goreng ba na le maitsholo a a sa siamang.

SourceText: There are lots of reasons why babies cry. It might be hunger, pain, too much going on, rough handling, feeling cold/hot, wanting contact or attention, or feeling irritable. Babies can cry when they sense tension in the room. And sometimes they cry for no reason at all!
text: Gona le mabaka a le mantsi gore goreng masea a lela E ka nna tlala, setlhabi, go le gontsi go go diragalng, a tshotswe makgwakgwa, utlwa mogote/gatsela, a rata go kukiwa kgotsa go elwatlhoko, kgotsa a etsaetsega. Masea a kgona go lela fa gona le tsitsipano mo phaposing. Mme ka nako dingwe ba lela fela go sena lebaka!

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about what to do when your baby is crying:
text: Ka kopo tlhopha nomoro e nngwe fa o batla go ithuta go feta ka ga go se o ka se dirang fa lesea la gago le lela:

SourceText: Here is a comic on coping with a colicky baby
text: Fano ke khomiki ka ga gore o mekamekana jang le lesea le le bipetsweng

SourceText: Parent 1: "We should do something."
text: Motsadi 1: Re tshwanetse go dira sengwe.”

SourceText: Parent 2: "Okay, I'll try feeding them."
text: Motsadi” 2: “Go siame, ke tla leka go mo jesa.”

SourceText: Baby: "aaaaaaaa"
text: Lesea: “aaaaaaaa”

SourceText: Parent 1:  "What is wrong with them?"
text: Motsadi 1:  “Bothata ke eng?”

SourceText: Parent 2: "I don't know. It has been an hour and they are still crying. I cannot take it anymore. They are driving me crazy, I just want to shake them!"
text: Motsadi” 2: “Ga ke itse. Go setse go fetile ura mme o santse a lela. Ke utlwile jaanong. O a ntlhakatlhakanya, ke batla fela go mo tshikhinya!”

SourceText: Parent 2: "I can see that this has been a stressful night for you. How about you get some sleep while I take Frankie into the other room. I will try wrapping them up in a blanket."
text: Motsadi” 2: “Ke kgona go bona gore e nnile bosigo jo bo boima go wena. go ka nna jang fa nka tseela Frankie kwa phaposing e nngwe mme wena wa robala go se kae. Ke tla leka go mo phuthela ka kobo.”

SourceText: Parent 1: "Thank you. I was getting so angry at myself."
text: Motsadi 1: “Ke a leboga" Ke ne ke ke ikgalefetse.”

SourceText: Parent 1: "How did you manage to get them to sleep?"
text: Motsadi 1: “O kgonne jang go mo robatsa?”

SourceText: Parent 2: "I think they wore themselves out but we should take them to the clinic tomorrow morning."
text: Motsadi” 2: “Ke akanya gore o bile a lapa fela re tshwanetse go mo isa kwa tleniking ka moso mo mosong.”

SourceText: Call someone for help - a family member, a friend. Sometimes just talking with someone is enough, but if you feel overwhelmed, ask someone for help. Calling for help is a sign of strength.
text: Batla thuso - leloko la lelapa, tsala. Nako dingwe go buisana le mongwe ke sone se o se tlhokang, fela fa o ikutlwa o tlalane go kopa thuso go mongwe. Go batla thuso go bontsha matla.

SourceText: Here's a video that might help you when @fields.child_nickname cries.
text: Fano ke bidiyo e e ka go thusang fa 1 a lela.

SourceText: 5. Take a break!
text: 5. Ikhutse go se kae!

SourceText: If you are getting angry because @fields.child_nickname won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Check on @fields.child_nickname every 5-10 minutes.
text: Fa o galefisiwa ke gonne 1 ga a didimale, go SIAME go mo tlogela a kaname mo lefelong le le bolokegileng mme o tswe go se kae. Tlhola 1 metsotso mengwe le mengwe e le 5-10.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.
text: Fa o galefisiwa ke gonne lesea la gago ga a didimale, go SIAME go mo tlogela a kaname mo lefelong le le bolokegileng mme o tswe go se kae. tlhola lesea la gago metsotso mengwe le mengwe e le 5-10.

SourceText: We know that this is not easy. You are not a bad father if your baby continues to cry after you have done all you can to calm them. You are doing your best!
text: Re a itse gore ga go bonolo. Ga o ntate yo o bosula fa lesea la gago le tswelela go lela le morago ga go leka tsotlhe go mo didimatsa. O dira ka bojotlhe.

SourceText: Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed @fields.child_nickname or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - @fields.child_nickname can actually sense tension from you, too!
text: Leka go mo potoka, o mo tshikhinye, kgotsa o mo opelele kgotsa o mo leletse mmino. O ka tlhoka go jesa 1 kgotsa go fetola mongwato. A ka tswa tuka molelo kgotsa a gatsela. OKgotsa o batla fela go tsholediwa. Ema go se kae mme o leke go repa - 2 o kgona go utlwa fa o sa repa!

SourceText: Remember that you can also change the type of messages you receive for an older or younger child. Just select "Tech Support". Chat to you later!
text: Gape o ka fetola mofuta wa melaetsa o o amogelelang ngwana wa gago yo mogolwane kgotsa yo monnye. tlhopha fela “Tshegetso ya setegeniki”. Ke tla bua le wena moragonyana!

SourceText: Be open to your children. They get stressed too - sometimes from different things from you. Allow them to express how they feel and accept their feelings. Try to listen to them and think about how it must feel for them.
text: Phuthologa go bana ba gago Baa imelwa le bona - nako dingwe go tswa mo dilong tse di farologaneng go na le tsa gago. Ba letle go tlhagisa maikutlo mme o a amogele. Leka go ba reetsa le go akanya gore ba ikutlwa jang.

SourceText: Here are some tips for how we can help our children learn how to cope with their emotions:
text: Fano ke dikakantsho dingwe gore re ka thusa jang bana ba rona go mekamekana le maikutlo a bona:

SourceText: 1. Be open to your child
text: 1. Phuthologa go bana ba gago

SourceText: 2. Share your own feelings
text: 2. Arolelanelang maikutlo

SourceText: 3. Help your child learn how to talk about feelings
text: 3. thusa ngwana wa gago gore a bue jang ka maikutlo

SourceText: 4. Talking about difficult emotions
text: 4. Go bua ka maikutlo a a bokete

SourceText: 5. Notice the positive emotions
text: 5. Elatlhoko maikutlo a a siameng

SourceText: 6. Show your child that you care
text: 6. Bontsha ngwana wa gago gore o kgathala

SourceText: To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Go ithuta go le gontsi ka nngwe ya dikakantsho tse, tlanya “1” go ya go “6”. Tlanya “N” go emisa kakantsho e.

SourceText: Your child will look to you for support and reassurance. Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling. Accept how they feel and give them comfort.
text: Ngwana wa gago o tla leba kwa go wena go bona tshegetso le netefaletso. Reetsa bana ba gago fa ba bua gore ba ikutlwa jang. Amogela gore ba ikutlwa jang mme o ba neele namatshego.

SourceText: When you share your own feelings with your children, you help them recognise their own feelings. It can also help your children learn self-discipline and to understand their own feelings.
text: Fa o bua ka maikutlo a gago le bana ba gago, o ba thusa go lemoga maikutlo a bona. Gape go ka thusa bana ba gago go ithuta go ikgalema le go tlhaloganya maikutlo a gago.

SourceText: There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Even babies can feel and express these emotions. As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.
text: Gona le maikutlo a le 6 a motheo: boitumelo,khutsafalo, ngadile, gakgametse, le letshogo. Le fa masea a kgona go ikutlwa le go tlhagisa maikutlo. Fa bana ba ntse ba gola, ba ithuta go lemoga maikutlo a mangwe a mantsi, jaaka a boitumelo,khutsafalo, ngadile, gakgametse, le letshogo.

SourceText: It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy. This may be especially the case for boys and men.
text: Go tlwaelegile go nna le bothata go bua ka ga kgotsa go tlhagisa maikutlo le gore o ikutlwa jang. Bontsi jwa rona bo ne ba bolelelwa gore bo se lelele ba bo hutsafetse kgotsa bo s tshege fa go itumetse. Seno se gantsi go basimane le banna.

SourceText: But we all have the same feelings, and  we can learn how to become aware of our own emotions, to experience them in our body, and to communicate about them.
text: Fela rotlhe re na le maikutlo a a tshwanang, mme re kgona go ithuta gore re lemoa jang maikutlo a rona, go a itemogela mo mebeleng ya rona, le go bua ka ona.

text: Ka kopo tlhopha nomoro e nngwe fa o batla go ithuta go feta ka ga go bua ka ga maikutlo:

SourceText: Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help @fields.child_nickname be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!
text: Go bua ka ga maikutlo go thusa bana go laola kgalefo, ditshepiso tse di sa dirwang le ketsaetsego. Gape go ka thusa 1 go elatlhoko maikutlo a a siameng jaaka kagiso, boitumelo kotsa thitibalo. Gape go ka letla bana go ananeela motsi o montle kgotsa maikutlo a lerato

SourceText: Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help your child be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!
text: Go bua ka ga maikutlo go thusa bana go laola kgalefo, ditshepiso tse di sa dirwang le ketsaetsego. Gape go ka thusa ngwana wa gago go elatlhoko maikutlo a a siameng jaaka kagiso, boitumelo kotsa thitibalo. Gape go ka letla bana go ananeela motsi o montle kgotsa maikutlo a lerato

SourceText: Use physical and verbal support to make @fields.child_nickname feel accepted and loved. A hug or saying, "I understand," can mean a lot. Remind @fields.child_nickname that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.
text: Dirisa tshegetso ka go kgoma le ka molomo go dira gore 1 a ikutlwe a amogetswe le go ratiwa. Go mo tlamparela kgotsa go re “Ke a tlhaloganya,” go botlhokwa tota. Gopotsa 1 gore o gona go ba thusa le gore ba ka bua le wena nako nngwe le nngwe.

SourceText: Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved. A hug or saying, "I understand," can mean a lot. Remind your child that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.
text: Dirisa tshegetso ka go kgoma le ka molomo go dira gore 1 a ikutlwe a amogetswe le go ratiwa. Go mo tlamparela kgotsa go re “Ke a tlhaloganya,” go botlhokwa tota. Gopotsa ngwana wa gago gore o gona go ba thusa le gore ba ka bua le wena nako nngwe le nngwe.

text: Fano ke khomiki go go bontsha gore o ka neela 1 lerato le tshegetso jang fa ba arolelanela le wena maikutlo a a bokete...

SourceText: Parent: “How are you doing, Andy?”
text: Motsadi: O ikutlwa jang Andy?

SourceText: Teen (looking sad): “I wish I could hang out with my friends.”
text: Mosha (o lebega a hutsafetse): “Ke eletsa go etela ditsala tsa me.”

SourceText: Parent (thinking): "Hmmm…that can wait…"
text: Motsadi (o a akanya): “Hmmm...seo se ka ema go se kae...”

SourceText: Parent (looks back to teen):“I understand it is hard to be separate from your friends. Especially since I am sure they are missing you, too. Let’s think of some ways that you could reach out to them.”
text: Motsadi (o lebelela mosha gape): “Ke tlhaloganya gore go thata go kgaogana le ditsala tsa gago. Segolo gonne ke dumela gore le bone ba a gopola. Tla re akanye mekgwa e mengwe e re ka ikgolaganyang le bona.”

SourceText: Teen: "Maybe I can make a TikTok video to share with them. But I am not sure how…can you help me?”
text: * “Mosha”: “Gongwe nka dira bidiyo ya TikTok ka e abelana le bona. Fela ga ke tshepe gore ke itse go e dira ... a o ka nthusa?

SourceText: Parent: “I would be happy to help and would like to know more about TikTok, too!”
text: Motsadi: “Ke tla go thusa ka le nna nka rata go itse go feta ka ga TikTok!”

SourceText: Here is a comic that shows how you can give your teen love and support when they share difficult emotions with you…
text: Fano ke khomiki go go bontsha gore o ka neela mosha wa gago lerato le tshegetso jang fa ba arolelanela le wena maikutlo a a bokete...

SourceText: Child: “Why can’t I go play with my friends today?”
text: Ngwana: “Goreng nka se kgone go ya go tshameka le ditsala tsa me gompieno?”

SourceText: Parent: “I can see that you are upset, Sam. It can be difficult when we feel separated from our friends.”
text: Motsadi: “Ke kgona go lemoga gore o utlwile botlhoko, Sam. go thata fa o ikutlwa o kgaogantswe le ditsala tsa gago.:

SourceText: Parent: “We are not allowed to visit other people right now because of COVID-19.
text: Motsadi: “Ga re a letlelelwa go etela batho gajaana ka ntlha ya COVID-19.

SourceText: This will keep them and us safe while making sure our health services are able to support those who are sick."
text: Seno ke go ba itshola mmogo le bona re bolokegile fa re ntse re netefatsa gore ditirelo tsa rona tsa itekanelo di kgona go tshegetsa balwetse.”

SourceText: Parent: “As soon as we are able, you can play with your friends. In the meantime, we can draw some pictures of your favourite times playing with them.”
text: Motsadi: “Fa fela go kgonega, o tla kgona go ya go tshameka le ditsala tsa gago. O ka nna wa tsamaisa nako, re thale ditshwantsho dingwe tsa nako e o e ratileng fa o ne o tshameka le bona.”

SourceText: Child: “Okay!”
text: Ngwana: “Go siame!”

SourceText: Here are 6 steps on how we can reduce negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like tantrums using what we call Ignore:
text: Fano le dikgato di le 6 gore o ka dira jang go fokotsa maikutlo a go batla go elwatlhoko le a go gapeletse go bona dilo tse ba di batlang jaaka ba dira matepe le go dirisang go ba ikgatholosa:

SourceText: 1. Try to redirect your child’s attention
text: 1. Leka go kaela tsepo ya ngwana wa gago gape

SourceText: 2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore
text: 2. Netefatsa gore ke maitsholo a o kgonang go a ikgatholosa

SourceText: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child
text: 3. Ikgatholose maitsholo e seng ngwana wa gago

SourceText: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour
text: 4. akgola ngwana wa gago ka nako eo go maitsholo a a siameng a a latelang

SourceText: 5. Be consistent when ignoring
text: 5. O lolame mo go ikgatholoseng

SourceText: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times.
text: 6. Netefatsa gore mo dinakong tse dingwe o neela ngwana wa gago kelotlhoko e ntsi.

SourceText: To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to move on.
text: Go ithuta go le gontsi ka nngwe ya dikakantsho tse, tlanya “1” go ya go “6”. Gape o ka tlanya “N”go tswelelapele.

SourceText: Here is a comic on combining consequences and ignore.
text: Fano ke khomiki mo go kopanyeng ditlamorago le go ikgatholosa.

SourceText: Parent 1: "Bailey, please clear the dishes after dinner"
text: Motsadi 1: “Bailey, ke kopa o tlose dijana morago ga dijo”

SourceText: Parent 2: "Sam, time to get ready for bed. Come with me."
text: Motsadi” 2: “Sam, nako go ipaakanyetsa go robala. Tlaya.”

SourceText: Parent: "The household rule is that you have to help clean up after dinner before you can play with your toys."
text: Motsadi: “Molao wa fa lapeng ke gore o thuse go phepafatsa le go morago ga dijo pele o tshameka ka ditshamekisi tsa gago.”

SourceText: Child: "I don't want to clear the dishes. I want to play with my new toy car. "
text: Ngwana: “Ga ke batle go phutha dijana. Ke batla go tshameka ka k=setshamekisi sa me sa koloi e ntshwa.”

SourceText: Parent 1: "Bailey, either you clear the table now, or you will not be able to play with your toys later tonight"
text: Motsadi 1: “Bailey, o ka phutha tafole jaanong, kgotsa o ka se kgone go tshameka ka ditshamekisi moragonyana maitseboa”

SourceText: Child: "But it is not fair! Sam doesn't have to clean up after dinner!"
text: Ngwana: “Tota ga go a siama! Sam ga a tlhoke go tlheka morago ga dijo!”

SourceText: Parent 1: "Because you did not listen, you cannot play with your toys. Please get ready for bed.
text: Motsadi 1: “GO ka se tshameke ka ditshamekisi gonne o sa reetsa. Ke kopa o ipaakanyetse go robala.

SourceText: Child: "But that is not fair!"
text: Ngwana: “Tota ga go a siama!

SourceText: Child: "But that is not fair. Waaaah!"
text: Ngwana: “Fela ga go a siama! Waaaah!"

SourceText: Parent 1: "It is so nice to see that you got ready for bed all by yourself!"
text: Motsadi 1: “Go gontle jang go go bona o ipaakanyetsa go robala ka bowena!”

SourceText: Child: "Now can I play with my toy car?"
text: Ngwana: “A jaanong nka tshameka ka koloi ya me ya setshamekisi?”

SourceText: Parent 1: "You can play with your car tomorrow. It is bedtime. Come, my sweetie, I will tell your favourite bedtime story."
text: Motsadi 1: “O tla tshameka ka koloi ya gago ka moso. Ke nako ya go robala. Tlaya moratiwa, ke tla go tlotlela kgang ya gago ya mmamoratwa fa o robala.”

SourceText: Parent 1: "Once upon a time..."
text: Motsadi 1: “Bogologolo tala...”

SourceText: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention
text: 1. Leka go kaela tsepo ya ngwana wa gago gape

SourceText: When they start demanding for something or whining, first try to redirect them to a positive behaviour or activity. Praise them for that positive behaviour!
text: Fa ba leka go nogongorega kgotsa go batla sengwe ka nakne, leka pele go ba kaela go maitsholo a a siameng kgotsa tirwana. Ba akgolele maitsholo ao a a siameng.

SourceText: These are behaviours like whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child. But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!
text: Ano ke maitsholo a a jaaka go ngongorega, go pateletsa go bona sengwe, matepe, le maitsholo a mangwe a mantsi a go batla nako le go pateletsa go bona dilo a a ka dirang gore re fetse re akanya gore ngwana o bosula. Ga gona bana ba ba bosula...ke ba ba maitsholo a a sa tlhaloganyegeng!

SourceText: When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.
text: Fa o ikgatholosa maitsholo a bngwana (e seng ngwana) ngwana wa gago o kgona go ithuta gore maitsholo a go pateletsa go bona dilo ga a thuse.

SourceText: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way.
text: Fa o arabela maitsholo, ngwana wa gago o tla ithuta gore maitsholo ano a a thusa. Gape a ka ithuta gore fa a oketsa maitsholo a a pgo pateletsa dilo o tla bona se a se batlang.

SourceText: This takes time AND patience. Normally your child will try to test you and behave worse. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.
text: Seno se tsaya nako LE bopelotelele. ka gale ngwana wa gago o tla leka go go leka le go itshola maswe tota. Eno ke nako ya go Ema go se kae mme o Ritibale.

SourceText: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times
text: 6. Netefatsa gore mo dinakong tse dingwe o neela ngwana wa gago kelotlhoko e ntsi.

SourceText: Children need attention. If children get plenty of attention for just being themselves, as well as for the “good” things that they do, it helps them to feel good about themselves, and they do more of what they are asked.
text: Bana ba tlhoka nako. Fa bana ba newa nako fela go bo ba nnile se e leng sona, go senyeletsa le dilo tse ba di dirang, go ba thusa go ikutlwa bontle le go dira ka fa ba kopiwang ka gona.

SourceText: Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.
text: Maitsholo a ngwana wa gago a ka etegela.  Go botlhokwa gore o tswelele go ikgatholosa maitsholo ano.

SourceText: Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.
text: Gantsi, ngwana wa gago o tla ngala le go feta fa o simolola go ikgatholosa maitsholo a a rileng fa a tsweletse go go leka.

SourceText: If you find yourself ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, it is either because you are not being consistent (sometimes ignoring and sometimes giving in) OR you are not spending enough positive time with your child. One-on-One Time is super important!
text: Fa o iphitlhela o ikgatholosa maitsholo a ngwana wa gago gantsi, e ka nna go bo o fetofetoga (nako dingwe o kgatholosa fa tse dingwe o mo neela se a se batlang) KGOTSA ga o na nako e ntsi le ngwana wa gago. Go ipha nako ya motho ka mong mmogo go botlhokwa tota!

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to use ignore to reduce tantrums or other difficult behaviours:
text: Ka kopo tlhopha nomoro e nngwe fa o batla go ithuta go feta ka ga go dirisa ikgatholoso go fokotsa matepe le maitsholo a mangwe a a boima:

SourceText: Ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining or tantrums. Your @fields.child_nickname’s behaviour might at first get worse, but with time they will learn that it does not work. Be consistent and patient. And make sure that you are also giving @fields.child_nickname plenty of positive attention at other times. You can do it!

SourceText: Challenges are stressful. But problem-solving can really help. There are 6 basic steps for problem solving:
text: dikgwetlho di a imela. Fela go rarabolola mathata go a thusa. Gona le dikgato tsa motheo di le 6 go rarabolola mathata:

SourceText: 1. Identify the problem
text: 1. Lemoga mathata.

SourceText: 2. Think of possible solutions
text: 2. Akanya ka ditharabololo tse di kgonegang

SourceText: 3. Figure out what the results of each solution would be
text: 3. Bona gore tharabololo nngwe le nngwe e ka tlisa dipoelo tse di ntseng jang

SourceText: 4. Choose one solution
text: 4. tlhopha tharabololo e le nngwe

SourceText: 5. Try it out!
text: 5. E leke!

SourceText: 6. Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution
text: 6. A e berekile? Go gontle! Fa e sa bereka, jaanong o ka leka tharabololo e nngwe.

SourceText: We can also teach our children the same steps.
text: Gape re ka ithuta bana ba rona dikgato tsona tse

SourceText: When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame our children. But what they really need is someone to help them work through their problems.

SourceText: Take a Pause! Become aware of anger and stress. Take a deep breath or count to 10 before you react. Then respond in a calmer way.

SourceText: Try to redirect. Stop it before it starts! When your children get restless, you can distract them with something interesting or fun: "Come, let's play a game together!"

SourceText: If your baby is starting to crawl or walk, you can also redirect them by physically picking them up and focusing their attention on something else interesting. Use a lively and cheerful voice!

SourceText: Keep it positive. It is normal to want to say something about @fields.child_nickname's negative behaviour, like “Don’t whine,” or “Stop running in the house.” Instead, just say something that you want @fields.child_nickname to do, like "Speak with a calm voice," or "Remember to walk inside the house."

SourceText: COVID-19 has interrupted our daily work, home and school routines. This is hard for children, teenagers and for you. Making new routines can help.

SourceText: We are now spending a lot more time online. Being connected helps us stay positive…but it also presents risks and dangers.
text: Gajaana re nna nako e ntsi mo inthaneteng. Go nna o golagane go re thusa go nna le tshepo...fela go ka tlhagisa matshosetsi le dikotsi.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you keep yourself safe online.
text: Fano ke bidiyo go go thusa go itshola o sireletsegile mo inthaneteng.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you keep yourself safe online.
text: Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo go go thusa go itshola o sireletsegile mo inthaneteng.

SourceText: Here are 5 tips that can help you keep yourself safe online:
text: Fano ke dikakantsho tse 5 tse di ka go thusang go itshola o sireletsegile mo inthaneteng:

SourceText: 1. Learn about the risks and dangers
text: 1. Ithute ka ga matshosetsi le dikotsi

SourceText: 2. Quick tech fixes
text: 2. Dipaakanyo tsa tegeniki tse di bonako

SourceText: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits
text: 3. Tlhama ditlwaelo tsa inthanete tse di itekanetseng le go sireletsega

SourceText: 4. Maintain privacy
text: 4. Tswelela ka bosephiri

SourceText: 5. Report and seek help
text: 5. Bega mme o batle thuso

SourceText: To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "5". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Go ithuta go le gontsi ka nngwe ya dikakantsho tse, tlanya “1” go ya go “5”. Tlanya “N” go emisa kakantsho e.

SourceText: 1. Learn about risks and dangers
text: 1. Ithute ka ga matshosetsi le dikotsi

SourceText: Keep personal information private, especially from strangers. – some people are not who they say they are!
text: Tshola tshedimosetso ya sebele poraefete, segolo go batho ba o sa ba itseng. - batho bangwe ga se seo ba reng ke sona!

SourceText: 2. Quick tech fixes:
text: 2. Dipaakanyo tsa tegeniki tse di bonako

SourceText: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits:
text: 3. Tlhama ditlwaelo tsa inthanete tse di itekanetseng le go sireletsega

SourceText: You can also create healthy and safe online habits like creating device-free spaces and times in your house (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).
text: Gape o ka tlhama ditlwaelo tse di sireletsegileng le go bolokega mo inthaneteng jaaka go tlhama dibaka le dinako tse o sa diriseng didiriswa tsa tlhaeletsano mo ntlong ya gago. (go ja, go tshameka, tiro ya sekolo, le go robala).

SourceText: Remember that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).
text: Gopola gore se se pegiwang mo inthaneteng se nna mo inthaneteng (melaetsa, ditshwantsho le dibidiyo).

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn another way to protect yourself online:
text: Ka kopo tlhopha nomoro e nngwe fa o batla go ithuta tsela e nngwe ya go itshireletsa mo inthaneteng:

SourceText: Hello @fields.user_name! Book-sharing can be a great learning tool for your child. You can use simple pictures in books, magazines, or newspapers to do lots of things that you and your child can enjoy.

SourceText: Would you like to learn more about how you can help your child develop through book sharing?
text: A o ka rata go ithuta go feta gore o ka thusa jang ngwana wa gago ka go arolelanela buka?

SourceText: Here's a video to take you through the shared book reading activity!
text: Fano ke bidiyo go go kaetsa tirwana ya go buisa buka e e arolelanelwang!

SourceText: Here's an audio message that takes you through the shared book reading activity!
text: Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo go go kaetsa tirwana ya go buisa buka e e arolelanelwang!

SourceText: Here are some tips for sharing books with your child:
text: Fano ke dikakantsho go arolelanela dibuka le ngwana wa gago:

SourceText: 1. Follow your child's interest
text: 1. Latela kgatlhegelo ya ngwana wa gago

SourceText: 2. Use a lifely voice
text: 2. Dirisa lentswe le le tletseng botshelo

SourceText: 3. Pointing and naming
text: 3. Go supa le go bitsa maina

SourceText: 4. Be positive and supportive
text: 4. Nna le tshepo mme o neelane ka tshegetso

SourceText: 5. Making actions and links
text: 5. Go tsaya dikgato lle dikgokagano

SourceText: 6. Talking about feelings
text: 6. Go bua ka maikutlo

SourceText: 7. Babies and books go well together
text: 7. Masea le dibuka di a tshwaisana

SourceText: 2. Use a lively voice
text: 2. Dirisa lentswe le le tletseng botshelo

SourceText: Speak with a lively or animated voice. This will help to keep the child’s attention on the book.
text: Bua ka lentswe le le tletseng botshelo mme o etsise diphologolo. Seno se tla thusa gore ngwana wa gago a tsepame mo bukeng

SourceText: 7. Babies and Books!
text: 7. Masea le dibuka!

SourceText: Even very young babies enjoy book-sharing and looking at the pictures together with a parent or caregiver. In fact, regular book-sharing helps their development and learning. And it is okay for them to put the book in their mouth - they are exploring!
text: Le fa ba santse ba le bannye, bana ba rata go arolelanela buka le go lebelela ditshwantsho mmogo le motsadi kgotsa motlhokomedi. Sentlentle, go arolelanela buka ka gale go thusa tlhabololo le go ithuta ga bona. E bile go siame le fa ba tsenya buka mo molomong - ba a batlisisa!

SourceText: Here are some examples!
text: Fano ke dingwe tsa dikai

SourceText: “Look, she is smiling. Why do you think she is smiling? What made you smile today?”
text: “Bona, o a nyeba. Gore o akanya gore o a nyeba? Ke eng se se dirileng gore o nyebe gompieno?”

SourceText: “The monkey is sad because he is all on his own. Can you remember when you were last sad?”
text: “Kgabo e hutsafetse gonne e ntse e le nosi. A o kgona go gopola gore ke leng labofelo fa o ne o hutsafetse?”

SourceText: “That tiger looks angry. Why do you think he is angry? Do you remember when I got angry this morning?”
text: “Nkwe e lebega e galefile. gore o akanya gore e lebega e galefile? A o gopola fa ke ne ke galefile mo mosong ono?”

SourceText: Always respond positively to whatever @fields.child_nickname says about the pictures. For example, if your child points to a red tomato and says “Apple”, you can say “Yes, you’re right, it’s red - it's a tomato!”

SourceText: Connect things in the book with familiar things in @fields.child_nickname’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask @fields.child_nickname to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and @fields.child_nickname can do the same.
text: Goalaganya dilo mo bukeng le dilo tse di tlwaelegileng go lefatshe la 1. Sekao, fa lesea mo bukeng le rwele ditlhako, kopa ngwana go supa ditlhako tsa gagwe. Fa mongwe mo bukeng a dumedisa a tsholeditse seatla, wena le 1 le ka dira fela jalo.

SourceText: Connect things in the book with familiar things in your child’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask your child to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and your child can do the same.
text: Goalaganya dilo mo bukeng le dilo tse di tlwaelegileng go lefatshe la ngwana wa gago. Sekao, fa lesea mo bukeng le rwele ditlhako, kopa ngwana go supa ditlhako tsa gagwe. Fa mongwe mo bukeng a dumedisa a tsholeditse seatla, wena le ngwana wa gago le ka dira fela jalo.

SourceText: Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about @fields.child_nickname’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.
text: Dibuka ke tsela e ntle gore bana ba ithute go feta ka ga maikutlo. O ka dirisa sefatlhego le lentswe go ba thusa go tlhaloganya mafoko a maikutlo a a jaaka boitumelo, khutsafalo, kgalefo, kgotsa letshogo. O ka dirisa se se diragalang mo bukeng go bua ka maikutlo a 1 le gore ke goreng batho ba na le go ikutlwa ka mokgwa o o rileng.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about your child’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.
text: Dibuka ke tsela e ntle gore bana ba ithute go feta ka ga maikutlo. O ka dirisa sefatlhego le lentswe go ba thusa go tlhaloganya mafoko a maikutlo a a jaaka boitumelo, khutsafalo, kgalefo, kgotsa letshogo. O ka dirisa se se diragalang mo bukeng go bua ka maikutlo a ngwana wa gago le gore ke goreng batho ba na le go ikutlwa ka mokgwa o o rileng.

SourceText: Millions of families are struggling to make ends meet. When money is tight, this can make us feel anxious, stressed, and sad. How we understand and talk about money with our children is important. Our children can also help us to spend and save in ways that will benefit the family.
text: Dimilione tsa malapa di itemogela bothata go tshela sentle. Fa madi a tlhaela, re ka itemogela ketsaetsego, ra imelea le go hutsafala. gore re tlhaloganya le go bua jang ka madi le bana ba rona go botlhokwa. Bana ba rona ba kgona go re thusa go dirisa le go boloka ka mekgwa e e tswelang lelapa mosola.

text: Ga se bothata! O ka nna wa tlanya “Thuso:” nako nngwe le nngwe fela fa o batla kakantsho e ka nako e nngwe. ke tla bua le wena moragonyana 1!

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you want this tip at another time. Chat to you later!
text: Ga se bothata! O ka nna wa tlanya “Thuso:” nako nngwe le nngwe fela fa o batla kakantsho e ka nako e nngwe. Ke tla bua le wena moragonyana!

SourceText: Millions of families are struggling to make ends meet. When money is tight, this can make us feel anxious, stressed, and sad. How we understand and talk about money is important. We can also learn about how we can save in ways that will benefit the family.
text: Dimilione tsa malapa di itemogela bothata go tshela sentle. Fa madi a tlhaela, re ka itemogela ketsaetsego, ra imelea le go hutsafala. gore re tlhaloganya le go bua jang ka madi le bana ba rona go botlhokwa. gape re ka kgona go ithuta ka ga go boloka madi ka ditsela tse di ka tswelang lelapa mosola.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you make a budget and save money together as a family.
text: Fano ke bidiyo go go thusa go dira tekanyetsokabo le go boloka madi mmogo jaaka lelapa.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you make a budget and save money together as a family.
text: Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo go go thusa go dira tekanyetsokabo le go boloka madi mmogo jaaka lelapa.

SourceText: Making a budget.
text: Go dira tekanyetsokabo.

SourceText: A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times. Making a budget can help you have enough at the end of the month so that you need to borrow less.
text: Tsekanyetsokabo e ka ga go swetsa gore re dirisa madi mo go eng, le mo dinakong tse di boima tota. Go dira tekanyetsokabo go go thusa go nna le go go lekaneng kwa bokhutlong jwa kgwedi goretlhokego ya gore o dime e nne kwa tlase.

SourceText: Do you want 4 quick steps to help you make a budget and save money?
text: A o batla dikgato tse di bonako di le 4 go go tusa golekanyetsa le go boloka madi?

SourceText: Step 1: What do we spend on now?
text: Kgato 1: Re reke eng gone jaanong?

SourceText: • Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen.
text: * Batla pampitshana (kgotsa lekwalodikgang la kgale kgotsa bokose ya khateboto) le pene.

SourceText: • Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
text: * Taka ditshwantsho tsa dilo tsotlhe tse wena le lelapa la gago le di rekang kgwedi le kgwedi.

SourceText: • Write next to each picture how much each thing costs.
text: * Kwala fa thoko ga setshwantsho sengwe le sengwe gore selo sengwe le sengwe se ja bokae kgwedi le kgwedi.

SourceText: • Add up how much money you have to spend each month.
text: * Tlhakanya gore ke madi a le kana kang a o tshwanelwang ke go a dirisa kgwedi le kgwedi.

SourceText: Do you want to receive Step 2?
text: A o batla go amogela kgato 2?

SourceText: Step 2: Talk about needs and wants
text: Kgato 2: Tlotlang mmogo ka dilo tse lo di tlhokang le tse lo di batlang

SourceText: • Needs: Which things are important or must haves for your family to survive? (like food, soap to wash hands, needs for ill or disabled family members).
text: Ditlhoko: Ke dife dilo tse di botlhoka kgotsa tse balelapa ba tshwanelang go nna le tsona go tshela? (jaaka sesepa, sesepa go tlhapa diatla, ditlhoko tsa balwetse kgotsa maloko a a balelapa a a tshelang ka bogole).

SourceText: • Wants: Which things are nice to have but not essential?
text: Tse re di batlang: Ke dilo dife tse o di BATLANG tse o ka itumelelang go nna le tsone mme gone tota di se botlhokwa jalo?

SourceText: Do you want to receive Step 3?
text: A o batla go amogela kgato 3?

SourceText: Step 3: Build your own budget
text: Kgato 3: Itirele tekanyetsokabo

SourceText: • Find a bag of stones or anything with lots of bits. This is your money for the month.
text: Batla kgetsana ya majwe kgotsa sengwe fela se senang le dibitsi tse dintsi. Seno ke madi a gago a kgwedi.

SourceText: • As a family, decide what you will spend on what, and put the stones on your picture.
text: * Dirang tshwetso gore lo a go dirisa bokae go reka eng, mme lo bo lo baya maje/dilo tseo mo godimo ga setshwantsho seo.

SourceText: • If you can save even a tiny amount for the future, or for an emergency  – it can make a big difference over time.
text: Fa lo ka boloka le eleng madi a mannye fela a maemo a tshoganyetso mo isagweng - e ka dira pharologanyo fa nako e ntse e ya.

SourceText: Do you want to receive Step 4?
text: A o batla go amogela kgato 4?

SourceText: Step 4: Find out where you can get extra help
text: Kgato 4: Dira dithulaganyo tsa gore o ka bona kae thuso e e oketsegileng

SourceText: Your government or community groups may be giving money, vouchers, or food parcels to families in need. Ask about whether places in your community are giving support.
text: Puso kgotsa ditlhopha tsa baagi di ka tswa di neelana ka madi, diboutshara kotsa diphuthelwalana tsa dijo go malapa a a di tlhokang. Botsa gore a gona le mafelo mo baaging ao a neelanang ka tshegetso.

SourceText: Well done for adding another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Over the next few days, try following these steps to create a family budget. You can even involve your partner in the discussion. Millions of families find that learning ways to manage money as a family reduces family arguments and brings everyone together. That's real success!
text: O dirile bontle ka go tsenya kgono e le nngwe go Kaedi ya Botsadi beke eno! Mo malatsing a a mmalwa a a latelang, leka dikgato tse di latelang go tlhama tekanyetsokabo ya lelapa. O ka nna wa tsenyeletsa molekane wa gago mo motlotlong. Dimilione tsa malapa di fitlhela gore go ithuta mekgwa go laola madi jaaka lelapa go fokotsa diknyanyisano le go golaganya botlhe mmogo. Ke katlego e kgolo!

SourceText: Well done for adding another layer to your House of Support! Over the next few days, try following these steps to create a family budget. You can even involve your partner in the discussion. Millions of families find that learning ways to manage money as a family reduces family arguments and brings everyone together. That's real success!
text: O dirile sentle ka go tsenya moalo o le mongwe go Ntlo ya gago ya Tshegetso! Mo malatsing a a mmalwa a a latelang, leka dikgato tse di latelang go tlhama tekanyetsokabo ya lelapa. O ka nna wa tsenyeletsa molekane wa gago mo motlotlong. Dimilione tsa malapa di fitlhela gore go ithuta mekgwa go laola madi jaaka lelapa go fokotsa diknyanyisano le go golaganya botlhe mmogo. Ke katlego e kgolo!

SourceText: Millions of families are struggling to make ends meet especially due to the COVID-19 pandemic. When money is tight, this can make us feel anxious, stressed, and sad. How we understand and talk about money with our children is important. Our children can also help us to spend and save in ways that will benefit the family.
text: Dimione tsa malapa di itemogela mathata go kopantsha dilo segolo ka ntlha ya leroboro la COVID-19. Fa madi a tlhaela, re ka itemogela ketsaetsego, ra imelea le go hutsafala. gore re tlhaloganya le go bua jang ka madi le bana ba rona go botlhokwa. Bana ba rona ba kgona go re thusa go dirisa le go boloka ka mekgwa e e tswelang lelapa mosola.

SourceText: Making a budget with your children and teens.
text: Go dira tekanyetsokabo mmogo le bana le basha ba gago.

SourceText: A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times. Making a budget together helps children understand that we all need to make hard decisions in difficult times. It can also help you have enough at the end of the month so that you need to borrow less.
text: Tsekanyetsokabo e ka ga go swetsa gore re dirisa madi mo go eng, le mo dinakong tse di boima tota. Go dira tekanyetsokabo mmogo go thusa bana go tlhaloganya gore rotlhe re tlhoka go tsaya ditshwetso tse di popota mo dipakeng tse di boima. Gape go kago  thusa go nna le go go lekaneng kwa bokhutlong jwa kgwedi goretlhokego ya gore o dime e nne kwa tlase.

SourceText: Do you want 4 quick steps to help you make a budget and save money with your children?
text: A o batla dikgato tse di bonako di le 4 go go tusa golekanyetsa le go boloka madi?

SourceText: • Discuss with your children what things you could try to spend less on as a family.
text: Buisana le bana ba gago ka dilo tse le tla lekang go di dira go kgona go dirisa madi a a kwa tlase jaaka lelapa.

SourceText: Well done for adding another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Over the next few days, try following these steps by involving your child in creating a family budget. Millions of families find that learning ways to manage money as a family reduces family arguments and brings everyone together. That's real success!
text: O dirile bontle ka go tsenya kgono e le nngwe go Kaedi ya Botsadi beke eno! Mo malatsing a a mmalwa a a latelang, leka dikgato tse di latelang go tlhama tekanyetsokabo ya lelapa. Dimilione tsa malapa di fitlhela gore go ithuta mekgwa go laola madi jaaka lelapa go fokotsa diknyanyisano le go golaganya botlhe mmogo. Ke katlego e kgolo!

SourceText: Well done for adding another layer to your House of Support! Over the next few days, try following these steps by involving your child in creating a family budget. Millions of families find that learning ways to manage money as a family reduces family arguments and brings everyone together. That's real success!
text: O dirile sentle ka go tsenya moalo o le mongwe go Ntlo ya gago ya Tshegetso! Mo malatsing a a mmalwa a a latelang, leka dikgato tse di latelang go tlhama tekanyetsokabo ya lelapa. Dimilione tsa malapa di fitlhela gore go ithuta mekgwa go laola madi jaaka lelapa go fokotsa diknyanyisano le go golaganya botlhe mmogo. Ke katlego e kgolo!

SourceText: Create routines! Your children will feel more secure and safe when they know what is expected of them and how each day will go. Make a plan with them with time for play, meals, chores, school, and sleep.
text: Tlhama mekgwatlwaelo! Bana ba gago ba tla ikutlwa bababalesegile le go sireletsega fa ba itse gore go lebeletswe eng go tswa mo go bona le gore letsatsi le lengwe le tla tsamaya jang. Rulaganya le bona nako ya go tshameka, go ja, tiro ya fa gae, sekolo le ya go robala.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you create daily routines with your children.
text: Fano ke bidiyo go go thusa go tlhama mekgwatlwaelo ya letsatsi le letsatsi le bana ba gago.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you create daily routines with your children.
text: Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo go go thusa go tlhama mekgwatlwaelo ya letsatsi le letsatsi le bana ba gago.

SourceText: Daily routines, such as time for schoolwork, play, meals, and sleep, can help our children feel safe and secure. They also give our children a sense of security.
text: Mekgwatlwaelo ya letsatsi le letsatsi, jaaka dinako tsa tiro ya sekolo, go tshameka, go ja, le go robala go ka thusa bana ba gago go ikutlwa ba sireletsegile le go babalesega. Gape di neela bana ba rona maikutlo a pabalesego.

SourceText: Here are 4 simple tips that you can use when establishing routines with your children:
text: Fano ke dikakantsho tse di bonolo di le 4 tse o ka di dirisang go tlhama mekgwatlwaelo le bana ba gago:

SourceText: 1. Give one instruction at a time
text: 1. Neelana ka taelo e le nngwe ka nako

SourceText: 2. Use transition warnings to help move from one activity to the next one
text: 2. Dirisa ditsiboso tsa phetogo go thusa go tloga go tirwana e le nngwe go ya go e e latelang

SourceText: 3. Create regular eating and sleeping times
text: 3. Tlhama dinako tse di tshwanang tsa go ja le go robala

SourceText: 4. Involve your teen in creating daily routines
text: 4. Tsenyeletsa mosha wa gago mo go tlhameng mekgwatlwaelo ya letsatsi le letsatsi.

SourceText: To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to 4". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Go ithuta go le gontsi ka nngwe ya dikakantsho tse, tlanya “1” go ya go “4”. Tlanya “N” go emisa kakantsho e.

SourceText: 1. Help your younger children learn routines by taking them through the activity step by step. Give one instruction at a time. Praise them each time they follow!
text: 1. Thusa bana ba gago ba ba nnye go ithuta ka ga mekgwatlwaelo ka go tsamaya le bona kgato ka kgato fa ba dira tirwana. Neelana ka taelo e le nngwe ka nako Ba akgole nako nngwe le nngwe fa ba latela!

SourceText: 2. Transition warnings can also be very helpful. They give your child some time to prepare for the next activity: "In 5 minutes it will be time to pack up the toys before bedtime…"
text: 2. Gape ditsiboso tsa phetogo di ka nna botlhokwa tota. Di neela ngwana wa gago nako nngwe go ipaakanyetsa tirwana e e latelang: “mo metsotsong e le 5 e tla bo e le nako ya go phutha ditshwamekisi pele go robalwa...”

SourceText: 3. Regular eating and sleeping times are especially important for babies. Not enough sleep can make your child cranky, irritable, and short tempered.
text: 3. Dinako tse di tshwanang tsa go ja le go robala di botlhokwa segolo go masea. Go sa robale go go lekaneng go ka dira gore ngwana wa gago a tselatsele, a tshwenyege mme a ngale ka bonako.

SourceText: Here are some tips for how to help your child prepare for bedtime:
text: Fano ke dikakantsho dingwe gore o ka thusa ngwana wa gago go ipaakanyetsa go robala jang:

SourceText: • Try to have regular bedtimes each day as much as possible.
text: Leka go nna le dinako tse di tshwanang tsa robala letsatsi le letsatsi ka moo go kgonegang ka gone.

SourceText: • Try to make it quiet and the lights in the room dim.
text: Leka gore go didimale mme dipone di fifale go le gonnye mo phaposing.

SourceText: • Spend some time with your child. You can sing a lullaby or tell a calm story.
text: * Go fetsa nako ke na le ngwanake O ka mo opelela pina ya tuntuletso kgotsa wa mo tlotlela kgang e e ritibatsang.

SourceText: • Give your child a hug and kiss goodnight before leaving the room.
text: Tlamparela le go atla ngwana wa gago pele a thulamela pele wena o tswa mo phaposing.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about creating daily routines:
text: Ka kopo tlhopha nomoro e nngwe fa o batla go ithuta go feta ka ga go tlhama mekgwatlwaelo ya letsatsi le letsatsi:

SourceText: 4, Involve your teen in creating daily routines
text: Tsenyeletsa mosha wa gago mo go tlhameng mekgwatlwaelo ya letsatsi le letsatsi.

SourceText: Here are some suggestions for routines that you could establish with your children:
text: Fano ke ditshitsinyo dingwe tsa mekgwatlwaelo eo o ka e tlhamang le bana ba gago:

SourceText: Bedtime
text: Nako ya go robala

SourceText: Schoolwork and Online Classes
text: Tiro ya sekolo le Dtlelase tsa inthanete

SourceText: Chores
text: Ditiro tsa fa gae

SourceText: Mealtime
text: Nako ya dijo

SourceText: Play/free time
text: Nako go ya tshameka/go ikhutsa

SourceText: T.V. or gadget time
text: Nako ya TV kgotsa ya sediriswa sa inthanete

SourceText: Storytime
text: nako ya kgang

SourceText: One-on-One Time
text: Go Ipha Nako Mmogo

SourceText: You can add more, too! Here is a comic on creating a daily routine with your child.
text: O tla tlaleletsa go feta! Fano ke khomiki ka ga go tlhama mekgwatlwaelo ya letsatsi le letsatsi le ngwana wa gago.

SourceText: Parent: “Now let’s look at the multiplication tables…”
text: Motsadi: “Jaanong tla re lebe dipapetla tsa katiso...”

SourceText: Parent: “Thank you for helping me make lunch, Junior”
text: Motsadi: “Ke lebogela go bo o nthusitse go dira dijo tsa motshegare, Junior”

SourceText: Child: “My favourite!”
text: Ngwana: “Ke a e rata!”

SourceText: Parent “And they all lived happily ever after…Goodnight, my love.”
text: Motsadi “Mme ba tshela monate go feta...Robala sentle lerato la me.”

SourceText: Being specific is not rude or insensitive, it really helps others understand you clearly and prevents confusion in the family. Emotions like anger and stress are part of our lives. All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is know how to handle it by taking a few deep breaths before responding.
text: Go totobala ga e se go tlhoka maitseo kgotsa go sa amege - seno se thusa ba bangwe go go tlhaloganya sentle mme seno se dira gore go seke ga nna le go tlhakana tlhogo mo lelapeng. Go ikutlwa o galefile le go tshwenyega mo maikutlong ke karolo ya botshelo jwa rona. Se re tlhokang go se dira fa re galefile le go tshwenyega mo maikutlong ke go tshwara maikutlo a rona sentle ka go hemela ko teng makgetlo a le mmalwa pele o araba.

SourceText: Sharing emotions is about explaining how you are feeling so @fields.child_nickname is aware and learns to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It’s up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later: “I am feeling angry/stressed now, can you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight”.
text: Go buisana ka maikutlo go ka ga go tlhalosa gore o ikutlwa jang gore 1 a eletlhoko le go ithuta go dira fela jalo. O ka nna wa tlhopha gore o batla go bua go le kana kang ka seemo sa gago. Go tswa mo go wena! Gape o ka tlhopha go araba dipotso moragonyana: “Ke ikutlwa ke galefile/ke imetswe gajaana, a o ka kgona go nnela nako nngwe? Re ka bua ka seno gape bosigo”.
