SourceText: 1. Treat each other as equals
text: 1. Tsholanang ka go lekalekana

SourceText: Family and friends might tell you how a husband or a father should act. But both men and women benefit when they talk to each other and make decisions together! For example, next time you’re making a decision, try involving your partner and ask what they think.
text: Balelapa le ditsala ba ka go bolelela gore monna kgotsa ntate o tshwanetse go itshola jang. Fela banna le basadi mmogo ba ka iponna molemo fa ba buisana le go tsaya ditshwetso mmogo! sekao, nako e e latelang fa o tsaya tshwetso, leka go tsenyeletsa molekane wa gago le go mmotsa gore o akanya eng.

SourceText: Family and friends might tell you how a wife or a mother should act compared to a husband or father.  But both men and women benefit when they talk to each other and make decisions together! For example, next time you’re making a decision, try involving your partner and ask what they think.
text: Balelapa le ditsala ba ka go bolelela gore mosadi kgotsa mme o tshwanetse go itshola jang fa go bapisiwa le mmona kgotsa ntate.  Fela banna le basadi mmogo ba ka iponna molemo fa ba buisana le go tsaya ditshwetso mmogo! sekao, nako e e latelang fa o tsaya tshwetso, leka go tsenyeletsa molekane wa gago le go mmotsa gore o akanya eng.

SourceText: Family and friends might tell you how a partner or a parent should act. But both men and women benefit when they talk to each other and make decisions together! For example, next time you’re making a decision, try involving your partner and ask what they think.
text: Balelapa le ditsala ba ka go bolelela gore molekane kgotsa motsadi o tshwanetse go itshola jang. Fela banna le basadi mmogo ba ka iponna molemo fa ba buisana le go tsaya ditshwetso mmogo! sekao, nako e e latelang fa o tsaya tshwetso, leka go tsenyeletsa molekane wa gago le go mmotsa gore o akanya eng.

SourceText: When mothers and fathers are both engaged with the parenting of their children, everyone benefits, including the children! Show your partner that you appreciate it when they spend quality time with your children.

SourceText: Sharing family responsibilities with your partner can make life less stressful! Can you think of ways you can share the workload? Doing tasks together can also make them more fun!

SourceText: All adults have disagreements sometimes. But solving issues through fighting is not effective. Instead, if you start feeling angry, walk away for a bit or take a deep breath before responding in a calmer way.
text: Bagolo botlhe ba nna le dikganetsano nako dingwe. Fela go rarabolola merero ka ntwa ga go thuse. Fa o ikutlwa go simolola go ngala, tswaya nakwana kfotsa o hemele kwa teng pele go araba ka tsela e e ritibetseng.

SourceText: Listening and talking to those around us is key to a more peaceful home. Talking to your partner about issues before they become problems can help avoid arguments from building up.
text: Go reetsa le go bua go bao a re dikologileng go botlhokwa go tlhama legae le le nang le kagiso. Go buisana le molenake wa gago ka ga dintlha pele e nna mathata go ka thusa go efoga dikgogakgogano go nna gona.

SourceText: First, we can find ways to encourage our children to behave well more often. Spending One-on-One Time with them is an important first step!

SourceText: Hi! Have you tried to talk to your partner about your feelings and any difficulties you are facing recently?
text: Dumela! A o kile wa leka go bua le molekane wa gago ka ga maikutlo a gago kgotsa mathata mangwe fela a o mekamekaneng le ona morago jaana?

SourceText: Good for you! Talking about challenges and our emotions can be hard. How was your experience?
text: Go go siametse! Go bua ka dikgwetlho le maikutlo a rona go ka nna boima. Maitemogelo a gago a nnile jang?

SourceText: Sharing how we feel and talking about the difficulties we’re facing actually makes everyone in the family stronger! By sharing emotions you can better understand and support each other.
text: Go buisana ka ga gore o ikutlwa jang le ka ga mathata ao re lebaganeng le ona gomatlafatsa botlhe fa lelapeng! Ka go arolelanela maikutlo le kgona go tlhaloganyana le go tshegetsana botoka.

SourceText: Sharing your emotions or difficulties you are facing is about making others more aware of how you are feeling. You get to decide how much you want to share. You can also choose to share more at a later time.
text: go arolelanela maikutlo kgotsa mathata a le mekamekaneng le ona go dira ba bangwe gore ba eletlhoko gore o ikutlwa jang. O kgetha gore o batla go arolelanela bokgakala bo jo kae. O kgona go kgetha go arolelanela go feta moragonyana.

SourceText: Talking about our feelings or challenges we’re facing can help others understand and support you better. Emotions and challenges are a part of life and learning how to handle these can help you avoid conflict with loved ones and make life less stressful.
text: Go bua ka maikutlo kgotsa dikgwetlho tse di re lebileng go kgona go thusa ba bangwe go go tlhaloganya le go go tshegetsa botoka. Maikutlo le dikgwetlho ke karolo ya botshelo mme go ithuta gore o mekamekana jang le tsona go kgona go go thusa go efoga kgotlhang le batho ba o ba ratang le go tlhofofatsa botshelo.

SourceText: Starting something new can be difficult. Give yourself and others time to get used to it. By setting a good example by sharing your emotions and challenges you’re facing others will feel start to feel more comfortable sharing too.
text: Go leka sengwe se seswa go ka nna boima! Iphhe nako wena le babangwe go tlwaela se. Ka go nna sekao se se siameng ka go arolelanela maikutlo le dikgwetlho tse o lebaganeng le tsona ba bangwe ba tla simolola go phuthologa go feta mme ba arolelanele a bona

SourceText: It’s okay if you don’t want to share at that time. You can choose to share how you’re feeling at a later time once you feel calmer.
text: Go siame go sa batle go bua ka nako eo. O kgona go khetha go arolelanela maikutlo a gago moragonyana fa o sena go ritibala.

text: Bagolo ba lepane le batho go ba dirisetsa mesola ya thobalano mo sohiale mmediyeng, metshameko, le dipolatefomo tsa melaetsa.

SourceText: • Teens sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos of themselves.
text: Go arolelanela tshedimosetso ya sebele le ditshwantsho kgotsa dibidiyo tsa thobalano.

SourceText: • Cyberbullying from other young people and strangers.
text: Kgokontsho ka inthanete go tswa go batho ba bangwe le batho ba re sa ba itseng.

SourceText: 2. Tech fixes to protect your children online:
text: 2. Dipaakanyo tsa setegeniki to sireletsa bana ba gago mo inthaneteng:

SourceText: This does not mean we should ban our children from spending time online. It just means that we need to learn how to protect them in a new world.
text: Seno ga se kae gore re tshwanela go kganela bana ba rona go nna le nako mo inthaneteng. Se kaya gore re tlhoka go ithuta gore re ba sireletsa jang mo lefatsheng le leswa.

SourceText: 5. Build open communication and trusting relationships
text: 5. Aga dikamano tse di phuthologo le botsalano jo bo nang le botshephegi

SourceText: Tell your children that if they experience something online (or anywhere) that makes them feel upset, uncomfortable, or scared, they can talk to you and you will not get mad or punish them.
text: Bolelela bana ba gago fa ba itemogela sengwe mo inthaneteng (kgotsa gongwe fela) se se ka kgopisang, se ba tshwenya, kgotsa se ba tshosa, ba ka go bolelela mme o ka se ba galefele kgotsa go ba otlhaya.

SourceText: Report to INHOPE Hotlines and IWF portals and the Child Helpline in your country to get support if you or your children experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.
text: Bega go INHOPE Hotlines le dipotale tsa IWF go bona tshegetso fa o itemogela tirisodikgoka ya mafaratlhatlha kgotsa dilo dingwe tse di sa amogelesegeng.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn another way to protect your child online:
text: Ka kopo tlhopha nomoro e nngwe fa o batla go ithuta tsela e nngwe ya go sireletsa ngwana wa gago mo inthaneteng:

SourceText: Here is a comic on discussing online activities with your child
text: Fano ke khomiki go tlotla ka ga ditirwana tsa inthanete le ngwana wa gago

SourceText: Parent: "Shani, have you done your homework?"
text: Motsadi: “Shani, a o dirile tirogae ya gago?" :

SourceText: Child: "Just a minute, I'm finishing this tiktok video"
text: Ngwana: "Ke etla , ke feleletsa bidio eno ya tiktok"

SourceText: Parent: "You are a really great dancer! Tell me about why you like it."
text: Motsadi: “Tota o kgeleke ya go bina! Mpolelele gore goreng o go rata"

SourceText: Child: "All my friends are on it. I have more than 600 likes and 120 followers."
text: Ngwana: "Ditsala tsa me tsotlhe di dira jalo. Ke na le batho ba ba e ratang ba le 600 ba ba ntshalang morago ba le 120.”

SourceText: Parent: "I’m proud of how well you dance, Joey. But we need to make sure you are safe on this. I know your friends look at TikTok, but with an open account there are also paedophiles who look at videos of teenagers. Paedophiles are older people who want to attack young children and teens."
text: Motsadi: "Ke motlotlo ka fa o binang bontle ka teng, Joey . Mme re tshwanetse go tlhomamisa gore o sireletsegile. Ke itse gore ditsala tsa gago di lebelela Tiktok, mme di dirisa akhaonto e e sa sireletsegang, go na le batho bangwe ba ba lebang dibidio tsa basha gore ba kgotsofatse keletso ya bone ya thobalano. Batho bano ba ba dirisang bana go ikgotsofatsa ka tsa thobalano ke bagolo ba ba batlang go tlhasela bana le basha.”

SourceText: Parent: "Let’s look together online at how we can keep this fun for you but also safe. Look – you can make your account private and control who follows you. So you can accept people you know but not strangers. Can we make a rule together that you can use TikTok but with a private account? I trust you to know who to accept!"
text: Motsadi: "Tla re lebe inthanete mmogo re bone gore re ka dira jang gore e go itumedise le gore gape e sireletsege. Bona - o ka kgona go dira gore akhaonto ya gago e nne khupamarama le go laola batho ba ba go salang morago. Ka jalo o ka amogela batho ba o ba itseng e seng batho ba sele. A re ka dira molao mmogo o o ka o dirisang TikTok, mme e le ka akhaonto ya khupamarama? Ke a go tshepa gore o tla amogela batho ba o ba itseng!”

SourceText: Parent: "I’m proud of you Shalini..."
text: Motsadi: "Ke motlotlo ka wena Shalini"

SourceText: Involve @fields.child_nickname in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.
text: Tsenyeletsa 1 go tlhama ditumalano tsa lelapa tsa thekenoloji ka ga tiriso e e itekanetseng ya didiriswa tsa tlhaeletsano.

text: Tlhama dibaka le dinako mo ntlong ya gago tse go ga dirisiweng didiriswa tsa inthanete.

SourceText: (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).
text: (go ja, go tshameka, tiro ya sekolo, le go robala).

SourceText: Help @fields.child_nickname learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers – some people are not who they say they are!
text: Thusa 1 gore a tshole jang tshedimosetso ya sebele e le poraefete, segolo go batho ba o sa ba itseng. - batho bangwe ga se seo ba reng ke sona!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Remind your children that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).
text: Gopotsa bana ba gago gore se se pegiwang mo inthaneteng se nna mo inthaneteng (melaetsa, ditshwantsho le dibidiyo).

SourceText: Actively supervise children’s time online, including computers, smartphones, and tablets.
text: Nna matlhagatlhaga mo go laoleng nako ya bana ba gago mo inthaneteng, go tsenyeletsa dikhomphiuthara, mesokelwatsebeng, le dithabolete.

SourceText: Help your child learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers – some people are not who they say they are!
text: Thusa ngwana wa gago gore a tshole jang tshedimosetso ya sebele e le poraefete, segolo go batho ba o sa ba itseng. - batho bangwe ga se seo ba reng ke sona!

SourceText: 4. Spend time with your child or teen online
text: 4. Go fetsa nako le ngwana kgotsa mosha wa gagoe mo inthanete

text: Itse gore 1 o itemogela lefatshe la dijitale jang.

SourceText: It‘s hard to feel positive when our kids or teenagers are driving us crazy. We often end up saying “Stop doing that!” But children are much more likely to do what we ask if we give them positive instructions and lots of praise for what they do right.
text: Ga go bonolo go nna le tshepo fa bana ba rona kgotsa basha ba re kopanya ditlhogo. Gantsi re feleletsa re rile “Gontse!” Fela bana ba feleletsa ba dira se re se kopang mo go bona fa re ba neela ditaelo tse di siameng le go ba akgolela se ba se dirileng ka nepo.

SourceText: Here's a positive video to help you get your children to follow your instructions more often!
text: Fano ke bidiyo go go thusa go dira gore bana ba gago ba latele ditaelo ka gale!

SourceText: Here's a positive audio message to help you get your children to follow your instructions more often!
text: Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo go go thusa go dira gore bana ba gago ba latele ditaelo ka gale!

SourceText: Here are 4 steps to help you get your children to follow your instructions more often:
text: Fano ke dikgato di le 4 go go thusa go dira gore bana ba gago ba latele ditaelo tsa gago ka gale.

SourceText: 1. Get their attention
text: 1. Dira gore bago eletlhoko

SourceText: 2. Be positive, specific, and realistic
text: 2. Leba dilo ka tsela e e siameng, o lolame, le go kgonega

SourceText: 3. One instruction at a time
text: 3. Neelana ka taelo e le nngwe ka nako

SourceText: 4. Praise them for doing it!
text: 4. Ba akgolele go e dira!

SourceText: To learn more about one of these steps, type "1" to "4". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Go ithuta go le gontsi ka nngwe ya dikgato tse, tlanya “1” go ya go “4”.Go ithuta go le gontsi ka nngwe ya dikakantsho tse, tlanya “1” go ya go “4”. Tlanya “N” go emisa kakantsho e.

SourceText: Step 3. Give Instructions One at a Time
text: Kgato 3. Neelana ka Ditaelo E le Nngwe ka Nako

SourceText: Children are much more likely to do what you ask if you break things up into smaller steps.
text: Bana ba kgona go dira se o se kopang fa o kgaoganya dilo ka dikgato tse dinnye.

SourceText: Step 4. Praise Your Children When They Follow Instructions
text: Kgato 4. Akgola bana ba gago fa ba Latela ditaelo!

SourceText: They will feel good about it and be more likely to follow instructions in the future!
text: Ba tla ikutlwa monate ka ga se mme ba tla latela ditaelo mo isagong!

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to get your children to follow instructions more often:
text: Ka kopo tlhopha nomoro e nngwe fa o batla go ithuta go feta ka ga go dira gore bana ba gago ba latele ditaelo ka gale:

SourceText: Can your child actually do what you are asking them? It is very hard for a child to keep quiet inside for a whole day but maybe they can keep quiet for 15 minutes.
text: A ngwana wa gago o kgona go dira se o se kopang mo go ene? Go boima tota go ngwana go didimala ka fa ntlong letsatsi lotlhe fela a ka kgona go didimala metsotso e le 15.

SourceText: Here is a comic on using positive words and praise with your teen.
text: Fano ke khomiki go dirisa mafoko a a siameng le go akgola ngwana wa gago.

SourceText: Teen: “Can I watch some T.V. after dinner?”
text: * “Mosha”: “A nka bogela TV morago ga dijo?”

SourceText: Parent: “When you clear the table, you can watch an hour of T.V.”
text: Motsadi: “Fa o phuthile tafole, o ka bogela TV ura.”

SourceText: Parent: “I really appreciate it when you help clean up after dinner. Thank you, Dylan”
text: Motsadi: “Nka leboga tota fa o ka thusa go phepafatsa morago ga dijo. “Ke a leboga, Dylan"

SourceText: Parent and teen watching T.V. together.
text: Motsadi le mosha ba bogela TV mmogo.

SourceText: Step 2. Be Specific, Positive, and Realistic!
text: Kgato 2. Leba dilo ka tsela e e siameng, o lolame, le go kgonega

SourceText: Household rules can help keep our children safe from potential dangers both inside the house and in the community. They also help children to know what kind of behaviour is expected from them.
text: Melao ya fa gae e ka thusa go tshola bana ba rona ba sirleletsegile go dikotsi tse di kgonegang mo ntlong le mo baaging. Gape e ka thusa bana go itse gore ke mofuta ofe wa maitsholo o o lebeletsweng go tswa go bona.

SourceText: Hello @fields.user_name! Today's Parenting Tip is about how we can involve our children in creating consistent household rules.
text: Dumela. Kakantso ya gompieno ka ga botsadi e ka ga gore re ka tsenyeletsa jang bana ba rona mo go tlhameng melao ya fa gae e e sa fetofetogeng.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Hello! Today's Parenting Tip is about how we can involve our children in creating consistent household rules.
text: Dumela! Kakantso ya gompieno ka ga botsadi e ka ga gore re ka tsenyeletsa jang bana ba rona mo go tlhameng melao ya fa gae e e sa fetofetogeng.

SourceText: Household rules can help keep our children safe from potential dangers both inside the house and in the community. They also help children to know what kind of behaviour is expected from them.
text: Melao ya fa gae e ka thusa go tshola bana ba rona ba sirleletsegile go dikotsi tse di kgonegang mo ntlong le mo baaging. Gape e ka thusa bana go itse gore ke mofuta ofe wa maitsholo o o lebeletsweng go tswa go bona.

SourceText: Here's an audio message on how you can involve your children in establishing household rules.
text: Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo ka ga gore o ka tsenyeletsa jang bana ba gago go tlhameng melao ya fa gae.

SourceText: Here's is a video on how you can involve your children in establishing household rules.
text: Fano ke bidiyo ka ga gore o ka tsenyeletsa jang bana ba gago go tlhameng melao ya fa gae.

SourceText: Here are some simple tips on how you can make household rules with your children and teens:
text: Fano ke dikakantsho dingwe tse di bonolo ka ga gore o ka tlhama jang melao mmogo le bana le basha ba gago:

SourceText: • Involve your child in establishing household rules.
text: Tsenyeletsa ngwana wa gago mo go tlhameng melao ya fa gae.

SourceText: • Make your household rules clear and specific.
text: Dira gore melao ya legae la gago e sedisege le go nna e e lolameng.

SourceText: • Make sure your child understands the reasons why you are establishing a household rule.
text: Netefatsa gore ngwana wa gago o tlhaloganya mabaka gore goreng o tlhama molao fa gae.

SourceText: • Make your household rules fair and realistic (just like instructions).
text: Netefatsa gore melao ya legae la gago ga e gobelele mme e a kgonega ( fela jaaka ditaelo).

SourceText: • Praise and simple incentives can help support your child in following a household rule.
text: Kakgolo le dikatso tsdi bonolo di kgona go thusa go tshegetsa ngwana go latela molao wa fa gae.

SourceText: • Add only 1 household rule at a time.
text: Tsenya molao o le 1 wa fa gae ka nako.

SourceText: Children and teens are spending a lot more time online. Here is a comic on how you can create safe and healthy online habits like scheduling time online and offline.
text: Bana le basha ba rona ba nna nako e ntsi mo inthaneteng. Fano ke khomiki gore o ka tlhama jang ditlwaelo tse di sireletsegileng le go itekanela tsa inthanete tse di jaaka go baya nako ya inthanete le e e seng ya inthanete.

SourceText: Parent: “Jack, you have been spending a lot of time on your tablet. Why do you think I am concerned about that?”
text: Motsadi: “Jack, o ntse o tsaya nako e ntsi mo thaboleteng ya gago. O akanaya gore ke goreng ke tshwenngwa ke seo?

SourceText: Child: “Um…because I am not doing my schoolwork?”
text: Ngwana: “Um...gonne ga ke dire tiro ya me ya sekolo?”

SourceText: Parent: “Yes, that is one reason. It is important that you make the time for your schoolwork. I also like seeing you being more active. Maybe we can make a household rule about gadget use. What do you think would be a fair limit each day?”
text: Motsadi: “Ee, ke lebaka le lengwe. Go botlhokwa gore o dire nako ya go dira tiro ya sekolo. Gape nka rata go go bona o le matlhagatlhaga gore feta. Gongwe re ka nna le molao wa ka fa ge o o ka ga tiriso ya sediriswa sa tlhaeletsano. O akanya gore tekanyetso e e siameng ya letsatsi le letsatsi e ka nna e kanakang?”

SourceText: Child: “Um…two hours a day?”
text: Ngwana: “...Um ..diura tse pedi ka letsatsi?”

SourceText: Parent: “Hmmm…I think that might be too much time. You have so much else to do every day.”
text: Motsadi: “Hmmm...Ke akanya gore e tla bo e le ntsi go feta. Go na le dilo tse dintsi tse dingwe tse o tla di dirang.”

SourceText: Child: “How about one hour for fun and one hour for learning?
text: Ngwana: “Go ka nna jang ka ura e le nngwe ya go iitumedisa le e le nngwe ya go ithuta?

SourceText: Parent: “That sounds reasonable. I would also like you to do your schoolwork before using any gadgets. So from now on, the household rule is that you do your schoolwork before using gadgets and that you can have 1 hour for free time and 1 hour for educational activities. Okay?”
text: Motsadi: “Go a utlwala. Gape nka rata fa o ka dira tiro ya gago ya sekolo pele o dirisa didiriswa dingwe fela. Go tloga jaanong, molao wa fa gae ke gore o dira tiro ya gago ya sekolo pele o dirisa didiriswa dingwe le gore o tla nna le ura e le 1 o ikhuditse mme ura e le 1 go ditirwana tsa thuto. A wa nkutlwa?

SourceText: Child: “Okay.”
text: Ngwana: A wa nkutlwa?

SourceText: Well done @fields.user_name! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Over the next few days, try to create one household rule with your child. Remember when you involve your child in making household rules, they are more likely to follow them. It's a recipe for success!

SourceText: Today's tip is about how we can help to protect our children.
text: Kakantsho ya gompieno e ka ga gore re ka sireletsa jang bana ba rona.

SourceText: The idea of talking to children about abuse can be scary. We don't know what to say. But there are some simple things that can help them understand when it is not OK to be touched, and that they can tell you if something ever happens.
text: Kakanyo ya go bua le bana ka tshotlakako e ka tshosa. Ga re itse gore re reng” Fela gona le dilo dingwe tse di bonolo tse di ka ba thusang go tlhaloganya fa go sa SIMAM go kgongwa, le gore ba ka go bolelela fa go direga sengwe.

SourceText: When you are walking or doing something together it can be easier to chat.
text: Fa lo tsamaya kgotsa lo dira sengwe mmogo go nna bonolo go tlotla.

SourceText: Do you want to learn more about how to protect your child from abuse?
text: A o batla go ithuta go le gontsi ka ga go sireletsa ngwana wa gago go tshotlakako?

SourceText: Here are 3 things that you should make sure your child knows to protect them from abuse:
text: Fano ke dilo tse 3 tse o tshwanetseng go netfatsa gore ngwana wa gago o a di itse go itshireletsa go tshotlakako:

SourceText: 1. Learn about private parts
text: 1. Ithute ka ga dikarolo tse di poraefete

SourceText: 2. Your body belongs to you
text: 2. Mmele wa gago ke wa gago

SourceText: 3. Bad secrets should be told
text: 3. Diphiri tse di bosula di a begiwa

SourceText: Type "1" to "3" to learn more about these tips. Type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Go ithuta go le gontsi ka ga dikakantsho tse, tlanya “1” go ya go “3”. Tlanya “N” go emisa kakantsho e.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to protect your child from abuse:
text: Ka kopo tlhopha nomoro e nngwe fa o batla go ithuta go feta ka ga go sireletsa ngwana wa gago go tshotlakako le ngwana wa gago:

SourceText: 3. Bad secrets should be told.
text: 3. Diphiri tse di bosula di a begiwa

SourceText: Your children should tell you if there is a secret that makes them feel worried. You will not be angry. Only nice secrets - like a surprise birthday party - should be kept secret.
text: Bana ba gago ba tshwanetse go go bolelela fa gona le sephiri se se mo tshwenyang. O ka se galefe. Ke diphiri tse dintle fela - jaaka go direla mongwe moletlo ya matsalo a sa itse - go ka tsholwa e le sephiri.

SourceText: The parts of their body that go under people's underwear or a swimsuit are private parts. It is not OK for other people to touch or to ask to look at them, or ask them to look at or touch theirs.
text: Dikarolo tsa mebele ya bona tse di tsenngwana ka fa tlase ga diaparo tse batho ba di aparang ka fa tlase ga diaparo kgotsa diaparo tsa go thuma ke dikarolo tse di poraefete. batho  Ga go a SIAMA gore batho ba bangwe ba go tshware kgotsa ba kope go go okomela, kgotsa o kope go okomela kgotsa go kgoma tsa bona.

SourceText: If someone tries to touch your children's private parts they must say NO and tell a grown up that they trust.
text: Fa mongwe a leka go kgoma dikarolo tsa poraefete tsa bana ba gago ba tshwanetse go re NNYAA le go itsise mogolo yo ba mo tshepang.

SourceText: Stress from caregiving can make us angry. Here is how we can maintain control and keep calm.
text: Kgatelelo ya maikutlo go tswa mo go tlhokomeleng e kgona go re galefisa. Fano ke gore re ka tswelela go laola le go ritibala jang.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you maintain control and keep calm when you get angry.
text: Fano ke bidiyo go go thusa go tswelela go laola le go ritibala jang fa o galefa.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you maintain control and keep calm when you get angry.
text: Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo go go thusa go tswelela go laola le go ritibala jang fa o galefa.

SourceText: Think about what makes you angry? When does it happen? How do you normally react?
text: Akanya ka gore ke eng se se dirang gore o galefe? Go direga leng? Gantsi o itshwara jang?

SourceText: Prevent anger from starting in the first place. Get some sleep or rest when you are tired. Try to eat something when you are hungry. Ask someone for support when you are feeling alone.
text: O seka wa letla kgalefo go simolola. Robala kgotsa o ikhutse fa o lapile. Leka go ja sengwe fa o tshwerwe ke tlala. Kopa tshegetso ya mongwe fa o ikutlwa o le esi.

SourceText: Here are some things that can prevent bad things from happening when you are angry:
text: Fano ke dilo dingwe tse di ka thibelang dilo tse di bosula go direga fa o galefile:

SourceText: 1. Cut back on drinking alcohol or don’t drink, especially when the kids are awake.
text: 1. Fokotsa bojalwa kgotsa se nwe, segolo fa bana ba tsogile.

SourceText: 2. Do you have weapons or things that can be used to hurt others? Lock them up, hide them or take them out of the home.
text: 2. A o na le dibetsa kgotsa dilo tse di ka dirisiwang go gobatsa ba bangwe? Di tswalele, di fitlhe kgotsa o di ntshe mo ntlong.

SourceText: 3. It’s ok to have your children stay somewhere safe or take them to a place where they can get help.
text: 3. go siame go letla bana go ya go nna gongwe kwa go bolokegileng kgotsa o ba ise kwa lefelong leo ba ka bonang thuso gona.

SourceText: Hello @fields.user_name! We love our children and teenagers, but stress from caregiving and money can make us angry. Here is how we can maintain control and keep calm.

SourceText: Well done @fields.user_name! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Over the next few days, take 10 deep breaths or do some exercise when you feel angry. Learning how to manage your anger can help you avoid some difficult situations.
text: O dirile sentle. O tsentse kgono e le nngwe go Kaedi ya Botsadi beke eno. Mo malatsing a a tlang a a mmalwa, hemela kwa teng ga 20 kgotsa o ikatise ka mokgwa mongwe fa o ikutlwa o galefa. Go ithuta gore o laola jang kgalefo ya gago go kgona go go thusa go efoga maemo mangwe a a masisi.

SourceText: Great job! You should be proud of yourself! Research shows that every time you control your anger in front of your child, you increase your child's brain development.
text: Tiro entle! O tshwanetse go nna motlotlo ka wena! Patlisiso e bontshitse gore nako nngwe le nngwe fa o laola kgalefo ya gago fa pele ga ngwana wa gago, o oketsa tlhalobogo ya boboko jwa ngwana.

SourceText: It is completely normal to experience this challenge. Next time you feel yourself getting angry try to manage this by taking deep breaths in. This can allow you to relax and reduce stress, which can help with managing your emotions. Every time you do this, you increase your child's brain development!
text: Go tlwaelegile go itemogela seno. Nako e e tlang fa o ikutlwa o galefa, leka go hemela kwa teng. Seno se ka go thusa go ritibala le go fokotsa kgatelelo, seo se ka thusang ka go laola maikutlo. Nako nngwe le nngwe fa o dira se, o oketsa tlhabologo ya boboko jwa ngwana!

SourceText: Hi! Managing anger can be really difficult. Take a break when you feel you are getting angry at your children or someone else.
text: Dumela! Go laola kgalefo ga ka nna thata. Ema fa o ikutlwa o galefela bana ba gago kgotsa mongwe o sele.

SourceText: Go somewhere else for 5 minutes to regain control of your emotions. If you have safe outdoor space, go outside. You can get through this!
text: Gore maikutlo a gago a boe ya golo gongwe o tseye metsotso e ka nna 5. Fa o na le lefelo la ko ntle le le sireletsegileng, tsamaya o ye ko ntle.  O tla fenya seno!

SourceText: Did you know that research shows if you control your anger or do something positive, you increase your child's brain development? Be proud of yourself when you manage to do it!
text: A o a itse gore patlisiso e bontshitse gore fa o laola kgalefo ya gago kgotsa o dira sengwe se se siameng, o oketsa kgolo ya boboko jwa ngwana wa gago? Itlotlomatse fa o kgona go dira jalo!

SourceText: Here's a video to help you manage your anger!
text: Fano ke bidiyo go go thusa go laola kgalefo ya gago.

SourceText: When you take care of yourself, you take care of your children. We all need to connect. Try to talk to friends, family, and other support networks every day. If it has been a while since you reached out to someone, do it now!
text: Fa o itlhokomela, o tlhokomela le bana ba gago. Rotlhe re tlhoka go ikgolaganya. Leka go bua le ditsala, balelapa, le netweke tse dingwe tsa tshegetso tsatsi le letsatsi. Fa ele gore ke kgale o sa bue le mongwe, bua le bone jaanong!

SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are not having a good day. It is completely normal to be going through a difficult time now. Remember that you are not alone. Here is an activity that might also help...
text: Ke maswabi go utlwa gore gompieno go thatanyana. Go tlwaelegile ka gotlhe go bo o le mo nakong e e boima gajaana. Gopola gore ga o nosi. Fano ke tirwana e e ka go thusang...

SourceText: Make a list of healthy activities that you like to do. Here are some suggestions:
text: Dira lenaane la dilo tsa boitekanelo jo bo siameng tse o ratang go di dira. Dikakantsho dingwe ke tseno:

SourceText: • Listening to your favourite music
text: * Go reetsa mmino o o ratang

SourceText: • Going for a walk (if allowed)
text: * Go tsamaya ka maoto (fa go letleletswe)

SourceText: • Doing some exercise
text: * Go ikatisa

SourceText: • Drinking a cup of tea by yourself
text: *Go nwa kopi ya tee o le nosi

SourceText: • Calling up a friend
text: * Go leletsa tsala

SourceText: • Singing, dancing, praying, or reading
text: * Go opela, go bina, go rapela, kgotsa go bala

SourceText: • Sitting in the sun with your eyes closed
text: *Go nna mo letsatsing o tswetse matlho

SourceText: • Watching your favourite T.V. show
text: * Go lebelela lenaneo la gago la T.V. le o le ratang

SourceText: Pick one and do it today!
text: Tlhopha e le nngwe mme o e dire gompieno!

SourceText: We would love to learn more about how we can improve these messages. Would you be willing to chat with us about your experience? You will receive a free data voucher if you are contacted for an interview!
text: Re ka rata go githuta go le gontsi ka ga gore re ka tokafatsa melaetsa eno. A o ka rata go buisana le rona ka ga maitemogelo a gago? O tla amogela boutshara ya mahala fa go ka ikopanngwa le wena go dira dipotsolotso!

SourceText: Thank you so much! Here is a link to sign up!

SourceText: Hello! Did you know that 3 is a magical number? Breathe in to the count of three and breathe out to the count of three. How do you feel now? Do you feel any different?
text: Dumela! A o ne o itse gore 3 ke nomoro ya motlholo? Hemela kwa teng o bala ka tharo mme o hemele kwa ntle o bala ka tharo. Jaanong o ikutlwa jang? A o utlwa pharologanyo?

SourceText: Here's an audio message to guide you through this activity!
text: Fano ke molaetsa wa odiyo go go kaela go dira go tirwana e!

SourceText: What are your three favourite foods? Can you name three things you can see right now?
text: Ke dijo dife tse tharo tse o di ratang? A o ka neela maina a dilo tse tharo tse o kgonang go di bona gajaana?

SourceText: Can you hear three sounds you can hear right now?
text: A o ka bitsa maina a medumo e o e utlwang gone jaanong?

SourceText: What are the three things you are grateful for right now?
text: Ke dilo dife tse tharo tse o di lebogelang gone jaanong?

SourceText: Breathe in to the count of three and breathe out to the count of three. How do you feel now? Do you feel any different?
text: Hemela kwa teng o bala ka tharo mme o hemele kwa ntle o bala ka tharo. Jaanong o ikutlwa jang? A o utlwa pharologanyo?

SourceText: Three is a magical number!
text: Tharo ke nomoro ya motlholo!

SourceText: Here's a video to guide through this activity!
text: Fano ke bidiyo go go kaela go dira tirwana e!

SourceText: Here is a song made just for parents like you.
text: Fano ke pina e e tlhametsweng fela batsadi ba ba jaaka wena.

SourceText: One-on-One Time with your children is free and fun. It makes children feel loved and secure, and shows them that they are important. It also increases their confidence and self-esteem!
text: Nako ya motho ka mongwe le bana ba gago e monate e bile ke mahala. E dira gore bana ba ikutlwe ba ratiwa le go babalesega, mme e ba lemosa gore ba botlhokwa.gago  Gape e oketsa boitshepho jwa bona le go itlotla!

SourceText: Here are 6 tips to make One-on-One Time with your child a success:
text: Fano le dikakantsho di le 6 tse di bonolo go atlega ka nako ya motho ka mong le ngwana wa gago:

SourceText: 1. Spend at least five minutes with each child
text: 1. Iphe bonnye metsotso e le metlhano le ngwana mongwe le mongwe

SourceText: 2. Give your child your full attention
text: 2. Neela ngwana wa gago nako e e tletseng

SourceText: 3. Let your child choose the activity
text: 3. Letla ngwana wa gago go tlhopha tiro

SourceText: 4. Follow your child's lead
text: 4. Latela ketelelopele ya ngwana wa gago

SourceText: 5. Use words to describe what your child is doing
text: 5. Dirisa mafoko go tlhalosa se ngwana wa gago a se dirang

SourceText: 6. Have fun!
text: 6. “Itumele!

SourceText: Even 5 minutes a day of quality time makes a big difference. If you have more than one child, try to find time for each individual child. It can be at the same time each day so your children look forward to it.
text: Le metsotso e le 5 fela ka letsatsi ya nako e e boleng e dira pharologanyo. Fa o na le bana ba fela a le monwe, leka go nna le nako ya ngwana mongwe le mongwe a le nosi. E ka nna nako e e tshwanang letsatsi le letsatsi gore ngwana wa gago a nne ka tebelelo.

SourceText: Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative.
text: Bana ba tlhoka go dira dilo ka nako ya bona. Leka go ba neela nako go utolola mme o nne pelotelele. Tshameka le go kopisa se ba se dirang fela leka go ba letla go itshimololela.

SourceText: Choosing builds their self confidence. If they want to do something that isn’t okay, then this is a chance to talk with them about this.
text: go tlhopha go aga go itshepa. Fa ba batla go dira sentle se se sa siamang, ke yone nako ya go bua le bona ka ga seo.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your child:
text: Ka kopo tlhopha nomoro e nngwe fa o batla go ithuta go feta ka ga go ipha nako ya motho ka mong le ngwana wa gago:

SourceText: Here is a comic about spending one-on-one time with your child! Try to follow your child's lead when spending time with them. It will help build self-confidence.
text: Fano ke motlae ka ga go nnako le nako ya motho ka mong le ngwana wa gago! Leka go latela ketelelopele ya ngwana wa gago fa o iphile nako le bona. Go thusa go aga boitshepo.

SourceText: Parent: "I see you are playing quietly with the lego with concentration, Alex."
text: Motsadi: “Ke a bona gore o itshamekela ka lego ka tsepo e kgolo, Alex.”

SourceText: Parent: "Wow! You are building such a tall and strong wall with those legos."
text: Motsadi: "Iyo! O aga lebota le le telele le le popota ka di lego tseo”.

SourceText: Child: "It is for cows."
text: Ngwana: “Ke la dikgomo”

SourceText: Parent: "It will keep the cow safe!"
text: Motsadi: “Le tla tshola dikgomo di bolokegile!”

SourceText: Child: "Now you can help me build a house for our family to sleep in!"
text: Ngwana: “Jaanong o ka kgona go nthusa go agela balelapa la rona ntlo eo ba tla robalang mo go yona!”

SourceText: Parent: "This house is going to keep our family warm and dry. You are such a good builder, Alex!"
text: Motsadi: “Ntlo eno e tla tshola balelapa la rona ba fithumetse le go oma. O moagi yo o tlhotlhwa tota, Alex!”

SourceText: Would you like some suggestions for activities to do with your child?
text: A o ka rata ditshitsinyo tsa ditirwana tse o ka di dirang le ngwana wa gago?

SourceText: Ask @fields.child_nickname what they would like to do. You can say, "I have 5 minutes to spend One-on-One Time with you, what would you like to do?"

SourceText: Ask your child what they would like to do. You can say, "I have 5 minutes to spend One-on-One Time with you, what would you like to do?"

SourceText: If @fields.child_nickname cannot think of anything, you can give them a choice of a couple things that you know they like.

SourceText: Listening to @fields.child_nickname is more important than talking to them at this time. If you do talk you should describe what @fields.child_nickname is doing. Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening!

SourceText: Here is a comic on spending one-on-time with your teen.
text: Fano ke khomiki ka ga go nnako le nako ya motho ka mong le mosha wa gago!

SourceText: One-on-One Time with your teen helps build a positive and trusting relationship. When you really notice them and listen to what they are saying and what they like, you make them feel valued and appreciated.
text: Nako ya motho ka mong le mosha wa gago e thusa go aga botsalano jo bo siameng go na le botshephegi. Fa o eletlhoko le go reetsa gore ba a reng le gore ba rata eng, o dira gore ba ikutlwe ba nale boleng le go ananneelwa.

SourceText: Here are 6 tips on how to make One-on-One Time a positive experience for you and your teen:
text: Fano ke dikakantsho di le 6 gore o ka nna le maitemogelo a a siameng a nako ya motho ka mong le mosha wa gago jang:

SourceText: 2. Let your teen choose the activity
text: 2. Letla mosha wa gago go tlhopha tirwana

SourceText: 3. Follow your teen's lead
text: 3. Latela ketelelopele ya mosha wa gago

SourceText: 4. Give your teen your full attention
text: 4. Neela mosha wa gago nako e e tletseng

SourceText: 5. Show your teen you are really listening
text: 5. Bontsha mosha wa gago gore o reeditse tota

SourceText: Fathers can have difficult relationships with their teenagers, it can be hard to find pleasure from spending time with them. Instead, we spend a lot of time disciplining them or complaining about how they are behaving.
text: Bontate ba ka nna le dikakamno tse di boima tota le basha ba bona, go ka nna boima go itumelela go nna le nako le bona. Ba ka nna le nako e ntsi go ba kgopolola kgotsa go ngongorega ka maitsholo a bona.

SourceText: Tell @fields.child_nickname that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. @fields.child_nickname might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy having this dedicated time with you!
text: Bolelela 1 gore o ka rata go ipha nalo le ene le gore a ka tlhopha se a ratang go se dira kgotsa go bua ka ga sona. 1 a ka akanya gore go a gakgamatsa kwa ntlheng fela o tla itumelela go nna le nako e e beetsweng ene mmogo le wena!

SourceText: Tell your teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. Your teen might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy having this dedicated time with you!
text: Bolelela mosha wa gago gore o ka rata go senya nako le ene le gore ba tlhophe gore ba batla go dira eng kgotsa go bua ka eng. Ba ka tsaya seno se sa tlwaelega ko tshimologong, mme ba tla itumelela nako eno le wena!

SourceText: Try to follow @fields.child_nickname's lead during One-on-One Time. Accept their suggestions. Remember this is @fields.child_nickname's activity. Your job is to show an interest and say something nice.
text: Leka go latela ketelelopele ya 1 ka Nako ya motho ka Mong. Amogela ditshitsinyo. Gopola gore ke tirwana ya 1 Tiro ya gago ke go bontsha kgetlhego le go bua sengwe se sentle.

SourceText: Set aside a specific time to spend One-on-One Time with @fields.child_nickname each day. Choose a time when you and @fields.child_nickname will not be interrupted and when @fields.child_nickname does not have something else that they want to do, like watching TV or playing with phones.

SourceText: Set aside a specific time to spend One-on-One Time with your teen each day. Choose a time when you and your teen will not be interrupted and when your teen does not have something else that they want to do, like watching TV or playing with phones.
text: Beela thoko nako e e rileng go nna le nako ya motho ka mong le mosha wa gago letsatsi le letsatsi. Tlhopha nako eo wena le mosha wa gago le ka se kgorelediweng le fa mosha wa gago a sena sepe se a ratang go se dira, jaaka go bogela TV kgotsa go tshameka ka founu.

SourceText: Try to do something different than watching TV or playing with a tablet/phone. However, you may need to at first join @fields.child_nickname and watch their favourite TV programme with them. They may feel comfortable doing other activities with time.
text: Lekang go dira sengwe se se farologaneng go na le go bogela TV kgotsa go tshameka ka founu/thabolete. Le fa go le jalo, o ka tlhoka go golagana le 1 mme la bogela lenaneo la gagwe la mmamoratwa la TV mmogo. Ba ka phuthologela go dira ditirwana tse dingwe fa nako e ntse e ya.

SourceText: You can even try rephrasing back what @fields.child_nickname says when they speak to you. For example, when @fields.child_nickname says, “This math problem is really hard,” you can say, “Yeah, I see that you are finding it difficult.” It shows you are really listening to them and will make them feel supported.
text: O ka leka go e bua ka mokgwa o mongwe go na le ka moo 1 a e buang fa a bua le wena. Sekao, fa 1 a re, “Palo eno ya Mmetshe e popota tota,”, o ka re “Ee, ke a bona o fitlhela e le popota.” Go bontsha gore o mo reeditse tota mme o tla dira gore a ikutlwe a na le tshegetso.

SourceText: Quick tip: It can be difficult to know how to talk to your children about something like COVID-19, especially since we are learning about it too.
text: Kakantsho ka bonako: Go ka nna bokete go itse gore o bue jang le bana ba gago ka ga sengwe sa go tshwana le COVID-19, segolo gonne le wena o santse o ithuta ka ga sona.

SourceText: The important thing is to be open and listen to your children. Be honest and supportive. Show them that you care.
text: Sa botlhokwa ke gore o reetse bana ba gago le go phuthologa mmogo le bona. Bua nnete mme o neelane ka tshegetso Ba bontshe gore o a ba kgathalela.

SourceText: Quick tip: It is really hard to help our children continue learning when schools are closed or part-open. One thing that might be helpful is to try and set up a daily schedule that includes time for schoolwork and time for fun.
text: Kakantsho ka bonako: Go tota go le boima go thusa bana ba rona go tswelela go ithuta fa dikolo di tswetswe kgotsa di butswe halofo. Selo sengwe se se ka thusang ke go leka go beela nako thoko e e akaretsang nako ya tiro ya sekolo le ya go itapoloa letsatsi le letsatsi.

SourceText: Quick tip: Caring for yourself is really important. Take five deep breaths when you feel overwhelmed. Try talking to a friend, or doing something relaxing for yourself? You deserve it!
text: Kakantsho ka bonako: Go itlhokomela go botlhokwa tota. Hemela kwa teng fa o ikutlwa o tlalana. Leka go bua le tsala, kgotsa go dira sengwe go repa? O tshwanelwa ke seno!

SourceText: Quick tip: All children, including those living with disabilities, need love, respect and time especially at difficult times.
text: Kakantsho ka bonako:  Bana botlhe, go tsenyeletsa le ba ba tshelang ka bogole, ba tlhoka lerato, tlhompho le nako segolo mo dinako tse di bokete.

SourceText: Quick tip: This is a stressful time for all of us. When a problem comes up, talk about it together! What is the problem exactly? What different solutions are there and what are the consequences of one? That way, you can find a solution that can be OK for everyone.
text: Kakantsho ka bonako: Ke nako e e bosula go rona rotlhe. Fa bothata bo tlhaga, buisanang mmogo ka bona! Bothata ke eng sentlentle? Go na le ditharabololo dife tse di farologaneng mme ditlamorago tsa tsona ke dife? Ka tsela e, le ka bona tharabololo e e ka nnang e e SIAMENG go botlhe.

SourceText: Quick tip: It is normal to be stressed about money. Talk to your children about how much money comes in and what you spend money on as a family each month. When everyone sees where the money goes, it is easier to agree on where you can save money together!
text: Kakantsho ka bonako: Go tlwaelegile go tshwenyega ka madi. Bua le bana ba gago gore go tsena bokae le gore le dirisa bokae le le lelapa kgwedi le kgwedi. Fa mongwe le mongwe a bona gore madi a dira jang, go bonolo gore dumalana gore mmogo le ka boloka madi mo go eng!

SourceText: Here's another tip! A daily stress-reducer can help us with parenting, and make us feel better.  Let’s start with 30 seconds of relaxation for yourself. You deserve this!
text: Fano ke kakantsho e nngwe! Phokotso ya kgateleleo ya letsatsi le letsatsi e kgona go re thusa ka botsadi, le go dira gore re ikutlwe botoka.  Tla re simolole ka metsotswana e le 30 go re o ikhutse wena. O tshwanelwa ke seno!

SourceText: Would you like to receive this activity now?
text: A o ka rata go amogela tirwana e jaanong?

SourceText: That's Ok! You can always type "Relax" whenever you want an activity to help you with stress.
text: Go siame! Gopola ka gale gore o kgona go tlanya “Repa” nako nngwe le nngwe fa o tlhoka tirwana go ithusa go repa.

SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are finding this challenging. If you think your child is accessing information online which is not age appropriate discuss with them why you have concerns, and why you are not comfortable. Try having your child involved in the conversation and get them to share their views. Having an open conversation is important, and children are more likely to stick to decisions if they feel that they are fair and their opinions have been heard.
text: Re itshwarele go bo o fitlhela seno se gwetlha. SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are finding this challenging. If you are getting angry because @fields.child_nickname won’t stop crying, it’s okay to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit and take a quick pause. Taking a pause will help you respond better. Check on @fields.child_nickname every 5-10 minutes.

SourceText: Thanks! One helpful way is to create a map with your child or teen that identifies the safe and unsafe places in the community. Here are 3 simple steps:

SourceText: That is a completely normal experience, it is shocking to learn that people who are close to us and who we trust may be a danger to our children. Find someone you can talk to about this, perhaps a friend or support service, so you can get the support your need. Remember to take a pause when you are stressed.

Batla mongwe yo o ka buang le ene ka seno, gongwe tsala kgotsa tirelo ya tshegetso, gore o kgone go nna le tshegetso e o e tlhokang. Gopola go ema go se kae fa o tshwenyegile mo maikutlong.

SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are finding this challenging. Our children may know things about our communities and technology that we are not aware of. text: Re itshwarele go bo o fitlhela seno se gwetlha. Bana ba rona ba ka itse dilo ka tikologo ya rona le thekenoloji tse rona re sa di itseng. SourceText: It is difficult to know every detail about our communities. Involve another family member or friend in your mapping activity. You can even visit some of the services available and ask what they do. The more we know, the better we can keep our families safe!

SourceText: It is completely normal to experience this. Try creating a safe space to talk with @fields.child_nickname when you are both calm. Listen to their thoughts about why they feel a certain place is safe, and then share your thoughts on why you feel it is not safe. Think about making a rule together that allows them to still have fun but stay safe. Our children will listen better when we speak to them calmly.
text: Go tlwaelegile go itemogela seno. Dira lefelo le le sireletsegileng la go bua le 1 fa lo kgobile makgwafo. Reetsa dikakanyo tsa mosha wa gago ka gore goreng ba akanya gore bara e sireletsegile, mme o abelane dikakanyo tsa gago gore goreng o ikutlwa gore bara ga e a sireletsega. Akanya ka go dira molao mmogo o o ba letlelelang gore ba ijese monate mme gone ba sireletsegile. Bana barona ba reetsa botoka fa re bua le bone re kgobile makgwafo.

SourceText: 1. Close your eyes.

SourceText: If you find yourself always having to give consequences to your children for behaving badly, you might need to spend more positive time with them. It will help them feel more loved and secure...and you less stressed!

SourceText: Sometimes, our children can have very violent tantrums when they do not get their way, especially if they are used to it. Try to move your child to a place where they will not hurt themselves or others. You may need to firmly hold your child while ignoring their behaviour - but only do this if you can remain calm and make sure you are not hurting them! Eventually, your child will calm down.
text: Nako dingwe, bana ba rona ba kgona go nna  matepe a a dikgoka fa ba sa bone se ba se batlang, segolo fa ba setse ba tlwaetse. Leka go isa ngwana wa gago kwa lefelong leo ba ka se ikgobatseng kgotsa ba bangwe. O ka tlhoka go tshwara ngwana wa gago fa o ikgatholosa maitsholo a bona - fela dira seo fa o kgona go ritibala le go netefatsa gore ga ba ikgobatse! Kwa bokhutlong, ngwana wa gago o tla ritibala.

SourceText: It is completely normal to feel uncomfortable, confused, or even scared. Everyone feels this way at times. The WHO and UNICEF and websites and local COVID-19 hotlines are great places to find advice on how you and your family can stay safe during COVID-19.
text: Go tlwaelegile go ikutlwa o sa namatshega, o tshwenyegile kgotsa o tshogile. Botlhe ba ikutlwa jaana nako le nako. WHO le UNICEF le diweposaete le megala ya selegae ya COVID-19 ke mafelo a a siameng go bona kgakololo gore wena le balelapa la gago ba kgone go sireletsega mo nakong ya COVID-19.

SourceText: It is completely normal for children to act out or react negatively during these unprecedented times. Give them space to share how they are feeling and let them know you are there for them. You can also try distracting them with fun activities and games.

text: Dumela! Ngwana mongwe le mongwe o na le maitsholo a a kgetlho nako dingwe. A o ka rata dikakantsho dingwe go samagana le maitsholo a?

SourceText: That is okay! You can always access parenting tips by typing "Help".
text: Seo se siame! O ka etela dikakantsho tsa botsadi gape ka go tlanya “Thusa”.

SourceText: Remember that One-on-One time, praise for being good, and consistent routines will also help reduce difficult behaviours.
text: Gopola gore nako ya motho ka mong, akgola go itshola sentle, mme mkgwatlwaelo e e lolameng e tla thusa go fokotsa maitsholo a a bosula.

SourceText: Hi @fields.user_name! How are you feeling?
text: Dumela @fields.user_name! O ikutlwa jang?
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Hi! How are you feeling?
text: Dumela! O ikutlwa jang?

SourceText: Lovely! Take a breath just to appreciate the moment.
text: Bontle! Hema jalo go ananeela motsi.

SourceText: Marvellous! When you feel good, it is easier to keep it positive throughout the day.
text: Matshetshe! Fa o ikutlwa sentle, go bonolo go go tswelela go nna le tshepo letsatsi lotlhe.

SourceText: Everyone has challenging days, but you do not need experience it alone. Try reaching out to family and friends for support.
text: Botlhe ba na le malatsi a a gwetlhang tota, fela se mekameknae le ona o le nosi. Leka go bua le balelapa le ditsala go bona tshegetso.

SourceText: It is completely normal to feel okay. You do not need to feel great everyday.
text: Go tlwaelegile go ikutlwa o siame. Ga o tlhoke go ikutlwa sentle letsatsi le letsatsi.

SourceText: Life is filled with ups and downs. It is important to recognise and accept how are you feeling. Please remember to be kind to yourself.
text: Botshelo bo tletse dilwana. Go botlhokwa go lemoga le go amogela gore o ikutlwa jang. Gopola go ineneketsa.

SourceText: Thank you for sharing! All feelings, whether they are good, bad, or okay are welcome here.
text: Ke lebogela go bo o mpoleletse! Maikutlo otlhe, a siame, a le bosula, kgotsa a le mantle a amogelesega mono.

SourceText: We are made to feel different emotions, and learning to identify them is a great skill. Good job! You know we are here to support you.
text: Re tlhodilwe go itemogela maikutlo a a farologaneng, le go ithuta go a lemoga ka kgono e kgolo. Tiro e ntle! O a itse go re fano go go tshegetsa.

SourceText: Thank you for sharing how you are feeling today. If you would like, try this relaxation activity that can help recenter and ground your emotions.
text: Re lebogela go bo o re boleletse gore o ikutlwa jang gompieno. Fa o rata, leka tirwana e ya itapoloso go ithusa go ipatla le go tsepamisa maikutlo.

SourceText: Thank you for sharing how you are feeling. Is there anything someone can do to help you feeling better? If so, try reaching out to them, a support system is so important.
text: Re lebogela go bo o re boleletse gore o ikutlwa jang. A go sengwe se motho a ka se dirang go go thusa go ikutlwa botoka? Fa go le jalo, leka go ikgolaganya, tsamaiso ya tshegetso e botlhokwa tota.

SourceText: We have all experienced difficult days, but remember its important to experience all emotions. Try to do something that can help you feel better, like going for a walk or talking to someone you care about.
text: Rotlhe re na le malatsi a a boima, fela gopola gore go botlhokwa go itemogela maikutlo otlhe. Leka go dira sengwe se se ka go thusang go ikutlwa botoka, jaaka go tswela kwa ntle kgotsa go buisana le motho yo o mo kgathalelang.

SourceText: That is excellent news. When you feel good, your family around you also feels good!
text: Ke dikgang tse di monate. Fa o ikutlwa sentle, balelapa le bona ba ikutlwa sentle!

SourceText: We all experience days where we just feel fine, and that is completely okay!
text: Rotlhe re itemogela malatsi ao re ikutlwang fela sentle, mme go siame fela!

SourceText: You should not feel pressured to feel happy and great all the time. All feelings are valid and healthy!
text: OGa o a tshwanela go pateletsega go itumela le go ikutlwa sentle ka dinako tsotlhe. Maikutlo otlhe a botlhokwa e bile a itekanetse!

SourceText: Feeling okay is perfectly normal. Try asking how your family members are feeling today. This can help everyone to understand each other better.
text: Go ikutlwa sentle go tlwaelegile> Leka go botsa maloko a lelapa gore ba ikutlwa jang gompieno. seno se ka thusa gore ba tlhaloganye botoka.

SourceText: Part of keeping healthy is allowing yourself to feel all your emotions: the good, the bad, and the ones in the middle.
text: Karolo ya go itshola o itekanetse ke go itetla go itemogela maikutlo otlhe: a a simaneng, a a bosula, le a a magareng.

SourceText: There are days when we just go with the flow and it is completely perfect.
text: Gona le malatsi fao o ikelang fela le phefo mme go siame.

SourceText: It is completely normal to not feel great all the time. Parents all around the world have felt how you are feeling right now, and it is okay! You are doing great!
text: Go siame gore o se ikutlwe sentle ka dinako tsotlhe. Batsadi go ralala lefatshe ba kile ba ikutlwa fela jalo, mme go siame! O dira sentle!

SourceText: Just like everyone else, you are allowed to have days where they are not feeling great. Be gentle and patient with yourself. Tomorrow is a new day!
text: Fela jaaka ba bangwe botlhe, o letleletswe go nna le malatsi a o sa ikutlweng sentle. Nna pelotelele le go ineneketsa Ka moso ke letsatsi!

SourceText: Having a bad day is not a reflection of your abilities or of you as a parent. Just showing up shows you care.
text: Go nna le letsatsi le le seng monate ga go bontshe bokgoni jwa gago kgotsa ja gago jaaka motsadi. Go tlhagelela fela go bontsha gore o a kgathala.

SourceText: We all have difficult days that make us feel upset. Remember to be kind to yourself and others during these days. How you are feeling is not a representation of your abilities!
text: Rotlhe re na le malatsi a a boima a a re galefisang. Gopola go ineneketsa mmogo le ba bangwe mo malatsing a. Gore o ikutlwa jang ga go emele bokgoni jwa gago!

SourceText: We all have bad days, and we know it can sometimes be difficult to deal with your emotions. Learning how to cope with them in a posiitve way, sets you aside from others. If you have a few minutes to spare, use them to take care of yourself and focus on your breathing. Take this time to reflect on your feelings and try and redirect these emotions into something positive.
text: Rotlhe re na malatsi a a bosula, mme re a itse gore nako dingwe go nna boima go mekamekana le maikutlo a rona. Go ithuta gore o mekamekana jang le ona ka mokgwa o o siameng, go go beela thoko go na le ba bangwe. IFa o na le metsotso e e mmalwa go beela thoko, e dirise go itlhokomela le go tsepama mo go hemeng ga gago. Tsaya nako go leba maikutlo a gago mme o leke go a kaelagape go sengwe se se siameng.

SourceText: Learning to identify and accept your emotions will allow you to build a stronger relationship with yourself, your family and your community. Well done!
text: Go ithuta go supa le go amogela maikutlo a gago go tla go letla go aga dikamano tse di natlafetseng le wena, balelapa le baagi ba gago. O dirile sentle!

SourceText: Here is a short relaxation activity for you:
text: Fano ke tirwana e khutswane ya go ikhutsa go wena:

SourceText: Do you ever feel something so strongly that you want to run away from it? Here's a short activity that might help!
text: A o kile wa utlwa sengwe ka mo go tseneletseng mo o batlang go se tshabela? Fano ke tirwana e khutswane e e ka go thusang!

SourceText: This activity uses the magic power of three breaths to stay connected and relaxed.
text: Tirwana eno e dirisa matla a motlholo wa go hema gararo go tswelela go golagana le go repa.

SourceText: Here's an activity to relax your body:
text: Fano ke tiro e e ka ritibatsang mmele wa gago:

SourceText: Here is a quick relaxation activity...
text: Fano ke tirwana go iketla ka bonako...

SourceText: How many sounds can you hear? Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers.
text: O utlwa medumo e kae? Reetsa medumo e e mo teng le kwa ntle ga kamore. E bale ka menwana ya gago.

SourceText: Try again for another ten seconds. Did you hear any new sounds? Did you hear any sounds inside your own body? Notice how you feel now.
text: Leka gape metsotswana e le lesome. A o utlwile medumo e mesha? A o utlwile medumo mo teng ga mmele wa gago? Lemoga kafa o ikutlwang ka gone gone jaanong.

SourceText: Breathe in to the count of three.
text: Hemela ko teng makgetlo a mararo.

SourceText: Instead of moving away from the feeling, let’s move towards it for a moment.
text: Go na le go itlhokomolosa kafa o ikutlwang ka teng, tla reye mo go yone go se kae.

SourceText: It’s ok. Close your eyes if you feel comfortable. Take a deep breath.
text: Ga se bothata. Tswala matlho fa o kgona fa o nnisega. Wela makgwafo.

SourceText: Become curious. Where are you feeling it in your body? Is it hot or cold? Hard or soft? Tight or loose?
text: Batla go itse. O e utlwa kae mo mmeleng wa gago? E mogote kgotsa e tsididi? E thata kgotsa e boleta? E gagametse kgotsa ga ya gagamala?

SourceText: Ask yourself some questions. What is it telling me? What does it need? How can I be kind to myself in this moment?
text: Ipotse dipotso dingwe. Se mpolelelang? Se tlhoka eng? Nka ikutlwela botlhoko jang gone jaanong?

SourceText: If your mind starts to wander, it’s normal. Just bring it back to the feeling. Keep breathing and feeling.
text: Fa monagano wa gago o simolola go falla, go tlwaelegile. O busetse fela mo nakong e. Tswelela go hema le go ikutlwelela.

SourceText: Reassure yourself. It’s ok to feel. Feeling is healing!
text: Inetefaletse. Go siame go nna le maikutlo. Maikutlo a a fodisa.

SourceText: Notice your connection with the ground beneath you.
text: Lemoga kgolagano ya gago le le lefatshe le le kafa tlase ga gago.

SourceText: What parts of your body touch the ground? What parts of your body don’t?
text: Ke karolo dife tsa mmele wa gago tse di amang mo fatshe? Ke karolo dife tsa mmele wa gago tse di sa ameng fatshe?

SourceText: Notice where it feels warm and where it feels cool.
text: Elatlhoko gore go thuthafetse kae le mo o go tsidifetseng teng.

SourceText: Feel the ground underneath you supporting you. Let your body sink into the support of the ground.
text: Ikutlwe o tshegediwa ke lefatshe mo tlase ga gago. Letla mmele wa gago gore o tshegediwe ke lefatshe.

SourceText: Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
text: Hemela ko teng makgetlo a mararo. 1, 2, 3.

SourceText: Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
text: Hemela ko ntle makgetlo a mararo. 1, 2, 3.

SourceText: Sit comfortably and close your eyes if you can.
text: Dula sentle mme o tswale matlho fa o kgona.

SourceText: Imagine a golden ring scanning your body from your feet to your head.
text: Akanya ka palamonwana ya gauta e sekaseka mmele wa gago go tswa mo maotong go ya ko tlhogong.

SourceText: Pay attention as it moves up and down your body. Are there any areas that feel tense? Numb? Painful?
text: Tlhwaya tsebe jaaka fa e ntse e ya godimo le tlase mo mmeleng wa gago. A go na le dikarolo tsa mmele tse di tiileng? Di sule bogatsu? Di botlhoko?

SourceText: Focus on those areas for a moment. Breathe in to the area and when you breathe out, try to let go of any tension or pain.
text: Tlhoma mogopolo mo dikarolong tseno metsotswana. Hemela mo teng ga karolo eo mme o ntshe mowa, leka go tsamaisa tiya goo kgotsa botlhoko joo.

SourceText: Do this for a few breaths.
text: Dira seno ka go hema ka makgetlo.

SourceText: Open your eyes. How does your body feel now?
text: Bula matlho a gago. Mmele wa gago o ikutlwa jang jaanong?

SourceText: Try this next time you find yourself lying in bed unable to sleep!
text: Leka seno mo nakong e e tlang fa o iphitlhela o robetse mo bolaong mme o sa kgone go robala!

SourceText: Listen to the sounds.
text: Reetsa medumo.

SourceText: Connection with the ground.
text: Kgolaganyo le lefatshe.

SourceText: Notice how you feel now.
text: Lemoga kafa o ikutlwang ka gone gone jaanong.

SourceText: How do you feel now? Do you feel any different? Deep breathing helps our whole body and mind to calm down.
text: Jaanong o ikutlwa jang? A o utlwa pharologanyo? Go hemela ko teng go thusa mmele otlhe wa rona le mogopolo gore di ritibale.

SourceText: Dealing with difficult feelings.
text: Go mekamekana le maikutlo a a boima.

SourceText: Body relaxation.
text: Mmele o a repa.

SourceText: It’s ok to feel. Feeling is healing!
text: Go siame go nna le maikutlo. Maikutlo a a fodisa.

SourceText: Let’s use the magic power of three to stay present and relax. At the end of a tough day, thinking of three things to be grateful for can help us find the courage to try again tomorrow.
text: A re dirise maatla a motlholo wa tharo go nna fano e bile re iketlile. Morago ga letsatsi le le boima, akanya ka dilo tse tharo tse o di lebogelang go re thusa go bona bopelokgale jwa go leka gape kamoso.

SourceText: Here's a short relaxation activity to end the day:
text: Fano ke tirwana e khutswane ya go ikhutsa ka bokhutlong jwa letsatsi:

SourceText: Let's take a moment to stop what you are doing and connect with your breath.
text: Tsaya motsotso go emisa se o se dirang mme o ikgolaganye le tsela e o hemang ka yone.

SourceText: What is one thing you can be grateful for right now?
text: Ke selo sefe se le sengwe se o se lebogelang gone jaanong?

SourceText: What is one thing that brings you happiness?
text: Ke selo sefe se le sengwe se se go itumedisang?

SourceText: What is one thing that you love?
text: Ke selo sefe se le sengwe se o se ratang?

SourceText: They don't have to be big. Sometimes the small things in life count the most!
text: Ga di a tshwanela go nna dikgolo. Ka dinako tse dingwe dilo tse dinnye mo botshelong ke tsone di leng botlhokwa thata!

SourceText: At the end of the day, take a minute to think about the day.
text: Kwa bokhutlong jwa letsatsi lengwe le lengwe, tsaya motsotso o akanye ka letsatsi.

SourceText: Think about one positive or fun thing you did.
text: Akanya ka sengwe se le nosi se se siameng kgotsa se se monate se o se dirileng.

SourceText: Think of one thing you can do differently tomorrow.
text: Akanya ka selo se le sengwe se o ka se dirang ka tsela e e farologaneng kamoso.

SourceText: Think of one thing that you are grateful for.
text: Bitsa selo se le sengwe se o se lebogelang.

SourceText: Do you sometimes feel like you are getting everything wrong?  Here's a short activity that might help!
text: A o na le go ikutlwa o ka re ga go sepe se se go tsamaelang sentle ka nako dingwe?  Fano ke tirwana e khutswane e e ka go thusang!

SourceText: The magic power of three.
text: Matla a motlholo wa tharo.

SourceText: Close your eyes and think about the day. Name 1 thing that you are grateful for. Name 1 thing that you did well. Name 1 think that you love. You earned a goodnight of sleep!
text: Tswala matlho a gago mme o akanye ka letsatsi la gago. Bitsa selo se le 1 se o se lebogelang. Bitsa selo se le 1 se o se dirileng sentle. Bitsa selo se le 1 se o se ratang. O tshwanelwa ke boroko jo bo monate!

SourceText: Take a moment to think over the day. Think of one thing you did today that you are proud of.
text: Tsaya motsotso go akanya ka letsatsi. Mme jaanong mme o akanye selo se le sengwe se o se dirileng gompieno se o leng motlotlo ka sona.

SourceText: Wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug.
text: Itlamparele ka matsogo a gago mme o iphe tlamparelo e kgolo!

SourceText: Think of one thing you did today that you don’t feel proud of. What can you do differently tomorrow?
text: Akanya selo se le sengwe se o se dirileng gompieno se o leng motlotlo ka sona. O ka dirang ka pharologanyo ka moso?

SourceText: And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug.
text: Jaanong itlamparele ka matsogo a gago mme o iphe tlamparelo e kgolo!

SourceText: Connect with your breath.
text: Golagana le go hema ga gago.

SourceText: Take a minute to think about the day.
text: Tsaya motsotso o akanye ka letsatsi.

SourceText: End of the day.
text: Kwa bokhutlong jwa letsatsi

SourceText: Be kind to yourself.
text: Ineneketse.

SourceText: You earned a goodnight of sleep!
text: O tshwanelwa ke boroko jo bo monate!

SourceText: It’s ok. You are doing your best so be kind to yourself. Get some rest and try again tomorrow!
text: Ga se bothata. O dira bojotlhe jalo ineneketse. Ikhutse mme o leke gape ka moso!

SourceText: Do your children ever make you feel like screaming? Give yourself a 10-second pause.
text: A bana ba gago ba a tle ba dire gore o batle go goeletsa? Iphe metsotswana e 10 o eme go se kae.

SourceText: Have you only got 30 seconds? Let's take a quick pause together. It might be helpful.
text: A o na le metsotswana e le 30 fela? Tla re eme go se kae mmogo! go ka thusa.

SourceText: Do you sometimes feel your feelings are too much?
text: A o na le go akanya gore go gontsi ka nako dingwe?

SourceText: Talk to someone.
text: Buisana le mongwe.

SourceText: Talk to someone you trust. Talk to a friend. Talk to family. Talk to a plant.
text: Buisana le mongwe. Bua le tsala. Bua le balelapa. Bua le sejalo.

SourceText: Get your worries off your chest and then let them go. Even if it’s just for a moment.
text: Ntsha matshwenyego a gago mo mafatlheng mme o kgaoane le ona. Le fa e le motsotswana fela.

SourceText: How do you feel now?
text: Jaanong o ikutlwa jang?

SourceText: A joy shared is twice the joy. A problem shared is half the problem.
text: Boitumelo jo bo arolelanelwang bo oketsega gabedi. Mathata a a arolelanelwang ke halofo ya mathata.

SourceText: Here is something fun to help you let go of stress:
text: Fano ke sengwe se se ka go thusang go tsamaisa go tshwenyega mo maikutlong ga gago:

SourceText: Sit down, close your eyes and listen to your breath as it goes in and out. Notice how you feel. When you are ready open your eyes again.
text: Nna fa fatshe, tswala matlho a gago mme o reetse mohemo wa gago jaaka o tsena o tswa. Lemoga kafa o ikutlwang ka gone. Fa go siametse go dira jalo bula matlho a gago gape.

SourceText: Breath in and out slowly 5 times. Then try responding in a calmer way.
text: Hemela ko teng le ko ntle makgetlo a 5. Mme leka go araba o kgobile makgwafo.

SourceText: Choose a song that reflects what you need in this moment. Do you need a gentle song to soothe your tired soul or an upbeat song to help you shake some stress out?
text: Tlhopha pina e e bontshang se o se tlhokang gone jaanong. A o tlhoka pina e e seng modumo go ritibatsa moya wa gago o o lapileng kgotsa pina e e tla go binisang go go thusa go ntsha go tshwenyega mo maikutlong?

SourceText: Make a space and move your body to the music. Remember to breathe while you move. Let your breath and the movement go together.
text: Dira sebaka mme o tshikinye mmele ka go binela pina. Gopola go hema fa o ntse o itshikinya. Letlelela mohemo wa gago le go tshikinya mmele ga gago go tsamaisane mmogo.

SourceText: Even a few minutes of movement can be enough to release stress and lift your mood!
text: Le metsotso e mmalwa e ka siame go go thusa go tsamaisa go tshwenyega mo maikutlong mme o a itumela!

SourceText: Choose a song that reflects what you need.
text: Tlhopha pina e e bontshang se o se tlhokang.

SourceText: Five deep breaths.
text: Hemela kwa teng gararo.

SourceText: Listen to your breath.
text: Itheetse fa o hema.

SourceText: When feelings are too much.
text: Fa maikutlo a go ntsifalela.

SourceText: Millions of parents say this helps - A LOT.
text: Dimilione tsa batsadi di a re seno se a thusa - THATA.

SourceText: Try this whenever you are feeling stressed and you need a break to reconnect.
text: Leka seno fa o ikutlwa o tshwenyegile mo maikutlong mme o tlhoka go ikhutsa gore ikgolaganye gape.

SourceText: That's wonderful! We are happy to hear that you are feeling good.
text: Lo dirile bontle tota! Re itumeletse go utlwa gore o ikutlwa sentle.

SourceText: That's wonderful! I am happy to hear that you are feeling good.
text: Lo dirile bontle tota! Ke itumeletse go utlwa gore o ikutlwa sentle.

SourceText: We are sorry to hear that you are not feeling great today. Remember to take it one day at the time. Tomorrow is a new day.
text: Re maswabi go utlwa gore ga o ikutwle sentle gompieno. Gopola go tsaya kgato e le nngwe letsatsi le letsatsi. Ka moso ke letsatsi!

SourceText: I am sorry to hear that you are not feeling great today. Remember to take it one day at the time. Tomorrow is a new day.
text: Ke maswabi go utlwa gore ga o ikutwle sentle gompieno. Gopola go tsaya kgato e le nngwe letsatsi le letsatsi. Ka moso ke letsatsi!

SourceText: Hooray! We are delighted to hear that you are doing well.
text: Ilililiiii! Re itumelela go utlwa gore lo tsoga sentle.

SourceText: Hooray! I am delighted to hear that you are doing well.
text: Ilililiiii! Ke itumelela go utlwa gore lo tsoga sentle.

SourceText: Fabulous! We are so happy to hear this.
text: Bontle! Re itumeletse go utlwa seno.

SourceText: Fabulous! I am so happy to hear this.
text: Bontle! Ke itumeletse go utlwa seno.

SourceText: What a great feeling! We hope that good feeling continues throughout the entire day.
text: A maikutlo a a monate! Re tshepa gore maikutlo a mantle a a tswelela letsatsi lotlhe.

SourceText: What a great feeling! I hope that good feeling continues throughout the entire day.
text: A maikutlo a a monate! Ke tshepa gore maikutlo a mantle a a tswelela letsatsi lotlhe.

SourceText: We are glad to hear this! We are sure your family is happy to see you this way as well.
text: Re itumeletse go utlwa seno. Re tshepa gore balelapa ba itumele go go bona o le ka mokgwa o le bona.

SourceText: I am glad to hear this! I am sure your family is happy to see you this way as well.
text: Ke itumeletse go utlwa seno. Ke tshepa gore balelapa ba itumele go go bona o le ka mokgwa o le bona.

SourceText: What fantastic news! We hope you continue to feel good throughout the day.
text: A dikgang tse dintle! Re tshepa gore o tswelela go ikutlwa sentle letsatsi lotlhe.

SourceText: What fantastic news! I hope you continue to feel good throughout the day.
text: A dikgang tse dintle! Ke tshepa gore o tswelela go ikutlwa sentle letsatsi lotlhe.

SourceText: It makes us very happy to hear that you are feeling good! Take that good energy and share it with others!
text: Ke itumeletse go utlwa gore o ikutlwa sentle. Tsaya enenji e e siameng eo mme o e abelane le ba bangwe!

SourceText: It makes me very happy to hear that you are feeling good! Take that good energy and share it with others!
text: Ke itumeletse go utlwa gore o ikutlwa sentle. Tsaya enenji e e siameng eo mme o e abelane le ba bangwe!
